story:
Why should I invest in my community?

Hi, I'm Karen Chan, the founder of HART Project. I'm a registered nurse and artist who has a connection to working with vulnerable inner city kids--ie. ones from the Downtown Eastside in Vancouver, Canada. To paint a picture, the kids we work/play with live in a community where we have to pick up used syringes / condoms before they can do so. Could these kids be given opportunities and positive mentors so they can have a stronger start?

HART Project = ART + HEALTH Initiatives. 

  •       Building Community / Empowering Kids to be healthy through ART
  •        ART as a universal tool for health advocacy / education / awareness

Our goal is to register as a non-profit organization (NPO) in Canada & continue to mentor vulnerable kids to be empowered by the arts to lead healthy lives.

Registering as a NPO allow us to sustain growth, change and have a broader effect. We can apply for larger grants to run our pilot projects on a bigger scale-- from our test sites in Vancouver to across Canada. We like to think big!

For more info on our projects so far, visit http://www.hartproject.ca

What we need to create a social movement!

Here's the nitty-gritty to starting a NPO: before we go after the big guns (grants) we need the foundation. We need a professional, concise way to get info to you, recruit volunteers and build momentum!

Website + Design + social media (at reduced rate): $300

Adminstrative Fees: $200-$300,

This includes creating a small reserve to pay small honorariums to participants in our projects eg. low-income teens, free groceries, bus tickets

Art + health supplies: $700

We ran our 1st project, a street photography workshop for 12 kids, on a shoestring budget of under $250. Our current project of making a film with street-involved teens, only received enough funding to work with 2 or less teens! 

Project funding: $2000 for the next 6 months

1. Next project: improve access to youth resources for vulnerable youth in partnership with VCC Nursing School & community partners.

2. Teen Video Project: introduces street-involved teens to film & to services such as youth clinics or outreach nursing teams.We would like to buy supplies like condoms, art supplies, food to give to participants, cover printing costs to create health teaching tools.

3. Anonymous Valentine Project: write postcards to an anonymous woman/child affected by violence/assault or trauma. These will be hand delivered to shelters by bicycle.

4. Art and mental health artshow to decrease stigma: For the past 3 years I have been drawing random "street people" in Vancouver and writing captions from my conversations with them. I hope to draw 100 people and tell their unheard stories in their own words. 

"As a registered nurse and artist, I am passionate about the effect creativity can have on vulnerable individuals. It gives them a voice, an outlet and a sense of confidence."

                                                                                                           Karen Chan, RN

The Impact

This project uses a creative approach to work with unique individuals from different populations, where a creative, accessible approach is more impactful.
Whether you can contribute $, "brain power" ie. volunteering as skilled mentor or bright ideas, or just spread the word, HART Project applauds you.

In a few words, HART Project hopes to

  • Decrease the stigma of living in poverty, improve access to basic necessities
  • Use art as a tool to teach and to advocate for vulnerable individuals

We would like to point out our successful projects so far!

1. eyeCapture photography workshop for kids gave low-income kids a unique photographic voice and helped build artistic confidence

2. HART Project's community mural at Raycam Community Centre helped engage the community (young and old) to cover graffiti

Our promise to you is to be transparent in how we use your funding for this grassroots organization. We will always be accountable & put as much $ into running the projects as is humanly possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

Be gabby and spread the word!
We're on Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest

Donate unloved art supplies such as easels, film cameras, tripods, paints.

Volunteer! One of the challenges with building a movement from the grass up is a lack of skilled volunteers. We'd love volunteers from all sectors, especially financial, healthcare, art... so insert your name here! _________________

Use the Indiegogo share tools!


Any questions? Feel free to email Karen at ihartvan@gmail.com.
Thanks for all your support!

story:
Short Summary

Hey there! I'm Daniel, an iOS and Web developer. I started coding aged around 8, and it has been the most empowering skill that I have ever learnt. I am personally almost fully self taught, although a few people have been a great help along the way.

I would love to put together a short 14 week course, to get people started in iOS development, and I could just put together a series of generic tutorial videos on YouTube, however, I don't feel that this offers a good way of teaching people to actually code their own projects.

What I'm proposing is a 1 - 2 hour video each week, explaining how to use 1 or 2 core librarys or system features, such as CoreAnimation, CoreGraphics, the Acceleromter and GPS. At the end of which, I will set a challenge to be completed that week, with a reasonably open scope, to create something using what you know so far.

Obviously, some people on the course will be complete beginners, so the first weeks course will feature the basics: Creating a new project, using storyboards, variables, methods and other language features, and I will provide my skype, phone and e-mail details to people on the course, to offer them help as needed.

If the project goes well, I hope to offer a limited number of scholarship places, to allow those who cannot afford to enter the course, or for younger people who do not have their own bank accounts. As well as to publically release the videos after the course has finished.

What We Need

To make the project happen to a high standard, I have some expenses to pay:

  • A high quality microphone, I will be purchasing a Blue Snowball or Blue Yeti, depending on the success of the project, as they offer great sound quality, without being really expensive.
  • Vimeo Pro, I will be purchasing a year of vimeo pro, to offer high definition video content, without advertising or upload limits (as each video will probably be around 2 - 3 hours long)
  • Web based storage, I will also provide a downloadable version of each video in H.264 1080p, this takes up a lot of space and bandwidth.
  • iOS Provisioning profiles, I will set up as many users as possible with iOS provisioning profiles so they can test their applications on device. This will require me to take out a second iOS developer membership.

The Impact

This project will allow many people to learn what is a truly fundamental skill in a modern world - programming, and open up access to high quality tutorials for iOS (as there are alot of development courses for the web and android, but not many for iOS)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, sharing this project with your friends and family using the indiegogo share tools would be absolutely amazing, to help the project come alive.

Thanks, for helping, you good looking person.

story:
What is KALE*?

* Kallaloo Alternative Learning Experience

The KALE* Project is a non-profit REM initiative, based in Maine and St. Croix, U.S.V.I., focused on enriching high school students educational experience through agricultural and cultural summer camp.  With a focus on food security and the health, as well as economic benefits, of growing and eating local foods, The KALE Project will empower students by working on leadership and team building skills. 

The project needs this funding for 8 scholarships, or $13,200, for Caribbean youth, who will interact with their counterparts in Maine.  We also need airfare for each student, a few inexpensive digital cameras, a video camera, camping gear for special trips (tents and new sleeping bags), and the ability to begin funding local initiatives in the Caribbean.  Scholarships will be given to students from economically challenged families under the guidelines of the U.S.V.I. Department of Agriculture. 

KALE began as a dream of Bonnie Davis, to foster interest in agriculture, food security and sustainability for Caribbean Youth.  As a freelance writer in Maine, she learned about the exciting local food movement.  Growing up on a family farm in New Jersey and moving to St. Croix, U.S.V.I. a pre teen, she knows the importance of fresh, local foods as well as the need for art and cultural exchange. 

With the support of local youth programs, farmers, farmers' markets, local artists, and the Maine, U.S.V.I. and U.S. Departments of Agriculture as well as the Maine University Extension service, teens will learn the importance of farming, local food initiatives and cultural experiences. Island teens will pair with Maine teens to exchange ideas and learn about each other's culture.  In the future, Maine teens will also have the opportunity to visit the Caribbean for a true exchange program.

What We Need & What You Get

The kick-off project will be a summer program for a limited (6-8) number of teenagers from the U.S.V.I. to come to for a 6-week summer program focused on agriculture, art and culture. 

The program will include:

  • Why farming is so important – no farms, no food
  • Why healthy food is a right, not a privilege
  • The importance of local foods
  • Leadership & teamwork skills
  • Different farming practices, soil, composting, etc., through the Master Gardeners from the University of Maine Extension Service
  • How to store various foods – freeze, dry, can
  • Customer service & marketing
  • Computer, math, writing skills & their importance in agriculture
  • Involvement with the Mid-Maine International Film Festival
  • Art, theater, crafts & meeting people of other cultures
  • African & Native American Drumming
  • Creating free educational videos & documentaries for Caribbean youth in developing nations, such as Haiti & Jamaica
  • Field trips to local farms, farmer’s markets, museums, historical interests, Boston, and other surrounding areas
  • Camping, canoeing/kayaking, swimming, hiking in Maine

Future projects will include support for agricultural projects such as school and community gardens.  KALE* plans to award grants and micro loans to assist island agricultural, educational and food related endeavors for people who would not otherwise be able to do so.

While KALE* is a non-profit, there is a sliding scale depending on economic need ($1,650.00 to $2,550.00) for the 6-week program, including room and board, traveling during the program, admissions, etc.  Students need roundtrip airfare and spending money.  Full scholarships are available for qualifying students.

KALE, since it is the first program year, also needs cameras, video equipment and camping gear.

Contributors will receive perks as well as the joy of having helped youth in Maine, the U.S. Virgin Islands and developing Caribbean nations.

The Impact

As the world economy struggles, the need for food security and independence grows.  KALE* hopes to help teens get excited about growing food by hands on experience.  Bonnie Davis has worked on the United Nations Millennium Campaign since 2005.  Through planning conferences on global poverty, she met Jan Schrock, the daughter of Dan West who founded Heifer International.  The KALE* Project asks participants to pass on their teachings to others as part of their involvement, much as Heifer asks participants to pass on the gift of a goat, heifer, etc. Jan Schrock lives in Maine.  She is a mentor to this project and plans to give a presentation during their program.

Not only will contributions assist programming for summer camp, but they will also help students create learning videos for teens in the developing Caribbean nations such as Haiti and Jamaica.  Kids teaching kids is an awesome way to learn.  KALE also hopes through culture and agriculture, the Caribbean islands will focus on trading with each other to help stabilize their economies.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Please speak with your church, civic organization, colleagues and friends to spread the word.
  • Like The KALE Project 2013 on Facebook and share the project's needs through your social media.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

"Our lives begin to end the day we become silent about things that matter." 

Martin Luther King, Jr.

Other Ways You Can Help


Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Martin Luther King, Jr.

story:
Who We Are

ACLA (a.k.a. ArtsCorpsLA) is a public art and land collective that focuses on transforming unused urban land into dynamic art parks with localized, community-directed programing. La Tierra de la Culebra was the first of these parks, established over 20 years ago by artist Tricia Ward and 35 youth volunteers in the neighborhood of Highland Park. While we continue our work with the visual arts, dance, landscape design, and academia as an example of community-directed public space, we are also engaged in the creation of our fifth art park, the Spiraling Orchard.

Many of the young people who built our parks and learned these skills in our program come back and work with the next generation. The majority of our staff, volunteers and board members are people who grew up in ACLA.

What We Need & What You Get

The County of Los Angeles has offered to reward our efforts with a grant of $19,000. Our task is to raise a matching amount so that we can expand music and arts programming, create permaculture demonstration gardens, and further develop on-site internships for local youth.

Donate now and claim one of the truly unique perks on the right side of this page. Over a span of twenty years we’ve been able to create a lot of amazing art and we would like to share some of it with you.

 

Tricia Ward-designed Spiraling Culebra screen prints.

  

Intriguing, hand poured, one-of-a-kind 4x4 iron and aluminum tiles that will beautifully accent any tile patio or staircase.

Have your name--or someone else's--engraved on a brick in our new "John Maroney Pavilion" at Spiraling Orchard Art Park.

These are gifts you’ll be proud to display simply because of their beauty, but through your support of ACLA you can be extra proud that your aesthetic taste will result in the continuation of teaching youth life skills through the arts.

The Impact

Our program works with young people to

• Support their ability to think critically about themselves and the world around them

• Develop leadership and life skills

• Create greater autonomy and independence in their passage to adulthood

• Increase locally focused civic engagement by community members of all ages

• Create cleaner, healthier local environments

We do this through

• The visual arts

• Music and performance

• Project management

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about us to your family and friends who support art as a way of teaching young people valuable life skills.

Post our campaign on your Facebook wall and Twitter with a personal endorsement of the work we do.

Come on out to our parks and volunteer!

story:
Short Description 

Aiming to promote conversations and discussions amongst young people of Vietnam, in the summer of 2008, a group of students in Hanoi and students studying overseas initiated the Vietnam Youth Forum project.

From its first days, the Vietnam Youth Forum has provided an off-campus, non-traditional classroom experience for young people. It has enabled them to discuss, share, learn, connect and generate fresh ideas and microscopic solutions for various issues of Vietnam. Activities and events are organized for and by young people aged between 16 and 22. Furthermore, the Forum offers workshop training to develop the skills of its participants so that they can carry out meaningful changes in their communities through their independent projects.

The Vietnam Youth Forum 2013 is the sixth annual forum of the VYF project which will take place this summer in Hanoi.  

Our Goal

The mission of the Vietnam Youth Forum includes

●   Provide the Vietnamese youth with background knowledge of social issues, raise their awareness of global environment and encourage them to learn and contribute to their communities

●   Create a link between guest speakers (usually experts and pioneers in different fields) and Vietnamese youth to assist the exchange and discussion of outstanding issues of the year.

●   Develop and enhance essential skills of leadership, organization, presentation, communication, and team-work.

●   Establish an environment where young people can express their ideas and opinions, as well as propose initiatives and solutions to current social problems

●   Encourage and nourish youth motivation and inspiration to carry out new projects directly benefiting the community

●   Forge a network of future leaders with a firm commitment to their communities

●   Promote VYF values, thus strengthening the link between VYF and Vietnamse youth

 

Highlights of the program:

- VYF is one of the first forums for youth and organized totally by youth, allowing young Vietnamese people to express their views and learn about issues of local, national, and global importance.

- VYF's candidates are all young Vietnamese people who are living in Vietnam or studying abroad. They are proactive and curious youth, who are interested in social issues and want to create changes in their communities.

- The content of the forum covers many fields and revolves around the Forum's main theme each year in order to provide an effective and focused approach to specific topics.

- VYF activities are organized with the consultancy of notable advisors and guest speakers such as: Mr. Duong Trung Quoc - Historian and Member of the National Assembly, Ms. Pham Chi Lan - Senior Economist, Mr. Tran Viet Duc - General Partner of IDG Ventures Vietnam, Dr. Nguyen Huu Ninh - Environmentalist...,

- The ultimate purpose of the forum is not only to discuss and share experiences, but also to inspire and enforce the post-Forum community projects. This is the purpose of the Inspiration for Action Day, which offers participants methods to a deeper understanding of personal preferences, tendencies, weaknesses and strengths.

 

Remarkable Post-Forum Community Projects:

1. TEDx Youth @ Hanoi - 2011 & 2012

TEDxYouth @ Hanoi is a branch of the world's TED - a global set of conferences which was held in 60 countries with the purpose of disseminate "ideas worth spreading." The goal of the project is to bring TED's ideas to Vietnam in order to spread the spirit of TED: "To Create and to Share."

2. Tay-Nguyen Youth Forum - 2011

The project focused on discussing heated issues in Central Highlands Vietnam such as preservation of traditional culture, educational innovation, environmental issues, and climate change.

3. Rainbow Campaign - 2011

The participants in the campaign cycled from Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam via the Mekong Delta provinces to Phnom Penh, Cambodia and returned via Moc Bai border gate in Tay Ninh. During the journey, the campaign members organized information dissemination activities and expanded awareness of human trafficking for the people in the provinces near the border Vietnam - Cambodia.

4. Say "Vietnam" Project - 2011

The project builds up a network/website to connect Vietnamese Culture and Humanitarian with 3 professional pages to introduce the culture, Vietnamese language, and to develop Specialized humanitarian fund development program.

5. Green Future of Children - 2011

This is an environmental education project in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam with the slogan "Paint the Green, Draw the Future." Activities of the projects are associated with environmental education and entertainment model, which combines 3 parts: a chain of festivals, the "Green Future" workshop, and tourism activities.

 Dành cho những bạn không có thẻ VISA, Master Card hay tài khoản PayPal

Tên chủ tài khoản: Hoàng Chiến Công

STK: 4214 9459 0012 6053

story_txt:
Short Description 
Aiming to promote conversations and discussions amongst young people of Vietnam, in the summer of 2008, a group of students in Hanoi and students studying overseas initiated the Vietnam Youth Forum project.
From its first days, the Vietnam Youth Forum has provided an off-campus, non-traditional classroom experience for young people. It has enabled them to discuss, share, learn, connect and generate fresh ideas and microscopic solutions for various issues of Vietnam. Activities and events are organized for and by young people aged between 16 and 22. Furthermore, the Forum offers workshop training to develop the skills of its participants so that they can carry out meaningful changes in their communities through their independent projects.
The Vietnam Youth Forum 2013 is the sixth annual forum of the VYF project which will take place this summer in Hanoi.  
Our Goal
The mission of the Vietnam Youth Forum includes
●   Provide the Vietnamese youth with background knowledge of social issues, raise their awareness of global environment and encourage them to learn and contribute to their communities
●   Create a link between guest speakers (usually experts and pioneers in different fields) and Vietnamese youth to assist the exchange and discussion of outstanding issues of the year.
●   Develop and enhance essential skills of leadership, organization, presentation, communication, and team-work.
●   Establish an environment where young people can express their ideas and opinions, as well as propose initiatives and solutions to current social problems
●   Encourage and nourish youth motivation and inspiration to carry out new projects directly benefiting the community
●   Forge a network of future leaders with a firm commitment to their communities
●   Promote VYF values, thus strengthening the link between VYF and Vietnamse youth

story:
LOTUS ELEMENT

 

17 years ago all of my blood vessels in a major organ collasped, nearly killed me. Because I was relatively young at the time, this experience inspired me to encourage youth to make smarter choices that can lead to healthier lifestyles. Today I am devoted to broadening children's knowledge of alternative health options that are geared towards helping them eat better and be more physically active. Ultimately, my goal is to help designate an alternative health youth coach in every home.

What is Lotus Element?

Lotus Element is a place where youth can converge to enhance both mentally and physically in the area of alternative health, with the goal of living a healthier lifestyle. By facilitating the 9 Pillars of Scientific Consciousness (Imagination, Contemplation, Meditation, Experimentation, Visualization, Observation, Concentration, Discrimination and Adoration) and providing alternative health education, research, energy exercises, going green experiments, currency respect, and mental health wellness strategies, Lotus Element will foster an equal opportunity for youth to fall in love with discovering the importance of pursuing a healthy lifestyle.

Why I Am Doing This?

My plight to instill healthy values into children stems from concerns I have with the lack of resources available to people who yearn for healthier lifestyles. After conducting extensive research, it has become clear to me that this slow economy restricts one's access to resources such as private schooling, summer vacations, supplements, books, organic foods, and post secondary education.

In light of this, I targeted a community that has little or no exposure to the alternative health knowledge that I have gained. Door to door I went asking mothers if they would allow me to teach their children “healthy habits” in my home. Eventually I met a woman named Sharon. I shared with Sharon my passion for healthy choices as well as ideas I am mulling that could lead to having a designated alternative health youth coach in every home. Sharon stated that she wanted something better for her children, an opportunity for them to do well in life.

I successfully convinced Sharon to allow me to teach her children “healthy habits,” which was a small labor of love compared to Sharon's loving courage to change the health, mindset and future of her children.

Your Impact

You could potentially help thousands of families that want something better for their children. Your generous donation will undoubtely help create a wealth of new opportunity for children to achieve healthy eating and lifestyle behaviors. As I looked in my rear view mirror at the glow on the faces of Sharon's children, watching the energy of their pointing fingers and their thinking caps shifting into high gear, I marveled at their exuberance and genuine desire to learn more about healthy eating. Your donation will change lifestyles as well as the lifestyles of countless other children, forever.

 

 

What We Need

Lotus Element needs Smart Boards, program and project funding. As we facilitate our Currency Respect program to our children it is important to us to formulate a strategy that shows our children that thinking outside of the box is a financially freeing exercise that can prevent debt and poverty while simultaneously strenghtening the economy.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We thank you in advance for any level of donation that you are empowered to help us with and welcome your passion to volunteer.

story:
My Story 

Music is my passion. I love to write and create songs that people can enjoy and relate to. At Columbia College Chicago, I am studying Audio Design and Production where I am learning how to turn acoustic and electronic sound into a professional quality recording. My ultimate goal is to become a music producer, and to write, record, and produce music for artists in the industry today. 


This coming Spring semester, I will be blessed with the opportunity to study abroad at the University of East London. The school was started in 1892, and hosts 28,000 students from 120 countries. This diversity in culture will allow me to be exposed to many different people and styles of music, and will help me grow as an artist. The school also just opened a new campus, University Square Stratford, which is home to 3 new state of the art performance studios and over £750,000 in brand new music recording equipment. 


Studying at UEL will provide me with access to high quality facilities to work and to hone my craft in. The school is situated in the music hub of the world, London, England, and that in itself will immerse me in a massively influential music community. Having this opportunity at this point in time in my development as an artist and music producer is crucial, and I will definitely gain insights and knowledge at UEL that I could not obtain at any other institution. 


What I Need & What You Get

Attending the school of course requires me to travel a long distance. This is not a normal expense, and will require me to obtain a passport, visa, and round trip plane ticket. For this campaign, I am looking to offset the financial burden that those expenses will put on me, but I would like to provide my sponsors with unique services in return. 


My goal is to raise $2,000 to cover the costs of all the necessary expenses that this trip calls for. Any sponsorship amount will greatly help me in this experience!


$5

You will receive a personal "thank you" shout out on Facebook for your generous donation!


$10

I will be keeping a blog while I spend my semester abroad, and at this level you will receive the link to my blog so that you can keep up on my travels and experiences!


$20

During my stay in London, I will send you a postcard to update you on my experience abroad!

*Note: If you choose this level you will receive the postcard, AND the link to my blog.


$50

At the sponsor level, you can choose any song that you like for me to perform a cover of on guitar or piano, and I will send you a video while I'm in London!

*Note: At this level you will receive the cover video, AND the postcard, AND the link to my blog. 


$100

Upon my return, I will cook you and your family a proper, authentic English meal! 

*Note: At this level you will receive the meal, AND the postcard AND link to my blog.


$200

For this sponsorship level, you can choose any topic, idea, person, place, thing, etc for me to write, record and fully produce a song about. I will put to use the knowledge and techniques that I have gained while attending Columbia, and I will create and engineer a high quality recording for your enjoyment. 

*Note: At this level you will receive the written and recorded song, AND a postcard, AND the link to my blog. 



(You do not have to choose any of those amounts if you do not wish to; any amount would be greatly appreciated!)


The Impact

As you know, music plays a very important role in many people's lives. It helps us manage stress, get through tough days, remember special moments, and brings happiness and joy into our lives. I would be very grateful for anyone's contribution to help me have this once in a lifetime experience, which will in turn play a huge role in my development as a songwriter and engineer and will allow me to bring more music to the world. 



Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to sponsor me and make a contribution, you can still help me out by sharing this campaign on your Facebook wall or Twitter feed! Everyone is in touch with a wide range of people, and I would benefit greatly from your social reach. 



Thank you so much for your time and consideration!


-Daly O'Brien


Here is a link to my SoundCloud where you can listen to songs that I have already written:

https://soundcloud.com/dalyobrien

story:
Using Shakespeare's ageless language and eloquent dramatic insight into people and events our mission is to bring our students from the Inner City High Schools of Los Angeles, mostly South Central, East LA, parts of the San Fernando Valley and other schools without Arts programs, into the world of "Theater". With the support of professional mentors, students find that they are able to realize their own special talents and perform with style and substance.

These students, who often have had no exposure to any of the dramatic arts, perform in original text. The entry into the language and stories is not an easy one for the young students but were the plays performed in street speech, there would be an element of self-consciousness in not being "cool".

Now they will speak in a new tongue, a language that encourages them to be bold in manner, demean and also gives them an immense sense of achievement and a new outlook on their lives!

We are now into the fourth year of our program.


WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET!

This year, Shakespeare's 450th Anniversary,  we are putting on a major production of A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM, at the city's showcase Park (Grand Park) bordering the Music Center in LA. Followed by a series of weekend performances in 5-6 County Parks.  Funds raised will help defray the cost of these productions.

Specifically the funding raised here will go to:

  • Costumes, scenery and props
  • Rental of rehearsal and performance space
  • Printing and copying fees
  • Advertising, ticketing and house management costs
  • Stage design
  • Rigging
  • Other on-site needs
  • Insurance Coverage
  • Transportation Stipends

Listed down the right hand side of the page are a series of exclusive perks you will receive for donating anything from $1 to $500 towards the production.  As a supporter of this program you will also receive the proud feeling and gratitude that goes with it!  If you have a question about a specific perk, drop us an email and we will be happy to answer!


Other Ways You Can Help

While every dollar helps, so does every word of promotion. If you are unable to support us financially, please utilize the indiegogo share functions, email, text or call people you know to help us spread the message and reach as many people as possible. Taking the time to share our project is a form of support that is not only appreciated but needed.

TWEET or    FACEBOOK the link to this page & help us spread the word!

Attend one of this year's productions of "A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM"!  For more information on show dates and locations please visit www.innercityshakespeare.org/show-dates

Thank you so much for taking the time to consider our campaign!

About Us

The Inner City Shakespeare Ensemble (ICSE) was created in 2010 by Paul Heller, Katy Haber and Dr. Melanie Andrews who have engaged a talented team of professionals committed to helping ICSE reach its goals.  All of our members and mentors are volunteers who work together to provide an enriching, educational and transforming program to as many inner city and disenfranchised youth as possible. 

The organization is a nonprofit public benefit corporation in the State of California.  It has also filed charitable tax exemption requests with the IRS and when granted all contributions will be fully deductible under the law.

Mentors

Our volunteer mentor program provides young aspiring actors the opportunity to work directly with seasoned professionals who have trained with  Julliard, Bristol Old Vic, and the Royal Shakespeare Company.  

History

Our first two productions were with Washington Prep High School (ROMEO AND JULIET and A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM). In 2013 we expanded to another school, LA High School, with a production of TWELFTH NIGHT.

Each production serves at least 50 students at a time. Our goal at this time is to raise additional funding which would to allow us to offer this program to more students in more locations.

The wildly popular free theatrical productions have become real community enhancing events.  The live productions in public parks and venue have drawn eclectic crowds and turned many people on for the first time to the wonders of Shakespearean Theater!

It has been phenomenal to witness the barriers of ethnicity being erased as our Ensemble explores the 17th Century world of the Bard. 

It is the Inner City Shakespeare Ensemble's hope to provide opportunities for talented youth to develop skills that will allow them to attend acting programs and a possible future in the industry.


Our Partners & Sponsors

Los Angeles Department of Recreation and Parks, Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD), Georganne Aldrich Foundation, Harold Karpman Foundation, Los Angeles City Council 13th District, Council member Mitch O'Farrell, BAFTA Los Angeles and Save the Arts


More information about the Inner City Shakespeare Ensemble can be found on our website www.InnerCityShakespeare.org

story:
About Us

We're a small grassroots group, made up of pro-indy English Scots.  Recently in the media, there has been suggestions that English, and English Scots people living in Scotland are anti-independence, and we feel it is important to give a voice to those of us who are proud to be both English AND Scottish, and wish to see Scotland governed by the people who care most about our future: the people that live and work here, no matter where they were born!

Hold on, didn't I already give you money?

Quite possibly yes.  If so, THANK YOU!  Our first fundraiser was phenomenally successful, and since then the group has had our official launch and began the serious business of the campaign, attending functions, speaking at debates and holding events across the country.

So why Round 2?? What do we need the money for?

Quite simply, we've been TOO successful!  Our campaign leaflets are already almost all allocated ready for distribution and they're not even finished being printed (as of 20th July)!!  We've been so much in demand, with people wanting us to hold events in so many places, put simply, we're going to run out of money before September 18th.  We want to be able to continue this campaign of speaking to every English and English Scots voter we can, right up until the minute the polls close.  But to do that we need cash!!
  • Times are tough, so we're not asking you to donate more than a few quid.
  • For the price of a cup of coffee, we can buy a few badges or leaflets.
  • If you can spare a bit more, we can use it to get activists to more out-of-the-way events in the many rural areas across the country where there are English Scots that we need to get to, or buy banners for street-stalls etc.
  • Please note that if you donate over £500, firstly, wow, thank you! Secondly, we will have to submit your details to the Electoral Commission, and you must be legally resident and able to vote etc.  (for more info, please visit the Electoral Commission. We're not Lawyers for Yes, and cannot provide competent legal advice!).

OK, so I want to help. What do I get out of it?

Aside from our heartfelt appreciation and thanks, we're able to offer a few things that are a little bit more substantial.
If you look at our perks, you will see that for a donation of £5, you can receive an English Scots for YES badge! Your donation, in turn will help pay for us to buy in around 25 badges more, which will be given to our activists to distribute.
For a donation of £10, in addition to the badge you will also receive an English Scots for YES window-sticker which can be stuck on, yep, you guessed it, a window.  Well, technically speaking they'll stick to just about any transparent surface, so a car rear window screen, your house windows, the windows of your YES shop, you get the idea...

For a donation of £30, you will receive a window-sticker, and you'll get an extra badge.  Oh, and a t-shirt. An English Scots for YES t-shirt to be exact.  In our first fundraiser, these were so much in demand we actually completely sold out and have had to order in a brand new batch, and in fact there are still a couple of people still to receive theirs, so please be aware, you WILL get your t-shirt...but it may take a wee bit longer than other perks to arrive, simply because they're so popular, we've run out!  If you DO opt for this PLEASE make sure to tell us what size!

For those of you able to donate over £50, we will give you with a couple (2) of our A3 English Scots for YES posters, some leaflets, 5 badges AND the English Scots for YES t-shirt, as modelled here by Math, one of our co-founders.  It will look better on you.  Honestly.

But I just want the t-shirt/leaflet/cuddly-toy!

If you just want to get your grubby hands on our leaflets and badges, we can't blame you - and we are selling all these articles and materials online, via our site-shop.  But we're selling them at around the price it costs us to get them, so we won't actually make any money from it to increase our campaign funds (and buy in more leaflets etc. to hand out at street-stalls, attend events and so on), so please, if you're able to, give us a few quid!


Other Ways You Can Help

OK, so not everyone can afford to donate, but you can still help us:

  • Get out the word about English Scots for YES.  If you believe some newspapers, every single English Scot is voting no! We know that's not true, but there are those out there who would like to vote yes, but need more information.  Spread the word, join our Facebook group, "like" our Facebook page follow us on Twitter etc.
  • Contribute to the debate! If you're a proud English Scot, attend public debates, talk to your family, friends and neighbours - don't be afraid to get the word out.
  • Make a video about why you're voting YES.  Upload it to YouTube or Vimeo or wherever saying why you want to see an independent Scotland and we'll link to it!  It doesn't have to be long, you don't need to spend ages making it look professional - just tell the world why you want a yes vote in September!
  • Not the photogenic type? Worried the video-camera may steal your soul 25-times a second? Write us an article!  We need articles on our website for fellow English Scots voters out there who reach our website to read about why you're voting YES!
  • Lastly but most importantly, register to vote and on September 18th, help make Scotland a greener, wealthier and fairer nation!
story_txt:
About UsWe're a small grassroots group, made up of pro-indy English Scots.  Recently in the media, there has been suggestions that English, and English Scots people living in Scotland are anti-independence, and we feel it is important to give a voice to those of us who are proud to be both English AND Scottish, and wish to see Scotland governed by the people who care most about our future: the people that live and work here, no matter where they were born!Hold on, didn't I already give you money?Quite possibly yes.  If so, THANK YOU!  Our first fundraiser was phenomenally successful, and since then the group has had our official launch and began the serious business of the campaign, attending functions, speaking at debates and holding events across the country.So why Round 2?? We know that's not true, but there are those out there who would like to vote yes, but need more information.  Spread the word, join our Facebook group, "like" our Facebook page follow us on Twitter etc.
Contribute to the debate! If you're a proud English Scot, attend public debates, talk to your family, friends and neighbours - don't be afraid to get the word out.
Make a video about why you're voting YES.  Upload it to YouTube or Vimeo or wherever saying why you want to see an independent Scotland and we'll link to it!  It doesn't have to be long, you don't need to spend ages making it look professional - just tell the world why you want a yes vote in September!

story:
Who Am I?

(Video note: my father's 75th Birthday is SUNDAY, September 14th, 2014).

The answer is unfolding before me.  But part of who I am is a comforter, who seeks to use yoga to comfort my community!

I thrive by infusing faith and yoga into my life and by sharing yoga’s tremendous ability to empower and comfort practitioners. 

There is a beneficial yoga practice for virtually each person at every stage of life.  

After a 15+ year, at-home practice, I took the leap and attended Kripalu Center's 200-hour Yoga Teacher Training in in 2012.  My sister finished her 200-Hour YTT at Kripalu in 2013, and then, we opened a tiny yoga studio in our hometown of Johnsonburg, Pennsylvania.  

The Shakti Initiation 500hr Women’s Only Yoga Leadership Certification (check out the link below!!), is so important to me at this time not only because of the quality, nature, and focus of the program, but also because of this question I ask myself almost every day: if not now, when?  

Although 500-hour certifications can be obtained state-side, the LEADERSHIP focus and quality of this amazing Certification with two of Yoga's most gifted instructors: Jovinna Chin and Grace Jull, is unparalleled; the location selected by these talented teachers due to its specific qualities (Bali 2015) is significant, as well. 

Additionally, this 500-Hour Leadership Certification, unlike other programs, encourages participants to focus and tailor the learning process towards their passions, which enables me to collaborate with experts as I continuing working on an 'outside-the-box' program, designed to empower our children and everyone who wants to transform their lives. 

The first 200-Hour portion of this intensive program has already started. It is with pleasure and awe that I report the extent of what I have learned in four short weeks. As I matriculate through the first portion of this program (during the next three months), I will learn even more as I diligently work on my assignments.  Already, my teaching-both on and off the mat-has been improved and enriched.

Upon completion of this Certification, I will be donating time to share TIE Yoga with victims of physical, sexual, and emotional abuse and will continue seeking partnerships with parents, schools and county agencies to share the knowledge and benefits of TIE Yoga in order to encourage and empower our youth and help transform lives.

Like so many others communities, the magnitude of challenges from drug abuse my community faces seems to be growing; taking its toll on everything from our individuals, families, friendships, schools, law enforcement agencies, judicial systems, and medical systems to our ability to effectively fill job positions.   

Unfortunately, I have experienced the toll drug abuse has on the friends and family members of the user. These experiences have heightened my awareness and increased my desire to PREVENT our young people from making choices that might lead to addiction. 

It is time to THINK OUTSIDE OF THE BOX and try something different.  Most any internet search on 'yoga and youth' will yield a plethora of results regarding successful Yoga-based programs with their encouraging results. 

I believe wholeheartedly in the transformative power of yoga...I am a living testament of yoga's ability to improve self-esteem, self-worth, self-awareness, and to increase our ability to pause and think before making what could be life-changing decisions.

By expanding my yoga practice, deepening my knowledge, and developing and implementing the TIE Yoga Program, I know I can make a difference in my community.  And it is my prayer that the effectiveness of TIE Yoga is a jumping point that produces positive transformation, not only in Elk County, but beyond!

I have a story and a calling...I know TIE Yoga can equip and empower my community and help its members find strength and peace in an unsettling world. This is comfort....and TIE Yoga is my Gift.  

"The meaning of life is to find your gift. 

The purpose of life is to give it away."

-Pablo Picasso

What I ASK and What you Receive:

My funding requirement is $7333.  

  • Tuition: $4800
  • Air Fare/Travel: $1887
  • Supplies: $333
  • Travel Insurance: $258
  • Tourist Visa: $55
In exchange for your donation (any size is greatly appreciated!) you will receive, not only the satisfaction of knowing you are supporting a worthwhile cause, but also, the following:
PICK YOUR PERK:
  • Every contribution: Heartfelt appreciation and much Metta!
  • $5: Hand written thank you note
  • $10: Hand written thank you note
  • $15: Hand written thank you n ote
  • $20:  Thirty-minute Yoga session ($10 savings)*
  • $30: Forty-five minute Yoga session ($15 savings)*
  • $40: Two thirty-minute Yoga sessions!!!* ($20 savings)#
  • $50: A sixty-minute Yoga session (a $10 savings).*
*Sessions held at LIving Brooks Yoga and Wellness, LLC's Elk County, Pa studio or via an alternative, mutually acceptable location or delivery method.
With your generous support, earning my 500hr Yoga Leadership Certification will enable me to better serve and comfort my community.
My Challenges:
Although the nature of the program is intense, I am certain of my determination to succeed and passionate about sharing TIE Yoga with others.  The challenge I face undertaking this Certification is purely financial in nature.

Other Ways You Can Help

Being under-employed for more than three years, I understand that some people cannot contribute financially, but that doesn't mean YOU can't help:

  • First and foremost: Keep me and this venture in your prayers!
  • Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to quickly spread the word!

And that's all there is to it!!!  Thank YOU so much for your support!!!

"But Blessed are those who trust in The Lord and have made The Lord their hope and confidence.  They are like trees planted along a riverbank, with roots that reach deep into the water.  Such trees are not bothered by the heat or worried by long months of drought.  Their leaves stay green, and they never stop producing fruit." (Jeremiah 17:7-8; The Wayfinding Bible).

Information about the 500-Hour Yoga Certification: www.Shakti-Initiation.com

story:
Actual Amounts Raised So Far

Good news ! Our offline contributions for this campaign to date, total $5200 - an additional 34.6% of our goal - which isn't included in the progress total you see above. 

That means our campaign total is currently at $9273 !

61.82 % of goal, as of 10/1/2014 at 3:50pm

What if I missed the Oct 1st @ midnight deadline ?

You can still make a tax deductible donation to Secret Knowledge, even after the IndieGoGo campaign deadline. We're a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt nonprofit organization; public support is how we fund our innovative programs throughout the year. Some of our perks will continue to be offered as donation thank you gifts, check our website, secretknowledge.org for details or to give online after the IndieGoGo campaign ends.

You can mail a donation check to: 

SECRET KNOWLEDGE 1509 NE 10th Ave #209 Portland, Oregon 97232

Perks Ahoy ! Here's how we'll thank you.

Tax Deductions and Oregon Cultural Tax Credit 

Secret Knowledge is a 501(c)(3) tax exempt non-profit. Your contribution is deductible, by law. You can make a donation of any amount to support this campaign, or select from one of the perks packages we've cooked up for you. 

If you pay taxes in the State of Oregon there are additional tax incentives for supporting Secret Knowledge. Your donation to Secret Knowledge is the first step to claiming Oregon's Cultural Tax Credit. We'll post more about that in the updates section. 

Thank You Party Invitation

Secret Knowledge will host an invitation-only party for people who supported this kick-off campaign. If you're not in Portland, Oregon you can still get in on the fun. We will set up a live-video stream of the party action. Enjoy surprise guests from the music and arts scene on site or from the comfort of your own home. It will be a fun time. 

Limited Edition Secret Knowledge Stickers

Not available in stores. These fine Secret Knowledge stickers are large enough to cover all but the largest logos. Instantly turn corporate-branded conference schwag into Secret Knowledge branded treasured keepsakes ! Extol motorists to STOP Secret Knowledge (or better yet, tell 'em to YEILD Secret Knowledge). Self-adhesive, context sensitive, and non-habit forming. Stick it on your notebook and people will wonder what it is that you know !

Thank You Music Mix - Listen to the Preview Track !

Secret Knowledge is assembling a mix of music from local artists. We'll send you a link or mail you a physical CD of this music mix as our way of thanking you for supporting this campaign. 

Pssst... Wanna hear a track that we're including in the thank you mix ? Ok. Check out "Cars are Boxes" by David Waingarten. It's from his soon-to-be-released album The Truth is... I Don't Know.  

You're hearing it here first, before the album is released ! The entire album will be included in our music grab bag. 

Secret Knowledge workshops DVD

Learn secret knowledge in the comfort of your living room with this DVD which features two Secret Knowledge workshops:
  • Secret Knowledge of Poster Design - skills you need to be seen
  • Secret Knowledge of Clear & Clever Marketing - find those magic words, in a world where there are no magic words

Music from the Totally Worth It - Secret Knowledge MUSIC GRAB BAG

Great Portland musicians have donated CDs, Download Codes, LPs (with download codes), and even Cassette Tapes (with download codes). We'll send you some really good music. 

The list of artists in the GRAB BAG keeps growing, so far we've got: 

  • Blue Cranes
  • Mike Coykendall
  • David Waingarten
  • Rachel Taylor Brown
  • Small Souls
  • The Old Joe Clarks
  • Blue Skies for Black Hearts
  • Anna Fritz the cellist/folksinger from our kickoff video.
  • Huck Notari
  • Swansea with Kyleen King, the guitarist/singer from our kickoff video
  • Wester Daywick
  • Montgomery Word
  • Y La Bamba
  • WHAKI
  • Mr.Noah's Opus with me, Noah Kleiman, from the kickoff video
  • The Perfect Band
  • Ezza Rose
  • Sean Flinn and The Royal We
  • Catherine Feeny  

Other cool stuff

Boomerangs, fresh cookies, tea with a working artist, and in-home music performances. Whether you want to get RAWKED, learn the secrets of boomerangs, connect with a real working artist, or have a private concert at your house - Secret Knowledge has you covered. 

All knowledge is secret, until you share it. 

I started Secret Knowledge to help Portland's working class artists & musicians gain the business, technical, and marketing skills they need to succeed; and to offer arts-engagement events for people who want culture to involve them. 

It's a two-pronged approach:

  • Help artists succeed. Give them the skills they need to make it here. 
  • Help creative audiences be more involved in culture. Give them access to real artistic insight & creative mentorship.

We're already rolling on this. 

Secret Knowledge started offering workshops for working class artists in February 2014. So far this year we've offered 12 workshops. With your support we'll be able to expand our workshops, produce videos, and start bringing concerts and arts events to creative audiences in 2015.

The power of regular folks, like you and me. 

The funds we raise through this Indiegogo campaign will allow Secret Knowledge to pay for staff, promote events, and to start producing instructional videos of our workshops - that means working artists in other places will start to benefit from the educational programing we're developing in Portland. 

We have a plan, and it involves you. 

Secret Knowledge has a detailed business plan, which you can download here. 

The plan is to start small, build our brand, and grow our audience. Then launch an annual Secret Knowledge conference. Turns out that's a sustainable model for the services we're providing. The best part is, we're gonna help a lot of people along the way. 

It all starts with this campaign. With your contribution to our kick-off. 

Invite your friends and family to join you in supporting Secret Knowledge. You could easily double or triple the impact of your contribution by doing this.

Wester Daywick


Montgomery Word


Y La Bamba


WHAKI


Mr.Noah's Opus with me, Noah Kleiman, from the kickoff video

The Perfect Band
Ezza Rose
Sean Flinn and The Royal We

Catherine Feeny  


Other cool stuff
Boomerangs, fresh cookies, tea with a working artist, and in-home music performances. Whether you want to get RAWKED, learn the secrets of boomerangs, connect with a real working artist, or have a private concert at your house - Secret Knowledge has you covered. 
  
All knowledge is secret, until you share it. 
I started Secret Knowledge to help Portland's working class artists & musicians gain the business, technical, and marketing skills they need to succeed; and to offer arts-engagement events for people who want culture to involve them. 
It's a two-pronged approach:

Help artists succeed. Give them the skills they need to make it here. 
Help creative audiences be more involved in culture. Give them access to real artistic insight & creative mentorship.

We're already rolling on this. 
Secret Knowledge started offering workshops for working class artists in February 2014. So far this year we've offered 12 workshops. With your support we'll be able to expand our workshops, produce videos, and start bringing concerts and arts events to creative audiences in 2015.
The power of regular folks, like you and me. 
The funds we raise through this Indiegogo campaign will allow Secret Knowledge to pay for staff, promote events, and to start producing instructional videos of our workshops - that means working artists in other places will start to benefit from the educational programing we're developing in Portland. 
We have a plan, and it involves you. 


Secret Knowledge has a detailed business plan, which you can download here. 
The plan is to start small, build our brand, and grow our audience. Then launch an annual Secret Knowledge conference. Turns out that's a sustainable model for the services we're providing. The best part is, we're gonna help a lot of people along the way. 
It all starts with this campaign. With your contribution to our kick-off. 
Invite your friends and family to join you in supporting Secret Knowledge. You could easily double or triple the impact of your contribution by doing this.

story:
The School of Choice (l'Ecole de Choix) is a unique elementary school located in Mirebalais, Haiti offering high quality curriculum, instruction in 3 languages, and leadership development to children living in extreme conditions of poverty. Choix's wholistic approach includes classroom instruction in several subjects, textbooks and technology, basic medical care, a nutrition program, a competitive athletics program, and access to music and art materials.  

The aim of the school is not simply to offer adequate educational opportunities, but also to provide these children with the opportunities they DESERVE to learn, grow and play.  The mission of the school is to provide an environment of respect and encouragement in which to develop Haiti's future leaders.

Nutrition plays a key role in the success of our students.  

Our students live in conditions of extreme poverty, are plagued by hunger, and endure food insecurity on a daily basis.  The lunch that they receive at Choix will most likely be the only meal they will have that day.  If students no longer are suffering from hunger, they are better able to focus on learning and also will have fewer absences from school!
"Our students are so hungry.  Even with our lunch they are still hungry..." ~ Ione Cassens, Director of Operations, l'Ecole de Choix
Better nutrition = Better health = Better well-being


With your $5, the School of Choice 

can feed 5 students

Your contribution of $5 can provide the following for 5 students:

  • A whole grain breakfast bar with added vitamins and nutrients
  • A nutritious lunch - often the only meal these students will receive
  • Access to fresh water for students and their families
  • Education about nutrition - eating right, food safety, proper sanitation
Every dollar you contribute will go directly the nutrition program at the School of Choice.  Our goal for this campaign is to support our meal program for 1/3 of our school year.

How to join us:

 Contribute $5 for 5 meals, then share, asking 5 friends to do the same!

IT ADDS UP:  Your total of $30 (you + 5 friends) will support meals for a class of students!!

Spread the word

Share our message with your friends and loved ones...supporting the health and well-being of a child has never been easier.

Twitter

I just gave #5for5 - I gave $5 to provide 5 meals for a student in Haiti. 5 friends make it a class at indiegogo:  http://igg.me/at/choix   

More delish than a $5 burger? Giving a student in Haiti 5 healthy lunches. Help make it a class at indiegogo: http://igg.me/at/choix #5for5

I just fed 5 students in Haiti while sipping my morning jo. Make it a class at indiegogo:  http://igg.me/at/choix #5for5 #SoChoix

Facebook

I just gave $5 to provide 5 meals for a student in Haiti.  If I can get 5 friends to do the same, we'll have supported a whole class of students.  Will you join me? [tag 5 friends here!]  Join me at Indiegogo,  http://igg.me/at/choix #5for5 #SoChoix

What's more delicious than a $5 burger? Feeding 5 students in Haiti!  If I can get 5 friends to do the same, we'll have supported a whole class of students.  Will you join me? [tag 5 friends here!]  Join me at Indiegogo,  http://igg.me/at/choix #5for5 #SoChoix

I just fed 5 students in Haiti while sipping my morning cup, will you do the same? If I can get 5 friends to do the same, we'll have supported a whole class of students.  Will you join me? [tag 5 friends here!]  Join me at Indiegogo,  http://igg.me/at/choix #5for5 #SoChoix

How can we thank you enough? 

Your $5 contribution brings you lots of good karma and the appreciation of a school full of children

Your $50 contribution brings you lots of good karma, the appreciation of a school full of children AND a digital copy of a piece of student art work

Your $100 contribution brings you lots of good karma, the appreciation of a school full of children, a digital copy of a piece of student art work AND a personalized note of thanks 

Your $250 contribution brings you lots of good Karma, the appreciation of a school full of children, a digital copy of a piece of student art work, a personalized note of thanks AND a Choix t-shirt!! 


Support the School of Choice, a unique Haitian elementary school offering quality education to children living in extreme poverty. For

more information, please go to www.ecoledechoix.org.

L'Ecole de Choix is a program of the School of Choice Organization, a 501c3 non-profit based in Chicago, IL, FEIN 45-4277736. L'Ecole de Choix is funded solely by private contributions.

story:
Intro

Since 1895, the World Student Christian Federation has been forming young people and students for leadership all around the world through movements known by many names, including Student Christian Movements (SCM).

This vital work has been so important to the lives of so many young people who have gone on to be the leaders that formed ecumenical movements such as the WCC (World Council of Churches), progressive leaders working for justice in their own denominations, and work in many organizations and people's movements in society at large.

This prophetic legacy of faith and justice has touched so many lives, including mine. For me, the SCM has been so important and has strengthened both my activism and my Christian identity. Global and cross-cultural experiences have been absolutely foundational to strengthening my analysis and skills for solidarity work.

What We Need

Unfortunately, funding has become quite difficult for WSCF in recent years. Many of the denominations and organizations that offered block grants in the past have moved towards project-based funding and are experiencing many of their own financial challenges.

WSCF is working hard to adapt to this changing situation, but in order to have the meetings and develop the processes to adapt to a more sustainable financial arrangement, we need some immediate funding. We are reaching out to partner organizations around the world but also to our own networks of friends, family, and allies for faith and justice.

Be One, Give One

This is the name of a campaign that was recently launched to encourage people around the world, particularly students and young senior friends, to demonstrate what WSCF means to them by contributing whatever amount they are able - even if it is just the smallest denomination of their currency - one peso, one rupee, one euro, one dollar.

This crowd-funding campaign is a mechanism to support that in North America - please give whatever you are able. We recognize that different people have different financial situations and that money is unequally distributed so please give what you can - one hour's wage from your job, one coffee you might have bought, even the amount of one iTunes purchase, or if you can't give anything, just your words of solidarity and prayers/good energy help too. Please share words and messages of solidarity on the SCM Canada Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/scmcanada)

If you are able to contribute a larger amount of money and would like a charitable donation tax receipt, please contribute (in Canada) to WSCF-Canada at:  P.O. Box 22010, The Colonnade P.O., 131 Bloor St. W. Toronto, ON, M5S 3L7 (*please put "Be One Give One" in the memo line)

Or in the USA: http://www.wscfusatrustees.org/wscf_current/

From Hope to Peace

My hope is that we might raise $1000 in this campaign in the first week of Advent, between the Sundays of Hope (November 30) and Peace (December 7). Hope and Peace are two very key themes in the life of WSCF. Solidarity offers hope to those marginalized and oppressed, building a more peaceful and just world for all.

Thank you

I will write a personal thank you note to everyone that contributes, in whatever amount!

Your support means SO much to me and I know will mean so much to those future generations who are still in high school or just starting university. Those students who, like I was, yearning for a community like SCM/WSCF so they wouldn't feel so alone, so their nascent sense that faith and justice are one can be nourished.

story:
WHO ARE WE AND WHAT WE ARE DOING

We are raising money to hold a two week bootcamp over the holidays for 25 female high school graduates (matric) to learn basic Javascript programming skills, gain exposure to the IT industry and mentors working in the field. They will use these skills to tackle local challenges and build a real site or app for a simulated client and pitch their solution.

Girls who show the most promise will be invited to join codeX, a full-time apprenticeship program designed to train agile developers for South Africa and the continent. In the program, they will learn to build real sites and apps for real clients.

The program shows girls that IT is for women, that coding is fun, that it can be used for business and social impact and that it can be a great career path.

This Indiegogo campaign is a joint effort between codeX, Africa's developer apprenticehip program,  and Innovate South Africa, a NGO that provides a platform to ignite creative thinking, to nurture invention and encourage entrepreneurship among young people. Innovate SA's program, Code4CT, trains girls to code. We are joining forces because we need more girls in tech!

WHAT WE NEED RIGHT NOW

We are trying to raise $7500 or R75000 to run a two-week bootcamp program for 25 girls in January 2015. It covers our costs for trainers, equipment, transport costs for the girls, and fees of this campaign. 

FOR THE FUTURE

It doesn’t stop there…the next step is to raise funds for the girls who make it through and get accepted to codex. All funds raised above that will go scholarships for the top girls in the program to the full year-long codeX program in 2015 (which costs $10,000 per coder).



THE IMPACT 

Innovate South African ran the Code4CT program earlier this year with 24 girls.  Here's what they said about the program:



By joining forces, Innovate South Africa's Code 4 CT program and CodeX are:

- Creating a pipeline to develop young female talent in the tech industry in South Africa and across the continent.

- Offering young women from disadvantaged backgrounds an opportunity to learn practical skills that are easily transferable to a job.

- Fostering a network of young women who will be leaders in tech in Africa.

- Supporting educational and employment opportunities in a country faced with more than 20% unemployment for young people.

story: My name is Liam Connors, I am 18 and a graduate of Rothesay High School in Rothesay, NB. I graduated in June, 2014 with an average of 85%. I took the past year off to work and save for school as well as to find out what I wanted to do for post-secondary education and ultimately my career path. I've always liked the idea of helping people and making a difference, I started looking into social work, particularly a career as a parole officer as I have a big interest in law. I thought it was the best combination of social and law work, something that I could make a difference doing. I've been accepted into UNBSJ for the fall 2015 term and I've applied for scholarships and asked many local businesses if they offer any. I have yet to hear back from some, so I am turning to the internet, to you. I need $30,000 for my entire 4 year degree. That doesn't cover living expenses or the numerous textbooks or even the full amount of tuition costs but it is the rough amount that I will have to pay in order to get the education I need for the job I want. (There's a link to the tuition costs at the bottom) Thank you so much for checking out my campaign, if you choose to donate please remember no donation is too small. Link:http://www.unb.ca/moneymatters/tuitionandfees/i...

story:
You guys, we did it! With your help, and the generous support of the Ella Lyman Cabot Trust, we ran a pilot program of Campesino School from May to August 2014 with nine young people and a great team of sustainable agriculture technicians, students with humanities degrees from the city, and the people of the community of Los Naranjos! For four three-week sessions, these kids, most of whom had never left the mountains where they were born, crossed the country to the Agro-Ecological Center in Los Naranjos. During the sessions, they studied the theory and practice of sustainable agriculture in the mornings, took popular-education style  classes in the afternoons about history, social-political studies, and music, and spent the weekends visiting other sustainable agriculture centers and experiences here in El Salvador.


Campesino School is an idea that was born out of the frustration over the lack of opportunities that Salvadoran young people face today. In rural areas like Morazán, where our students live, today’s teenagers and young adults have anywhere between a third and ninth grade education. Some have been able to access scholarships to complete high school or even university, with great personal, familial, and communal sacrifice. When they graduate, however, the few job opportunities that exist keep them in the cities, far from their communities. It means that young people are leaving rural Morazán en masse in search of jobs or any kind of future, and many communities are losing their up-and-coming generation. It also means that the farming practices that their families have used for generations to grow corn and beans are being lost, not only because of the influence of transnational agricultural corporations like Monsanto who came in after the war to introduce their products to the impoverished repopulated communities, but also because nobody can stick around to learn them. The land is exhausted, the water table is low, the gangs are circling, and the promise of $7 an hour washing dishes on the night shift in New Jersey is appealing.


Last year, we were able to host the pilot year of Campesino School, described above, and we are ready to tweak the program to make it better and more effective. The most important change we need to make is to move the program out to Morazán. The long distance that the students had to travel to get to FUNDAHMER’s Agro-Ecological Center in Los Naranjos had a couple detrimental effects on the program. First, the distance made it difficult for us to help the students implement the techniques they learned at Campesino School back in Morazán because they were away from home for so long during the growing season. Second, for young women who were interested in participating in the School, the distance was prohibitive because their parents didn’t want them traveling so far. Finally, the goals of the Agro-Ecological Center and the kind of coastal climate, soil, and environmental challenges that they face are very different from the kind of family-oriented subsistence agriculture that the students do in Morazán. We want to move Campesino School out to Morazán and give the courses in monthly workshop format so that students can implement the techniques at home during the course, so that more women can participate, and so that what they learn at School applies directly to the climate, soil, and environmental challenges of their municipality.


Our other goal is to use a bit of land available to us out in Morazán to build a demonstration parcel. For those of you who know the area, it’s right below the Padre Octavio Ortiz chapel in Agua Blanca, by the bus stop. It’s a central location in the region where FUNDAHMER does its work in the communities, and by having Campesino School there and by maintaining the land as a demonstration parcel using sustainable agriculture techniques, we hope to show-not-tell the positive effects of a long-term commitment to sustainable agriculture practices, both in terms of environmental recuperation and agricultural productivity. We eventually want it to be self-sustainable, producing enough marketable specialty crops (probably starting with cacao) to maintain a small staff and materials, but for now, we will need to rely largely on personal donations, collaboration with Salvadoran institutions, and international development funding.


We are working on long-term financial support, but for now, we need to get started, and we need your help, once again. We want to invite students back to School in March 2016, and we’ve got a lot to do before then. This fundraising campaign will help support some goals we have for the second half of 2015, including:

  • Planting a bit of corn before the growing season is over, to start recuperating the soil and implementing anti-drought techniques
  • Planting ancestral trees and plants native to the region like cacao (for chocolate, of course), mezcal (the fibers traditionally used to make hammocks and sacks), and ojushte (a tree whose seed can be made into tortilla if the corn crop fails!)
  • Supplementing the salary of Agustín Luna, an agricultural promoter who has worked with FUNDAHMER for years and whose personal agriculture initiatives are some of the best examples of creative and sustainable farming in the region. He’s going to be a point person on our team, and we need to start meeting with him to plan the curriculum and ready the land.
  • Wages for day-laborers, mostly students from last year and young people who are interested in participating next year, to help us plant, put up fences, possibly build a small storage space, and begin to care for and visit the land on a daily basis.
  • Transportation to and from Morazán to meet as a team and work on curriculum, methodology, and educational goals. The Campesino School team is going to be a mix of paid staff and volunteers, mostly from San Salvador and Morazán, and we need to start meeting to get to know each other better and getting organized. We hope that the team will include Agustín full time, two other part-time promoters from Morazán, two scholarship students from the area who are studying Agricultural Engineering at the National University in San Miguel, Economics students from the UCA in San Salvador who can help us make sure our plans make economic sense for our goal of being self sustainable, students from last year who will be assistant teachers, guest technicians who will help with particular techniques like beekeeping or fruit tree care, and other young professionals from the city who will contribute extracurricular workshops around topics like music, history, politics, and culture throughout the course. We need to get these folks out there and talking to each other!


Thank you in advance, dear reader, for taking some time to get to know our project! Any little bit you can contribute really does help, and even sharing this campaign with your family and friends goes a long way. We are excited to get to work, and so appreciate your energy and accompaniment on this journey! Please feel free to direct any questions to me at soy.laurel@gmail.com, and we look forward to keeping you all informed!
