It means that young people are leaving rural Morazán en masse in search of jobs or any kind of future, and many communities are losing their up-and-coming generation. It also means that the farming practices that their families have used for generations to grow corn and beans are being lost, not only because of the influence of transnational agricultural corporations like Monsanto who came in after the war to introduce their products to the impoverished repopulated communities, but also because nobody can stick around to learn them. The land is exhausted, the water table is low, the gangs are circling, and the promise of $7 an hour washing dishes on the night shift in New Jersey is appealing.Last year, we were able to host the pilot year of Campesino School, described above, and we are ready to tweak the program to make it better and more effective. The most important change we need to make is to move the program out to Morazán. The long distance that the students had to travel to get to FUNDAHMER’s Agro-Ecological Center in Los Naranjos had a couple detrimental effects on the program. First, the distance made it difficult for us to help the students implement the techniques they learned at Campesino School back in Morazán because they were away from home for so long during the growing season. Second, for young women who were interested in participating in the School, the distance was prohibitive because their parents didn’t want them traveling so far. Finally, the goals of the Agro-Ecological Center and the kind of coastal climate, soil, and environmental challenges that they face are very different from the kind of family-oriented subsistence agriculture that the students do in Morazán. We want to move Campesino School out to Morazán and give the courses in monthly workshop format so that students can implement the techniques at home during the course, so that more women can participate, and so that what they learn at School applies directly to the climate, soil, and environmental challenges of their municipality.Our other goal is to use a bit of land available to us out in Morazán to build a demonstration parcel. For those of you who know the area, it’s right below the Padre Octavio Ortiz chapel in Agua Blanca, by the bus stop. It’s a central location in the region where FUNDAHMER does its work in the communities, and by having Campesino School there and by maintaining the land as a demonstration parcel using sustainable agriculture techniques, we hope to show-not-tell the positive effects of a long-term commitment to sustainable agriculture practices, both in terms of environmental recuperation and agricultural productivity. We eventually want it to be self-sustainable, producing enough marketable specialty crops (probably starting with cacao) to maintain a small staff and materials, but for now, we will need to rely largely on personal donations, collaboration with Salvadoran institutions, and international development funding.We are working on long-term financial support, but for now, we need to get started, and we need your help, once again. We want to invite students back to School in March 2016, and we’ve got a lot to do before then. This fundraising campaign will help support some goals we have for the second half of 2015, including:

Planting a bit of corn before the growing season is over, to start recuperating the soil and implementing anti-drought techniques


Planting ancestral trees and plants native to the region like cacao (for chocolate, of course), mezcal (the fibers traditionally used to make hammocks and sacks), and ojushte (a tree whose seed can be made into tortilla if the corn crop fails!)


Supplementing the salary of Agustín Luna, an agricultural promoter who has worked with FUNDAHMER for years and whose personal agriculture initiatives are some of the best examples of creative and sustainable farming in the region. He’s going to be a point person on our team, and we need to start meeting with him to plan the curriculum and ready the land.


Wages for day-laborers, mostly students from last year and young people who are interested in participating next year, to help us plant, put up fences, possibly build a small storage space, and begin to care for and visit the land on a daily basis.


Transportation to and from Morazán to meet as a team and work on curriculum, methodology, and educational goals. The Campesino School team is going to be a mix of paid staff and volunteers, mostly from San Salvador and Morazán, and we need to start meeting to get to know each other better and getting organized. We hope that the team will include Agustín full time, two other part-time promoters from Morazán, two scholarship students from the area who are studying Agricultural Engineering at the National University in San Miguel, Economics students from the UCA in San Salvador who can help us make sure our plans make economic sense for our goal of being self sustainable, students from last year who will be assistant teachers, guest technicians who will help with particular techniques like beekeeping or fruit tree care, and other young professionals from the city who will contribute extracurricular workshops around topics like music, history, politics, and culture throughout the course. We need to get these folks out there and talking to each other!

Thank you in advance, dear reader, for taking some time to get to know our project! Any little bit you can contribute really does help, and even sharing this campaign with your family and friends goes a long way. We are excited to get to work, and so appreciate your energy and accompaniment on this journey! Please feel free to direct any questions to me at soy.laurel@gmail.com, and we look forward to keeping you all informed!

story:
Last year, we found the perfect school for our boys, St. Teresa's. We filled out the paperwork and found we qualified for two scholarships: Grace and one from the church since I am also Catholic. This made our tuition affordable and the boys are academically challenged, have small sizes, and have a lot of friends.

Two weeks ago, we got a letter from our church stating that they would no longer be able to give scholarships to students, regardless of economic status. This means that our tuition is doubling to over $500 this coming school year for both our boys to attend. We also must provide uniforms and other fees associated with sports, since our boys enjoy playing. In short, this is a very expensive endeavor.

Since the birth of Elizabeth, I have only been able to work the weekends since going back to work, and shorter shifts while breastfeeding. This is because my husband works long hours at his job (Navy pharmacy tech). I have been making a little money on the side coaching, but combined, it will not cover everything. I have already written the check to re-register them there, which depletes my savings that I was going to use for my own fitness certification.

I don't expect anyone but our family and friends to donate. People keep asking what they can do and how they can help, and well, this is it. Education for my children is the upmost of importance to me - even more so than my own. I would do anything in the world for my kids, and if you hear of a job in Albany/Leesburg/SWGA that's worth having 2-4 kids in daycare services (depending on the time of year), please email me at tara@taraglenn.com. Thanks so much for hearing us out.

Thanks so much for hearing us out.

story:
Imagine being air dropped in the middle of a war zone with only a radio in hand. What would you shout into the radio? HELLLLLLLP!?!?! How would you answer, "What's your 20?"

This is what our returning veterans face as they enter into a civilian work zone that they have never experienced. 

Career Gear Houston is dedicated to helping veterans achieve success as they make their transition from military to civilian employment.  Over the past 10 years we have served over 10,000 men as they strive to be the fathers and providers their families need. Mission Possible is a veterans transitional series that covers aspects key to sustainable employment.

It is our turn to serve our veterans as they shift from defending our freedoms and everyday way of life, into civilian employment and the way of life they have defended.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to deliver Mission Possible to 350 deserving veterans this year.

  • The average cost per veterans to attend a Mission Possible Series is $225
  • Those funds cover the cost of materials, lunch, services to clients such as a professional head shot, a new suit to interview in complete with shoes, dress shirt and tie, and veteran-transitioned facilitator
  • Each donor will receive the satisfaction of serving someone who would never asked to be served. This is a priceless gift that can't be put into words.
  • Every donor will receive a signed Thank you picture from one of our 2015 series, which begin on January 16, 2015.
  • Depending on your donation level you may also receive a Mission Possible T-Shirt and Invitation to our Annual Gala in September 2015.

The Impact

Helping our local veterans transition into civilian employment is ultimately life saving as the suicide and homeless statistics of our veterans is heart retching. 

  • Everyday, 22 veterans take their own lives, 1 every 65 minutes.
  • Veterans make up the largest % of the homeless population right here on our Houston streets. 
  • In 2014 (Sept-Dec), Mission Possible served 76 veterans of which 53 are currently employed and 16 are furthering their education.

Risks & Challenges

The sooner the veterans can make the transition with all the proper tools, the less risk they face of becoming a statistic. Yet, not every veteran we serve will make the transition. Some will go through a couple jobs before landing in their career. Some will have to deal with PTSD issues before they are truly ready to make this transition. Career Gear Houston will stand beside those veterans and see them through, with your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share with your sphere of influence, follow and join us on socail media.
  • Donate your time and talent to Career Gear Houston
  • Encourage your compnay to begin best hiring practices for our veterans as they transition.

And that's all there is to it.


CAREER GEAR IS A MULTIDIMENSIONAL NONPROFIT THAT HAS PROVIDED LOW-COST, HIGH IMPACT SOLUTIONS TO OVER 10,000 MEN-IN-NEED SINCE 2004.

story: The money raised here will be used to help the senior class of NMSA give a final thank you gift to those who made it possible to dream. We want to thank the faculty and staff for their dedication and love they give each and everyday.

story:
The comic book follows two kids, Tanya and Kevin, as each tries to create a business. It presents typical obstacles faced by startup founders in a easy-to-understand, engaging, and practical way. We consulted with economists, child psychologists, and successful entrepreneurs to make sure our comic book is accessible to kids, teaches sound principles, and is based on the real issues faced by startup founders.

Tanya dreams of going to Video Game Camp (to create some amazing games), but needs money for it. She is great with web design and that gives her an idea. But how will she get people to pay for her skilled work?

Kevin wants to buy the latest gaming console, but also needs the money for it. He's very good at noticing problems around him that he can solve. So he comes up with one business idea after another. Which one will he finally make into a strong, scalable business? You'll have to read My First Startup to find out.

Kids - they're awesome! Today's kids are very tech savvy and full of ideas that can change the world. And the world is changing - but their education is not catching up. Let's turn kids' dreams into reality and build their own path towards a successful future with a comic book that teaches them about creating their first startup.

The creators are Russell, Andrey, and David. We are serial entrepreneurs ourselves, so the biggest motivation for creating My First Startup was to give today's kids what we wish we had growing up. We've been creating custom comic books as the founders of Your Comic Story - so we know how good comic books are at teaching without being overwhelming or patronizing. We know how exciting each kid gets when opening a comic book and know that entrepreneurial education could be fun.


We really believe in "My First Startup". From our research, we found nothing quite like this. There are various books, articles, and TV shows - but nothing that a kid can pick up and have fun learning on their own. We received enthusiastic feedback from a number of educational, parent, and entrepreneurial organizations. We consulted with experts in economics, child psychology, and entrepreneurship. But the ultimate judge is YOU. We hope you love My First Startup and get one for every kid you know.
To help kids get the most out of "My First Startup" and be more prepared for starting a business, we are offering some exciting perks:

You get the eBook version of My First Startup (PDF/EPUB/MOBI/Etc.)

You get one of the first edition print versions of My First Startup.

Get a custom superhero poster plus a first edition print copy of My First Startup.

Get 30 print copies of My First Startup. Inspire your students to innovation!

story:
"In the opinion of the Government of the United States the coming of Chinese laborers to this country endangers the good order of certain localities... it shall not be lawful for any Chinese laborer to come..."

These words were approved at the 47th United States Congress in 1882 as part of the Chinese Exclusion Act.

Short Summary

The Chinese Exclusion Act was a federal law that prevented entry of Chinese to the U.S. and excluded legal Chinese immigrants from obtaining U.S. citizenship. Chinese labor was considered a threat to the labor opportunities of American citizens. The act was in effect from 1882 to 1943 -- more than 60 years.

The Chinese Exclusion Act enshrined injustice into our legal code – it stopped the Chinese, and the Chinese alone, from immigrating, from ever becoming naturalized citizens and ever having the right to vote.

Early Chinese immigrants who arrived before the Act faced harsh racism in America, and in California. Eleven years prior, in Los Angeles, practically every building in Chinatown was ransacked and almost every resident was attacked or robbed. A total of 18 Chinese immigrants were tortured and then hanged by a mob of 500, making the event the largest mass lynching in American history.

In 2012, a bipartisan resolution that formally expressed the regret of the House of Representatives for the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 and other legislation that discriminated against people of Chinese origin in the United States was passed. 

Congresswoman Judy Chu, author of the bill, said, “Today the House made history when both chambers of Congress officially and formally acknowledged the ugly and un-American nature of laws that targeted Chinese immigrants. “

Rose Hills Memorial Park and the Chinese American Museum are collaborating to establish “A Place of Inclusion” monument and produce educational curriculum for grade schools to remember California’s forgotten pioneers from China.

The inspiration for the monument’s design was selected from submissions received from students of Cal Poly Pomona’s School of Environmental design.

The curriculum component is a supplement to fourth grade history books used in California schools. It will explain the role and contributions of Chinese immigrants to the Unites States, as well as the passage and subsequent repeal of the Chinese Exclusion Act.

What We Need & What You Get

“Tell me and I’ll forget; show me and I may remember; involve me and I’ll understand.” —Chinese Proverb

不闻不若闻之，闻之不若见之，见之不若知之，知之不若行之；学至于行之而止矣 

Our goal for this funding project is to advance the project from conceptual art to architectural drafting of the monument. The land for the project has been donated by the world’s largest memorial park, Rose Hills, and this campaign will be managed by the Chinese American Museum of Los Angeles. 

We anticipate needing $10k to hire an architect to do construction documents and other architectural renderings needed to make the monument a reality.

If we raise more funds than we need, the overage may be used for the next phase: the actual construction of the monument itself.

If we do not meet our goal, we will collect all donations and explore other avenues of fundraising. All funds collected will be directed to the Chinese-American community.

The Impact

The Chinese Exclusion Act is currently omitted from the majority of grade-school textbooks. Without our joined efforts to fund this project, this heinous act will be forgotten and future generations won't have the benefit of knowing their history and learning from it. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please contribute to this important community project. To show your ongoing support, please:

  • Spread the word about the Chinese Exclusion Act and how Rose Hills and the Chinese American Museum are working together to remember it. 
  • Invite your family, friends and colleagues to view this page.

story:
DISCLAIMER: Since our goal was surpassed (thank you so much to all contributors!!), we have closed donations on this site. Click here to donate or visit our website. All funds raised after April 29, 2015 will go towards gear, food, and lodging for the trip.


Hi, welcome!

Thanks so much for dropping by. We're Elizabeth and Rachel, and this spring and summer we're bicycling from San Francisco to New York City.

As we pedal east, we plan to teach hands-on lessons at middle schools and summer programs using the Sol Cycle, a miniature, 3D-printable, solar-powered bicycle we are in the process of designing. We’ll also be profiling science educators about innovation in the classroom and curating science lesson plans to create a repository of accessible, engaging activities for parents, kids and teachers alike.

Cycle for Science begins April 17 -- and we need your help.

Cycle for Science is endorsed by:
  • The North America Association for Environmental Education! Go check out their amazing work to bring the world to the classroom, and the classroom out into the world, at www.naaee.net.
  • Rock the Bike, the bringers of bicycle powered concerts!
  • The American Physical Society (APS) Education and Diversity Division

Who are we, anyways?

We met while studying physics at UCLA. But neither of us entered school thinking we'd be scientists. Rachel arrived, trombone strapped to her back, set on a career in music. Elizabeth signed up to study English, hoping to side gig at the student newspaper. Curious about physics, we both enrolled in the same one-unit seminar on "The Arrow of Time" as freshmen.

A couple years and one backpacking trip to the Alps later, we found ourselves burning the midnight oil together in a particle physics lab. Now, we're both headed toward careers in science: Elizabeth applied to graduate school in engineering last fall; she’s still figuring out where she’s going to go. Rachel is researching materials science and solar energy at the Lawrence Berkeley National Lab and applying for her PhD next year.

On our trip, we hope to show the students that scientists aren’t all old white guys with calculators growing out of their beards, who spend 24/7 in underground labs and have been tinkering with circuits since preschool. We hope to demonstrate how creative science can be and how much it already impacts their day-to-day lives.

Seriously though, diversity and engagement are two of the most pressing issues in science education. We don’t think we can solve these problems (at least not yet!) but we hope this trip will spark conversations, inspire a few kids to become scientists, and create lasting resources for educators to use in their classrooms.

Want to read more about the gender gap in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM)? Check out the 2010 report from the American Association of University Women.

Here's our plan

Biking across the country, we have three goals:

  1. Teach classes at 10 middle schools about physics, engineering and renewable energy. To do this, we need the Sol Cycle and a variety of lesson plans.

    • We are in the process of prototyping the Sol Cycle, a toy-sized bicycle that runs off a solar-powered motor. This is where the bulk of the campaign funds will go. Manufacturing and shipping are expensive -- per unit, about $60 to print and $10 more for the solar panel and motor -- and there will be additional costs for delivery and shipping to us on the road. We printed our first draft at the Sacramento Public Library, and are now working with CITRIS Invention Lab at UC Berkeley. Membership there is a little costly, but their resources and expertise will help us turn the Sol Cycle from dream to reality.


    • To design the lesson plans, we are talking with teachers and working with BASIS, a science role model volunteering program run by Community Resources for Science in Berkeley, to ensure our plans for the Sol Cycle align with Next Generation Science Standards and are feasible and implementable. And before we leave, we will be teaching lessons in Berkeley middle school classrooms to get feedback.

  2. Interview teachers at each stop about their experiences and challenges, and celebrate their work in the classroom.

    • How did they get started? What kinds of lesson plans do kids find most engaging? Does the community they live in affect the way they teach certain subjects?

    • As of the beginning of this campaign, we have already interviewed three educators and have already been deeply inspired by their grit, ingenuity and love for their students. We can't wait to share them with you.

  3. Curate these stories and lesson plans in an online collection, freely available on our website www.cycleforscience.org for anyone to use.

    • On our blog we'll be sharing video interviews and highlights from our trip, as well as other inspiring science education projects from across the globe.

    • Plus, we are going to release the digital files for the Sol Cycle, so anyone with access to a 3D printer can make their own.

The Impact

We have spent the last year saving up for this trip. We have the bikes, the bags, the lights, the seats. So, basically, we need your help funding what's important: the Sol Cycle, the lesson plans, the teacher's stories, the good stuff.

Plus, female role models have been shown to play a part in the retention of women in science. By funding our project, you're helping put female scientists in the classroom and showing your support for a more equal, diverse and innovative STEM workforce. 

Rachel teaching circuits to curious kids with our homemade bicycle generator that powered lights and a radio at Explore Your Universe Day, an annual event at UCLA.

We chose to model and 3D-print the Sol Cycles to help highlight the educational potential of emerging printing technology. Designing functioning models requires careful engineering, applying skills like trigonometry to conceptualize, create and test ideas. At the same time, it also has almost unlimited possibilities: from fossils to musical instruments, students can make almost anything they imagine.

Estimated Budget

  1. Sol Cycle (x20)
    • Prototyping -- $300
    • Materials (solar panels, electronics) -- $500
    • Manufacturing (3D printing, assembly, packaging) -- $1,500
    • Shipping -- $150
  2. Additional building and lesson plan materials: light sources, multimeter, pyranometer, wires, soldering iron etc -- $500
  3. Video Gear
    • Tripod -- ~$50
    • External Hard Drive -- $100
    • Microphone -- $150
    • Adobe Premiere, for video editing -- $20/month for six months
    • Photoshop -- $10/month for six months
  4. Travel costs for the extra days due to teaching
    • 10 classrooms and summer programs (15 additional days) -- $400/per person
Total: ~$4,400
(The additional money will be used to fulfill the perk orders.)

Perks

Stickers (colors may vary)

    

    

T-shirt

Water bottle (Customized with logo, color may vary)

Coaster

Bike jersey design coming soon (will be similar to t-shirt)

Why us?

Elizabeth Case

As it turns out, Elizabeth did get that gig at the student newspaper -- and spent four years producing radio, web and news stories for it. She worked at The Oregonian in 2013 as an AAAS Mass Media in Science and Engineering fellow, traveled to Mexico to report on injuries in the lobster-and-sea-cucumber trade, and just wrapped up her job at the Davis Enterprise, a small newspaper based in Yolo County. Curious about her work? Read the Putah Creek Legacy, a 10,000 word story on the success of a contentious environmental lawsuit.

She decided to apply to graduate school in engineering because she loves to make stuff. In her free time, she builds things like shelves and bike-mounted phone cases and jewelry and sometimes maps and websites. On Tuesdays, she plays Ultimate Frisbee. On Wednesdays, she hangs around with Code for Sacramento.

Rachel Woods-Robinson

Rachel is a scientist. At work (which she bicycles to every day, zooooom!) she synthesizes and studies new transparent conducting materials to use for solar energy conversion. In addition to her current love affair, solar energy, she's researched geothermal energy and the Moon (turns out it gets down to -250ºC in some parts, that's some ~brrrrrie~ if you're itching for a cheesy pun).

She's dedicated to spreading science beyond the lab through community outreach. In college she founded Ecochella, a now-annual concert with sound powered entirely by bicycles connected to speakers, in order to educate students about fun renewable energy solutions. She built her own bicycle generator to use at the first Ecochella, and helped initiate an engineering competition (now a staple of Ecochella!) so that student teams design their own generators for the concert.

Teaching Experience

We both have experience teaching and understand how incredibly difficult it is to teach good science while meeting state and federal standards. In high school Rachel taught music and trombone lessons, and since then has applied these skills to science to tutor high school and college students and teach renewable energy and lab classes in Bay Area classrooms through the Community Resources for Science. Elizabeth has organized statistics and data journalism workshops, tutored physics and math to elementary and high school students, was a counselor at a science and arts camp, and served an A.V.I.D. mentor her senior year in high school.
And we're both proudly nerdy about physics and incredibly passionate about the need to ensure every kid knows he or she can become a scientist.

Our Route

Our route is approximately 3,800 miles and will take about three months. The exact roads we take, and the stops we make, will vary depending on road and weather conditions, the locations of the classrooms, and other unpredictable variables. But this is about right (updated 4/30/15):
 
CA → OR → ID → WY → SD → NE → IA → IL → IN → OH → PA → MD → DC → DE → NJ → NY

Risks & Challenges

This campaign hinges around a three-month long bike trip. Many things could go wrong: we could get injured and have to stop or shorten our trip. We might have to start later than anticipated to wait out the snow melt. We will be training for the next two months to ensure we're in good shape for the road.

While all the educators we are in touch with so far (two in Sacramento, one in Idaho, two in New York) are excited about having us stop in their classrooms or at their summer programs, it's always possible other teachers will be less enthusiastic about our proposal and there's a small chance we wouldn't be able to find 10 classrooms to stop in. We have reached out to a variety of teacher associations, and many have agreed to reach out to their networks and put us in touch with teachers along our route.

We are in the midst of prototyping the Sol Cycle. We are confident we can get it running and manufactured by the time we embark on our trip, but printing errors and shipping delays could potentially postpone the trip or classroom visits. To avoid this, we will carefully review and test as many iterations of our prototype as we can. Additionally, they are toys -- they will likely be dropped and flung around, and run the risk of breaking. We will be bringing spare kits with us in case this happens. Although it is more expensive, we have chosen to use high grade 3D printing materials so that the Sol Cycle can be a durable, lasting educational tool.

Other Ways You Can Help

Other than donating to the campaign, there are a number of ways you can help contribute:

  • Do you teach along our route, or know someone who does? Get in touch with us; we'd love to talk to you about stopping at your school.
  • Send us your best lesson plan and a short blurb about you. We'll choose the best ones to highlight on our website.
  • Share our story on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, Pinterest, Ello, whatever rocks your boat (your bicycle?).
  • When the Sol Cycle .stl file goes live, print your own at your local makerspace, and get the word out!
  • Make an effort to: recognize your own biases, encourage a girl to pursue science, explain a scientific topic to someone you love, or learn about a physics concept you were never quite sure about. Share your story with the hashtag: #cycleforscience
  • Do you represent a business and like what we're doing? We'd love to talk to you about sponsoring part of our trip. Sponsors will have their logos listed on our bike jerseys and be highlighted in social media and on our website. 
Contact us at: wecycleforscience@gmail.com or check out our website at www.cycleforscience.org.

In Conclusion

We think this trip will introduce us to some pretty extraordinary folks: teachers inspiring their students to look harder and deeper at the world, kids who have their own impressions about science, researchers and educators who have studied pedagogy in depth.

And so we need your help distributing the Sol-Cycle, documenting our trip and building an online resource around the tools and lessons we learn about.

Acknowledgements

We would like to extend a super special thank you to everybody who's helped us and inspired us so far, to our science teachers who have made our education possible, and to our friends and family who have put up with our scattered brains during the sleep-deprived days leading up to this campaign. Thank you! In particular:

Sponsors/Endorsements

Rock the Bike

The North American Association of Environmental Education


Organizations

Sacramento public library
CITRIS Invention Lab, UC Berkeley
Sasha and Elise from Community Resources for Science, Berkeley
Rock the Bike, Oakland

Educators we’ve spoken with so far

Becca Rolon (Cambridge, ID)
Maria Aguilar (Sacramento, CA)
Robert Bajor (San Francisco, CA)

Video Credits

  • Filming and editing - Mara Woods-Robinson
  • And more editing - Rachel Woods-Robinson

  • Music (in order of appearance):
    • Cold World - Free Food
    • Clarinet Marmalade - Original Dixieland Jass Band
    • Miss - Jonah Levine
    • This Land is Your Land - Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings

All logos and graphics designed in-house by Elizabeth Case and Rachel Woods-Robinson

FAQ

1. Where will you guys be staying?
We plan on camping, couch surfing, and occasionally staying/showering in hotels (especially before we teach).
2. Why are you going north?
Honestly, to see Yellowstone and the Grand Tetons. There's a small chance snow's going to push back our start date, but a lot of our teaching will be at the beginning of our trip, so we'll be moving north slowly.
3. But schools end in May/June!
Yep. That's why we'll be making most of our visits at the beginning of the trip, and why we are also talking to summer schools and programs in New Jersey/New York, which start in late June.
story_txt:
DISCLAIMER: Since our goal was surpassed (thank you so much to all contributors!!), we have closed donations on this site. Click here to donate or visit our website. All funds raised after April 29, 2015 will go towards gear, food, and lodging for the trip.
Hi, welcome!

 
Thanks so much for dropping by. We're Elizabeth and Rachel, and this spring and summer we're bicycling from San Francisco to New York City. 
As we pedal east, we plan to teach hands-on lessons at middle schools and summer programs using the Sol Cycle, a miniature, 3D-printable, solar-powered bicycle we are in the process of designing. We’ll also be profiling science educators about innovation in the classroom and curating science lesson plans to create a repository of accessible, engaging activities for parents, kids and teachers alike.Cycle for Science begins April 17 -- and we need your help.


Cycle for Science is endorsed by:



The North America Association for Environmental Education! Go check out their amazing work to bring the world to the classroom, and the classroom out into the world, at www.naaee.net.

Rock the Bike, the bringers of bicycle powered concerts!
The American Physical Society (APS) Education and Diversity Division


Who are we, anyways?
 



We met while studying physics at UCLA. But neither of us entered school thinking we'd be scientists. Rachel arrived, trombone strapped to her back, set on a career in music. Elizabeth signed up to study English, hoping to side gig at the student newspaper. Curious about physics, we both enrolled in the same one-unit seminar on "The Arrow of Time" as freshmen.
A couple years and one backpacking trip to the Alps later, we found ourselves burning the midnight oil together in a particle physics lab. Now, we're both headed toward careers in science: Elizabeth applied to graduate school in engineering last fall; she’s still figuring out where she’s going to go. Rachel is researching materials science and solar energy at the Lawrence Berkeley National Lab and applying for her PhD next year. 
On our trip, we hope to show the students that scientists aren’t all old white guys with calculators growing out of their beards, who spend 24/7 in underground labs and have been tinkering with circuits since preschool. We hope to demonstrate how creative science can be and how much it already impacts their day-to-day lives.
Seriously though, diversity and engagement are two of the most pressing issues in science education. We don’t think we can solve these problems (at least not yet!) but we hope this trip will spark conversations, inspire a few kids to become scientists, and create lasting resources for educators to use in their classrooms.
Want to read more about the gender gap in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM)? Check out the 2010 report from the American Association of University Women.


Here's our plan
Biking across the country, we have three goals:


Teach classes at 10 middle schools about physics, engineering and renewable energy. To do this, we need the Sol Cycle and a variety of lesson plans.


We are in the process of prototyping the Sol Cycle, a toy-sized bicycle that runs off a solar-powered motor. This is where the bulk of the campaign funds will go. Manufacturing and shipping are expensive -- per unit, about $60 to print and $10 more for the solar panel and motor -- and there will be additional costs for delivery and shipping to us on the road. We printed our first draft at the Sacramento Public Library, and are now working with CITRIS Invention Lab at UC Berkeley. Membership there is a little costly, but their resources and expertise will help us turn the Sol Cycle from dream to reality.




To design the lesson plans, we are talking with teachers and working with BASIS, a science role model volunteering program run by Community Resources for Science in Berkeley, to ensure our plans for the Sol Cycle align with Next Generation Science Standards and are feasible and implementable. And before we leave, we will be teaching lessons in Berkeley middle school classrooms to get feedback.



Interview teachers at each stop about their experiences and challenges, and celebrate their work in the classroom.

How did they get started? What kinds of lesson plans do kids find most engaging? Does the community they live in affect the way they teach certain subjects?
As of the beginning of this campaign, we have already interviewed three educators and have already been deeply inspired by their grit, ingenuity and love for their students. We can't wait to share them with you.



Curate these stories and lesson plans in an online collection, freely available on our website www.cycleforscience.org for anyone to use.

On our blog we'll be sharing video interviews and highlights from our trip, as well as other inspiring science education projects from across the globe.
Plus, we are going to release the digital files for the Sol Cycle, so anyone with access to a 3D printer can make their own.





The Impact

We have spent the last year saving up for this trip. We have the bikes, the bags, the lights, the seats. So, basically, we need your help funding what's important: the Sol Cycle, the lesson plans, the teacher's stories, the good stuff.
Plus, female role models have been shown to play a part in the retention of women in science. By funding our project, you're helping put female scientists in the classroom and showing your support for a more equal, diverse and innovative STEM workforce. 


Rachel teaching circuits to curious kids with our homemade bicycle generator that powered lights and a radio at Explore Your Universe Day, an annual event at UCLA.
We chose to model and 3D-print the Sol Cycles to help highlight the educational potential of emerging printing technology. Designing functioning models requires careful engineering, applying skills like trigonometry to conceptualize, create and test ideas. At the same time, it also has almost unlimited possibilities: from fossils to musical instruments, students can make almost anything they imagine.

Estimated Budget

Sol Cycle (x20)

Prototyping -- $300
Materials (solar panels, electronics) -- $500
Manufacturing (3D printing, assembly, packaging) -- $1,500
Shipping -- $150


Additional building and lesson plan materials: light sources, multimeter, pyranometer, wires, soldering iron etc -- $500
Video Gear

Tripod -- ~$50
External Hard Drive -- $100
Microphone -- $150
Adobe Premiere, for video editing -- $20/month for six months
Photoshop -- $10/month for six months


Travel costs for the extra days due to teaching
10 classrooms and summer programs (15 additional days) -- $400/per person



Total: ~$4,400(The additional money will be used to fulfill the perk orders.)




Perks
Stickers (colors may vary)
    


    

T-shirt



Water bottle (Customized with logo, color may vary)

Coaster


Bike jersey design coming soon (will be similar to t-shirt)

Elizabeth Case
As it turns out, Elizabeth did get that gig at the student newspaper -- and spent four years producing radio, web and news stories for it. story:
(For more on Bridges, and to watch him perform to support The KEEN Group, go to esquire.com.)


What Is The KEEN Group?

Kids Environmental Education Network (KEEN) is a charitable nonprofit serving youth who are underrepresented in nature and the outdoors.  Prior to 2009 KEEN was a community development corporation which performed comprehensive community revitalization.  In 2009 a County Health Assessment revealed  that KEEN’S Target Area had the highest  rates of obesity, diabetes, high blood pressure  and heart disease.  KEEN knew the area had few amenities that contributed to healthy lifestyles, like supermarkets, greenspace and recreation.  We decided to concentrate on the segment that we could have the greatest impact, youth and the outdoors.

KEEN developed two groundbreaking projects to get children into nature, Focus and the Green Bunch.  Focus teaches digital photography and introduces film photography to kids from ages 9 to 15.  Kids  are rewarded with a photo exhibit, public acclaim and positive feedback.  They are encouraged to continue photography  as Focus gives them a digital camera upon completion of the course.

Green Bunch teaches fishing, hiking, camping, and land navigation to kids ages 7 to 16. In addition the Green Bunch uses these  excursions to teach environmental stewardship, personal responsibility and team building.

KEEN’s programs are unique because they teach skills that can be enjoyed for a lifetime and because they provide intergenerational engagement. KEEN delivers programs through the KEEN Volunteer Corps, a multiracial group of trained, screened, retired individuals. These persons teach, keep order, encourage, mediate conflict and become the kind of grandfatherly figure kids need.


Where Your Donation Goes

KEEN needs funds to transport kids to and from the parks and lakes, pay for cameras, provide food, water and supplies, Incentives for completion of activities, t-shirts, and other uncovered expenses.

story:
My journey

Hi, I'm Aimee-Josiane! I'm from Rwanda and I grew up in the heart of Africa. When I was 10 years old, my parents, siblings and I came to the United States and ended up staying here as refugees because of the war and genocide in Rwanda. Being a refugee pushed me into activism and I have since been involved in work to lift up queer and trans people of color, to stop violence against Black women and girls, and work to end domestic and international militarism. 

I believe that oppression sucks, and that is takes away so much from us including our internal permissions to be our most authentic selves. But authenticity is key to self-determination and liberation. So as I struggle and wait for justice in the world, I find incredible peace in the process of seeking the things that will allow me control of my life (self-determination) as well as the strength to liberate the parts of me that have been erased by oppression. This process can and IS transforming me and people that I know, and now with the guidance and support of my family I would like to share this gift with as many people as possible. I want to be a coach for personal and collective transformational change!

 

Why coaching?

Coaching for me comes down to helping. I believe in abundant support, encouragement and self-recognition. As an internationally certified coach, I will be able to help individuals, romantic partners and organizations transform the ways they operate by honoring their gifts and learning how to get unstuck in the most difficult situations. I also hope to radicalize this practice by making it more accessible to people who are most impacted by racist, economic, and gendered state-violence.

Here's what it's going to take:

  • MORE TRAINING: While I have experience as a community organizer, mentor and consultant, I want to learn from the best, and to me that is Leadership That Work's Coaching for Transformation program.
  • MORE MENTORSHIP: In addition to 140 classroom hours, I will work with mentors who reflect me and the communities that I serve. 
  • CHALLENGE TO GROW: This program includes 40-100 practice hours where my coaching can be evaluated by my peers in this field.

I have already raised $2000 in scholarships and by helping me pay for the rest of my tuition [ $6,860 ]  you will allow me to save money for my licensing exam and my official membership to the International Coaching Federation, a global organization for the advancement of the art, science and practice of professional coaching. 

Anything raised beyond my goal will go towards my licensing and professional fees.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money but still want to help?

  • Share this campaign with your friends!
  • Spread the word and let your network know what culturally-relevant, queer and trans friendly, anti-oppression based coaching means and how they can support it.
  • Connect me to people in your life who are looking for coaching.

 

Thank You!

story:
The Story

http://www.aryakanya.org/aims_objects.html
  • To grow a vegetable (and possible flower) garden for the Arya Kanya Sadan girls orphanage in Delhi NCR, India
  • To teach the life skill of gardening to some of the girls
  • To have a project that could have a long-term impact
  • Any money beyond what is needed for the garden will go towards the girls uniforms and education
Hello, my name is Claire Moore. I am 19 years old and passionately wanna do some good in this world. Why not do what you can do? Who's to say you're not making an impact or changing the world? The suffering of one person is not any less valid than 1 million's. One persons joy in one moment matters too.  I have come to India to volunteer with an organization and I was placed in an incredible girls orphanage. I have been here 1 month and I'm staying 4 more. I have fallen in love with these girls and this place has become my home. I have contacted past volunteers who are also passionate about this place and we are going to try to raise some funds for this place. A little here goes a very long way! You can't imagine what 5 dollars will do. Obviously there is a lot of need so the more the better but every dollar here truly counts. Don't shy away because you only have a small amount to give, it will be used with care and will be spent well and it will be appreciated. I have written more detailed about this place on my blog and in particularly in one post..if you would like to learn more about the 87 girls here and this place please go to the link and read, I promise you won't be sorry you did. 
http://beauty-in-the-chaos.blogspot.in/2015/02/somethings-to-discuss.html
What We Need & What You Get
There are many needs here and every month it changes. This place gets most of their things and funding from donors but a lot of that isn't money so they make use of what they get. Every month I'm here I'm hoping to do a little bit. I'm using about 50 US dollars (3000 rupees) of my own money each month I'm here (the other day this bought a mirror and about 30 panties and 20 bras) but for a girl on a tight budget that's quite a lot but I still want to do more! Something I recently talked to the director, Annie, about was a garden. I've done some gardening in the past and I mentioned this. Annie thought this was a great. We have some green space here but that haven't been able to do much with it, so my first project with the money is to make a garden. Any money beyond what would be spent on the garden would go for new school uniforms, which is something they need, and then after that school tuitions. As the garden grows you'll be able to see pictures and I'll try to keep up the updates on my end. 
The Impact
    So let's talk more about this garden shall we? This is great for a few reasons: 1) It's longterm 2) they often get rice and such donated but less often veggies, so Annie has to trade for them, how great would it be if they could also get these veggies from their garden?! 3) Hello helping the environment! (trust me, in India it's very needed) 4) How about spreading beauty? 5) Most importantly I hope to help teach a few of the girls, and they can carry it on to other girls, and this is a valuable tool you can carry on in life, if they have a family having a garden could truly help their future lives. Now let's talk about school. Private schooling here to them isn't cheap but Annie wants her girls to get a good education. Right now though Annie is only able to select some girls once they get older to send to private school and the rest go to government school, and even then it's difficult to get together the money for the private schooling. Not only this but after high school she makes sure her girls get the chance to go to university and training and can even stay here during this time, but this also can be pricey. So your funding would be going towards a place I feel very passionate about helping and very useful things; a garden which would allow an education of this for these girls to carry with them into womanhood and help when they have a family and would be an asset to this orphanages needs and then if more is raised it would be used towards the invaluable wealth of a girls education. To read more facts on the importance of educating women look here http://www.takepart.com/photos/ten-must-read-facts-impact-girls-education/education--

Risks & Challenges

So obviously I can only promote this so much. There is no way to guarantee that I will raise all the funds to make an incredible garden and there is no way to guarantee it will always last and be properly taken care of but I think the more stable and sturdy I am able to make it with the funds the better it will be and the longer it will last. Such as I will be able to buy more shovels and equipment, I will be able to buy more seeds and the proper ones, I will be able to help solve soil problems. The biggest issue will probably be the animals so I'd really like to spend some good money on fencing and chicken wire for that. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can donate 5 dollars or 50 dollars do it! And make some noise whether you can or not! Get the word out there about this place and what were doing! Send your positive thoughts and prayers and keep this place in your mind. So lets get the word out there and try to educate some girls and hand in hand change the world:)
story_txt:
The Story

http://www.aryakanya.org/aims_objects.html


To grow a vegetable (and possible flower) garden for the Arya Kanya Sadan girls orphanage in Delhi NCR, India
To teach the life skill of gardening to some of the girls
To have a project that could have a long-term impact
Any money beyond what is needed for the garden will go towards the girls uniforms and education

Hello, my name is Claire Moore. I am 19 years old and passionately wanna do some good in this world. Why not do what you can do? Who's to say you're not making an impact or changing the world? The suffering of one person is not any less valid than 1 million's. One persons joy in one moment matters too.  I have come to India to volunteer with an organization and I was placed in an incredible girls orphanage. I have been here 1 month and I'm staying 4 more. I have fallen in love with these girls and this place has become my home. I have contacted past volunteers who are also passionate about this place and we are going to try to raise some funds for this place. A little here goes a very long way! You can't imagine what 5 dollars will do. Obviously there is a lot of need so the more the better but every dollar here truly counts. Don't shy away because you only have a small amount to give, it will be used with care and will be spent well and it will be appreciated. I have written more detailed about this place on my blog and in particularly in one post..if you would like to learn more about the 87 girls here and this place please go to the link and read, I promise you won't be sorry you did. 
http://beauty-in-the-chaos.blogspot.in/2015/02/somethings-to-discuss.html
What We Need & What You Get
There are many needs here and every month it changes. This place gets most of their things and funding from donors but a lot of that isn't money so they make use of what they get. Every month I'm here I'm hoping to do a little bit. I'm using about 50 US dollars (3000 rupees) of my own money each month I'm here (the other day this bought a mirror and about 30 panties and 20 bras) but for a girl on a tight budget that's quite a lot but I still want to do more! Something I recently talked to the director, Annie, about was a garden. I've done some gardening in the past and I mentioned this. Annie thought this was a great. We have some green space here but that haven't been able to do much with it, so my first project with the money is to make a garden. story:
Across the country, 15 Now has played a leading role in the struggle for a higher minimum wage. In June of 2014, I started the 15 Now NJ chapter to organize a grassroots campaign in my community. Since then, we have picked up traction with unions, community groups, and working people across the state.

Attending this meeting in March would be an amazing opportunity and I'd really appreciate any assistance.

In June of 2014, I started the 15 Now NJ chapter to organize a grassroots campaign in my community.  Since then, we have picked up traction with unions, community groups, and working people across the state.Attending this meeting in March would be an amazing opportunity and I'd really appreciate any assistance.

story:
(Check back here for regular updates, including exclusive videos of performances, behind-the-scenes footage and personal messages - check out the new featured video of 'The Solution' below!)

Hi, I'm Umar.

On January 12th, 2015 I will begin my first day of class at the New England Conservatory in Boston. With the help of a generous scholarship, I will travel to a new city and start a brand new adventure. I'll meet inspiring people, learn new things and try crazy ideas I'd never imagined before. 

But in order to stay there, I'll need your help. Boston is well-known as one of the most expensive places to live in the United States, and even with the substantial scholarship I've been offered, the tuition and fees at New England Conservatory are incredibly costly.

It was only a few days before the launch of this campaign that I was offered this opportunity. Since then I have spent my days and nights planning and preparing for this campaign and for the trip itself. If nothing else, I have on my side the determination to make this work. I have been auditioning for schools since late 2013 and this is indeed the prize that I have been fighting for.

I cannot express in words how much I appreciate the support of those who have brought me this far. Please join us - make a pledge to support my quest. I've been working hard over several days to prepare some really great experiences as perks, too! Your help will not go unrewarded, and it certainly will not go unappreciated.  

Yours sincerely,

Umar

---

About Umar

  • Born in Singapore. Grew up in Christchurch. Studied in Wellington and Denton, TX.
  • Won 2nd place in the BASS2014 International Jazz Bass Competition
  • A previous student of the legendary Lynn Seaton.
  • Played in the NZSO National Youth Orchestra for 3 years.
  • Umar's compositions have been performed by the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra, the Royal New Zealand Ballet and the New Zealand School of Music Big Band One.

Articles

• http://www.nzsm.ac.nz/news/latest-news/umar-world-runner-up-jazz-bassist

◦ http://www.jazzlocal32.com/2014/08/06/mark-lockett-trio-cjc-winter-2014

---

Featured Video: 'Archimedes' by Umar Zakaria


---

story:
hs.hact.io is a three day digital technologies event for 300 ACT high school students. Our event promotes a project-based learning approach to STEM disciplines and entrepreneurship.

Beginners enroll in one of five technology streams on offer, receiving mentoring and support from Canberra's talented tech community. Over three days we will help students prototype their first website, mobile app, videogame, 3D animation, or 3D printed object. Advanced students can team up and use the three day event to start and finish a project, pitch their innovation, and compete for some great prizes.

This inaugural event is for students from all ACT high schools. It takes place in the Easter school holidays over 17-19 April at Canberra Grammar's brand new Snow Centre building. Tickets are only $20 and you can get one here. We're keeping the ticket price low to make sure any teen with a passion for tech can attend. This means we need your support to help cover prizes and brain food.

Australia's future is in exporting ideas and technologies. Our goal is to grow hs.hact.io into a national event. Your support now will let us produce the materials we need to roll out hs.hact.io to satellite locations across Australia in 2016.

hs.hact.io takes many people to organise. It builds on Event Lead Matt Stimson's solid track record in running Canberra's largest coding and entrepreneurship events (including GovHack Canberra 2014 and its 140 developers).

We've had more than 60 expressions of interest for volunteers already - submit yours here! Our event and stream leads are shown below. Read more about our qualifications by clicking any of the photos below. 

Improving gender diversity in tech is a critical objective for us, and is the shared responsibility of all volunteers at our event. If you're a female technologist, please make the extra effort to volunteer at our event. Positive association now can make all the difference to a young person's future studies and choice of careers.

The safety of the students is another event priority. All volunteers at hs.hact.io will have their ACT Government-issued 'Working with Vulnerable People' card (or interstate equivalent, for example the 'Working with Children Check' in New South Wales). We are also bringing as many teachers on board as volunteers as we can find.

The Snow Centre is a state of the art facility with 14 classrooms, breakout spaces, and 1Gb fibre connection. It's the perfect venue for our event and has been made available for our use on the weekend. 

All that's left to do is for students to arrive with their WiFi-capable laptops!

We have some great rewards for the people and organisations that pledge to support our campaign. Take a look:

A range of corporate partnership opportunities exist for this event. Please consult our Partnership Opportunities document for details:

Icons made by Freepik from www.flaticon.com is licensed by CC BY 3.0.

We've approached startup luminaries and asked them to provide an hour of 1 on 1 coaching, with proceeds going to our campaign. To say these people are in high demand is a serious understatement. We'll be announcing more mentors across our campaign, so regularly check in to avoid missing your big opportunity.

Our eternal thanks to the following rockstars:

hs.hact.io will have some 450 people involved across the weekend. The costs add up quickly. The $20,000 goal covers the event prizes, venue cleaning, printing, certificates, and t-shirts for the students/volunteers. Raising money beyond this means we can do a lot more for high schoolers nationwide:


The difference between raising $20,000 and $100,000 means the difference between local and national satellite locations in 2016.

Thank you for seeing the value in our event. There are so many ways for you to get involved!

1. Click the campaign share tools and help us spread the word.

2. Make a pledge and help us better engage young Australians with tech and entrepreneurship.

3. Volunteer your technical skills and/or event management talents here.

4. Purchase your child's ticket to our event here.

5. Find photos of your first memory of tech and share your story with the #firstmemoryoftech hash tag.

6. Follow our journey on twitter and facebook!

Thanks IndieGoGoers for your help. We'll document the journey to hs.hact.io 2015 in our campaign updates, so remember to check back regularly :)

- The hs.hact.io team


Entry 29 Limited is a community organisation. It is owned by and operated for the benefit of its members. It is a requirement of using our facilities and paid programs and events that you are a member of Entry 29 Limited. Any amount of money pledged to this campaign will be considered to be an application to be a 'Special Events' class of member of Entry 29. No voting rights or access to the Entry 29 member benefits program is attached to this class of membership. Pledging to this Indiegogo campaign must be on the basis that you agree to these terms. Those persons pledging at least AUD$30 to this campaign have the option of using a complimentary day of co-working at Entry 29's facilities. Anyone exercising this option accepts and will comply with the terms found in the Entry 29 'member licence agreement' and 'Entry 29 code of conduct' (accessible here). This membership expires either on 30 June 2015 or at the end of the calendar day at which you exercise the complimentary day pass offer (whichever occurs first).

story:
What does it mean to be fluent in a language?

  • to express oneself effortlessly
  • to express oneself accurately
  • to express oneself effectively

Our Mission

To foster greater fluency among adult English language learners. How? By building a cutting-edge, state-of-the art website that allows ESL students to converse orally with both native and non-native English speakers.  

An Educator's Perspective

      

Why We Need the Website

Many adult English language learners plateau (level off) before acquiring enough fluency to successfully manage academic coursework. 

Nine Students' Perspectives

(The students interviewed below are all intermediate English language learners. They were not told what or what not to say.)

How We Acquire Fluent English

  • By listening to others (preferably native speakers).
  • By speaking the language yourself.
  • By interacting with others who are speaking the language.
  • By embracing the language learning experience.

What the Website Will Provide

  • Online conversation practice with native and non-native English speakers
  • Discussion of interesting topics that are presented right on the website.
  • Discussion of thought-provoking films that are watched on the website.
  • Discussion of engaging video lessons that are watched on the website.

What We Need

  • Website Design and Development:  $ 8500 - 4000 = $4500                          ($4000+ already contributed by the founder)
  • Hosting- Virtual Private Server (VPS):  $ 200 per month
  • Stock Footage, Photography, Video Portfolio:  $600 per year

What You Get

Be an Honorary Founder!

For a pledge of $ 40, you'll receive a full-year's membership in the "Conversations in English" family. You'll have access to all the topics, videos, and lessons...and you'll be able to participate in the online discussions at any time. What's more, you'll be acknowledged as an Honorary Founder of the website in the "About Us" page of the website!

The Impact

Your contribution will:

  • Make it possible for adult English as a Second Language (ESL)  learners to practice conversing in English anytime and anywhere.  
  • Help bridge the cultural divide--if only to a small degree.
  • Combat the cultural illiteracy of both native and non-native English speakers.
  • Open doors of opportunity for many who are stifled by poor language skills.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out to anyone, and particularly to those who speak English as a second language.
  • Share the need via social media and other share tools.

story:
Short Summary

I'm a monk from Zimbabwe. I founded a charity (UK registration 1136035) that works in Zimbabwe called Tariro, which means hope. We have about 80 children (most of whom are orphans) who we care for: getting them into school, making sure they're well fed and clothed, and ultimately, giving them a future. 

Most of the children we work with are victims of HIV/AIDS; their parents have died, leaving them sometimes abandoned, sometimes with old grandparents, and always, deeply traumatised. Without Tariro, they would have no hope, no future - to survive they would turn to crime or the sex industry, abused, and desperate. Tariro doesn't just give these children help; it saves their lives.

The children we support live in four centres around Zimbabwe. We work with 80, but there are thousands beyond that need help. We keep finding more children who need looking after and must build a new home to take them in. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need £5,000 as soon as possible so we can build some new, small cottages, each with a house mother, to give new children a family home environment. 

The £5,000 would complete the first of these cottages, in Zimbabwe's Eastern Highlands. If we can raise more than £5,000, we can build further cottages, supporting even more children.

To donate please do so via https://mydonate.bt.com/charities/tariro-hopefo... or follow the funding link.

The Impact

Tariro has been running for six years and in that time we have seen our children grow up strong, healthy, and able to support themselves in Zimbabwe's hard economic and political environment. Without our help these children would be abandoned on the streets. Instead, their future is bright.

We have developed real expertise in knowing what particular support these children need, and want to be able to deliver it to more children across the country.  

Risks & Challenges

We are a very small charity based in northern England. We have no running costs in England, and so Tariro is able to spend 100% of the funding we receive supporting children in Zimbabwe. We have a strong, transparent policy whereby funds are sent directly to a Tariro administrator in Zimbabwe, who distributes them directly to the centres. 

We have put in place a child protection policy which has regular reviews.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can contribute, but anything you can do to help spread the word would be amazing:

1. Please post the link to this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn profiles, or anything else that will help us spread the word

2. Please send an email to your friends and family who might be interested and tell them they can help support orphans in Zimbabwe

4. Please sign up to join our newsletter by emailing nstebbing@mirfield.org.uk and find out more about our work at http://www.tarirouk.com

 We need £5,000 as soon as possible so we can build some new, small cottages, each with a house mother, to give new children a family home environment. 
The £5,000 would complete the first of these cottages, in Zimbabwe's Eastern Highlands. If we can raise more than £5,000, we can build further cottages, supporting even more children.
To donate please do so via https://mydonate.bt.com/charities/tariro-hopefo... or follow the funding link.
    The Impact Tariro has been running for six years and in that time we have seen our children grow up strong, healthy, and able to support themselves in Zimbabwe's hard economic and political environment. Without our help these children would be abandoned on the streets. Instead, their future is bright.
We have developed real expertise in knowing what particular support these children need, and want to be able to deliver it to more children across the country.  
    Risks & Challenges We are a very small charity based in northern England. We have no running costs in England, and so Tariro is able to spend 100% of the funding we receive supporting children in Zimbabwe. We have a strong, transparent policy whereby funds are sent directly to a Tariro administrator in Zimbabwe, who distributes them directly to the centres. 
We have put in place a child protection policy which has regular reviews.
    Other Ways You Can Help We know that not everyone can contribute, but anything you can do to help spread the word would be amazing:
1. Please post the link to this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn profiles, or anything else that will help us spread the word
2. Please send an email to your friends and family who might be interested and tell them they can help support orphans in Zimbabwe
4. Please sign up to join our newsletter by emailing nstebbing@mirfield.org.uk and find out more about our work at http://www.tarirouk.com

story:
**IMPORTANT**
At this time, I'm overwhelmed by support. If you want to donate, please consider giving to Migration Aid (http://www.migrationaid.net/english/) in lieu of a donation to me.

*Note:
Due to the number of donations I have received, I may be unable to supply you with calories, though I will give you a list of the supplies your contribution bought. Receipts for the goods are also available on request.


Short Summary

I will carry food or any other supplies to the Nyugati and Keleti refugee camps or "Transit Zones" and give them to people.

What We Need & What You Get

  • A little bit goes a long ways, whatever you can give will go directly into the hands or refugees in the form of food and supplies.
  • I'll take a picture of your donation, and give you a calorie count and an estimation of how many people you fed.
  • I'll cover whatever percentage IndieGoGo takes, in real time. If I don't meet the five hundred dollar (minimum) goal, I'll cover the 5% of the donation that IndieGoGo takes. That way, 100% of your money goes to the refugees.

The Impact

  • The Hungarian government is not helping people, is actively obstructing them as they move across Europe.
  • I live twenty minutes from these camps in the train station. Magdi reads Hungarian and we can bring them what they need every day based on the facebook feed of the groups running the camps. I'll go buy the food and supplies at a grocery store in Budapest and bring it to the camps.

Risks & Challenges

  • There's literally no risk. I'm going to turn your money into food and feed people with it, and as long as there's more money, I'll keep hauling food and supplies to the people at the refugee camps.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't afford to send money, feel free to share.

story:
THANK YOU for coming to Smart Me's Indiegogo page!  Please choose a reward perk on the right to enable Smart Me Educational Products to take its products to production and have them ready for Summer Learning 2020!  

 

About Smart Me Educational Products...

Smart Me™ originated by inspiration after the birth of my youngest daughter, who was born with Down syndrome.  Putting my law career on hold to be available for her (and my other children) full-time, the educator in me surfaced and the desire to provide her with focused educational tools for early learning inspired the creation of the original Smart Me™ educational workbooks and DVDs – Colors and Shapes, Letters and Sounds, and Ready to Read!.  These Pre-K and Kindergarten level workbooks and DVDs were designed to provide her with focused visual and auditory learning as well as memory and fine motor development.  They worked!  At age three, my daughter could identify every primary color and basic shape, and could identify and sound out almost all letters of the alphabet.  By age four, she knew all letters and their sounds.  Her Exceptional Early Learning Program (EELP) teachers were astonished at her level of ability.

Realizing that Smart Me™ was a gift, not just to my daughter, but to ALL children, Smart Me™ Educational Products began reaching children in daycare settings, through sales to parents, grandparents, and even teachers, at flea markets, and through word-of-mouth.  I have heard and continue to hear great reports that Smart Me™ preschool products was/is instrumental in successfully preparing children for kindergarten.  And, Smart Me™ kindergarten products are of the BEST available in reinforcing skills taught in kindergarten in preparation for first grade.

In 2011, Smart Me™ Educational Products expanded its product line of Math and Reading/Language Arts workbooks from preschool up to 5th grade.  Smart Me™ was excited to make a difference in learning for children in pre-k through 5th grade by helping them build and master strong foundational skills in earlier grades for success in middle grades and beyond.  Smart Me™ Educational Products continued to provide its great educational resources to parents for their children through word-of-mouth, afterschool tutoring (Joint Base Andrews, MD), and sales at military Exchange store kiosks.

Smart Me™ Educational Products believes in its products and in its mission, which is… “To make a difference in education by helping children build strong, foundational early learning skills in math and reading.”  With extra practice at home, children are more likely to gain improved understanding of skills and improved grades…  Encouraging continued learning in math and reading, especially over the summer, is critical to a child’s mastery of current and future concepts and skills. 

So, now… today… settled after a long military journey and looking forward to a bright, successful future, Smart Me™ Educational Products is rebranded, is reviving and revising vintage products, and is creating amazing NEW products!!!  Smart Me™ is RELAUNCHING in 2020 into online sales and into retail space to bring its exceptional products to children everywhere in a BIG way! 

What We Need & What You Get

Smart Me Educational Products seeks to raise $60,000 for 

Product Production (Math and Reading Skills workbooks, Summer Reading books, puzzles, Smart Me Learning Cards, Smart Me Kid Educational Plush Dolls, Promo Items) - $42,000 

New Website Structure - $3,400

Advertising and Marketing - $9,000

Re-Startup/Working Capital - $5,000 

Please click one of the links to “back” Smart Me™ Educational Products and receive great Smart Me™ perks, such as...

  • Smart Me Kid "Melia" Plush Educational Doll
  • Smart Me Educational Puzzle
  • Smart Me Coloring Book and Crayons

 

The Impact

The objective of Smart Me Educational Products is to help parents help their children build strong, foundational (basic) skills in early learning that are necessary for educational success.  A solid foundation DOES improve academic success. Also, with an emphasis on Summer Learning, SMEP provides fun, effective practice, review, and reinforcement of foundational (basic) skills learned during the just ended school year to bridge the gap in learning over the summer months.

 

Risks and Challenges

This is Smart Me Educational Products' first Indiegogo campaign and we are excited and confident in meeting our goal.  The deliverables are not challenging to meet as all Smart Me products offered are at the production stage and just need funding to proceed.  All reward perks should be shipped to you by mid-May.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, Share, Share with anyone and everyone you know on your social media outlets and through word-of-mouth, especially with parents and grandparents with children ages 2 - 12.  ANYONE can "back" SMEP.  Send texts and emails to family and friends and share the link to this crowdfund page.  Thank you in advance for your support!
