story:
It's "Smart Cube" 

 

 

Cube is sometimes used in a variety of ways.

 

 

It's been 40 years since the cube came into the world and it's true that almost everyone knows or has tried it more than once.

According to the survey, about 98% people of the world knew about the cube.

 

How about you?  Here's my case.  

Cube was too difficult to learn!! Do you buy that?

 

But now, it is no longer so. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The mobile apps are available via Apple app store and Google Play.

 

You can enjoy various contents such like missions, timer and games through a mobile app that works with JUNECUBE.  

 

However, you need to know about this.

In fact, JUNECUBE does not necessarily require a mobile app.

 

Because the processor of JUNECUBE has an intelligent solution algorithm.  So JUNECUBE can tell you the solution on its own without having to sync with the app. 

This is a big difference from other Smart Cubes.

 

 

Light emitting from JUNECUBE can make it easier for the user to solve the cube. This is very direct and most effective.

So we can call JUNECUBE as the "Smart Cube" or the "Easiest Cube"

 

 

 

PLUS

JUNECUBE is also a Smart Mood light, so it can be awesome interior item in your place.

The brightness of the mood light can be controlled by the mobile app. 

 

 

Remember light-emitting sequence and rotate the layers of the cube just like that!

 

 

 
 
 

 

One day in the spring of 2018, my son, June, came up to me and said,

     "I watched YouTube videos and read books to solve the Cube, but it's still too hard."

     "How nice would it be to have light coming out of the cube and giving directions?"

 

I shouted, "That's a good idea."

 

This was the beginning of the development of JUNECUBE. 

 

So I started searching for prior patents and papers all over the world.  And I was able to collect and analyze the patents related to the cube. 

 

 

PCB

When developing the PCB, we have disassembled the cube which is commonly sold in the market and applied the PCB prototype into the cube. 

 

 

Working prototype

It was very hard to make the size of a cube like an existing cube.
However, if the size of the cube is bigger than the existing cube due to electronic components, users will feel uncomfortable.

We've been trying to make sure that all electronic components are integrated into the core of a limited-sized cube. 

So after repeated 3D printing and revised the drawings, we were finally able to make the current cube product.  JUNECUBE is about the almost same size as the existing cube. 

 
 
 

Amazing Magnetic Cube

All blocks in the JUNECUBE contain magnets.
This adjusts to the correct angle when the user rotates the cube.
Also, it is made of good material and solid design.
You can feel it as soon as you try to twist it.

 

Completed mass production system

 

 

 
 

We don't want children to give up the challenge after all because the cube is so difficult.

We want every child to master the cube and enjoy the challenge. 

JUNECUBE can do so.
 

And ultimately, we believe that children will have an ability to solve the any cube quickly without any JUNECUBE's instruction. 

JUNECUBE's role is just in there.

 

 

 
Charging cable is included.
 
 

(cable is micro USB cable) 

 

Product Color variation for Indiegogo 

Classic edition : Gray Cube & White Charger

Red edition : Red Cube & Red Charger

 

Plus White and Black Editions are coming : only for Indiegogo

 

Product dimension:  65mm X 65mm X 65mm (Length x Width x Height)

Weight:  180g

Wireless Communication:  Bluetooth BLE 

Battery:  Lithium ion, 3.7V 370mAh (available for 30 minutes after a full 1 hour charge)

 

Please note that the specifications listed above can be changed somewhat to make a better product. 

 

Intellectual property : International patents, design patents, and trademarks are pending.

 

 

It's fortunate that experienced and knowledgeable professional engineers have joined in this project. Thanks to their dedicated passion, JUNECUBE was developed faster.  

 

 

TED LEE:  General manager of this project and June's dad.

S.Y LEE:  Software and application developer.  He is developing Android and IOS applications. 

J. CHOI:  Product planning and hardware developers. He was in charge of hardware development and is currently building a mass production system. 

I.H.KIM:  Circuit design and development engineer. He has developed PCBs and sensors and is currently working on product certification. 

Y.J.BHAN:  Mechanical design engineer.  He designed and manufactured a prototype. He is complementing the product design for mass production. 

J.W. BAEK:  Product designer.  He was responsible for the design of JUNECUBE. And it is currently  improving design of mass-production products.

and my son, June, is a co-inventor of JUNECUBE.

 

 

Thankfully, our project has been supported by many organizations in the South Korea.

 

 

 

Do you want to see more pictures and recent information?

Just visit our social channels and contact us. 

 

Risks and challenges

1. All the built-in parts will be commercial products. However, some of parts can be changed during mass-production phase to produce better products, which could lead to an increase in overall production cost. Nevertheless, this Indiegogo campaign is the for first time to introduce JUNECUBE, so we will not charge the backers any additional costs.

2. We will do our best for delivery. However, there will be a little delay to some countries and regions.

3. If the product breaks down during shipment, we will ship it back to the new product in the earliest possible time.

4. We're a small startup. A few employees are always working busy. Therefore, the respond to the inquiry may be delayed. However, we strongly promise that we will do our best.

story:
What's a Manga Library?  Why Should I Care?

The Carolina Manga Library is a non-profit organization that sets up free libraries at conventions for all attendees to enjoy. They bring over 5000 manga, American graphic novels, webcomics, and novels for fans to enjoy. By setting up a quiet place for people to relax at conventions, the Library seeks to promote literacy through the medium that they love.

The Library was founded in 2013, debuting at Nashicon in Columbia, South Carolina. Since then, the Library has been guests at conventions all over the eastern United States and their collection becomes larger with every passing month, having expanded to all forms of graphic novels. 

This group travels all around the US to set up these libraries to provide free access to graphic novels to underprivileged areas and to foster a life-long love of reading.  They set up at schools, hospitals, conventions, public libraries, and shelters.

What's Going On?

In the wake of the COVID-19 virus pandemic, more and more large gatherings are being forbidden by various cities in the United States.  This has unfortunately shown that many large scale events like conventions are now being closed down for 2020.

Our largest spring event was scheduled to take place March 19-21 in Lancaster, PA.  That event has now been cancelled with less than a week to go.  

This event was supposed to be our largest spring fundraising event.  We usually raise about 20% of our annual budget at this show.  Without that show happening, we will not be able to pay our bills in March, April, or early May.  Our next event isn't scheduled until mid-May.  

 

How Can You Help?

After the massive success of our Trailer GoFundMe in 2019, we did not want to do another GoFundMe where our supporters didn't receive anything other than thanks for their generosity.  

Most of the other vendors/artists who were supposed to attend these cancelled shows have the ability to have online sales to try to generate lost revenue.  As a nonprofit, we do not have that luxury.  Instead, we've decided to utilize Indiegogo so that our supporters can have a tangible piece of our gratitude.

We need to raise $2000 to pay our bills for the months of March, April, and May.  This does not include any salaries, this is strictly to keep the vehicles, storage units, and liability insurance paid for.  Anything raised over the initial $2000 will be put away in case any other conventions cancel on us.

 

What Do I Get?

Below are descriptions of our tiered donation rewards!

$10: Button Set

If you donate at this tier you will receive a complete set of our 2.5 inch buttons.  There are 7 buttons in all featuring various designs of our two mascots, our logo, and our slogan "Reading is Reading is Reading".

$25: Button Set + 2 Bookmarks

If you donate at this tier you will receive our two exclusively designed bookmarks featuring our two mascots, Caro and Lina, at leisure in their own homes.  These designs are ONLY available on our bookmarks!  Each bookmark comes with a colored tassel and star charm, as well as a holographic backing that makes each bookmark 100% unique.  The bookmarks are enclosed in a durable plastic sheath.

 

$50: Button Set + 2 Bookmarks + Sparkle Jar (Small)

If you donate at this tier you will receive a custom-made small Sparkle Jar.  Each donor will be asked their favorite colors and our Head Librarian will create a customized, one-of-a-kind sparkle jar for you to enjoy.  All the bottles are made of durable, nearly-unbreakable plastic and are sealed shut with a combination of wood glue, Gorilla Glue, and rubber cement.  

 
 

$100:   Button Set + 2 Bookmarks + Sparkle Jar (Small) + Shelf Dedication

If you donate at this tier you will receive the opportunity to dedicate one of our bookshelves to the person or organization of your choice.  Each donor will provide their dedication and we will create a custom plaque just for you.  Each plaque will be affixed to the top of our of our shelves.  Everyone who visits our Library will forever see your contribution and dedication to our cause of improving literacy.  

 

$500: Trailer Dedication

If you donate at this tier your name will be added to our list of donors on the back doors of our trailer!  This can be either your personal name or the name of your company.  This can be text only, or we will create a custom vinyl sticker of your logo (must be provided by you).  This trailer travels with us to all of our events, so everyone will see how wonderful you are!


Risks & Challenges

 

If we fail to raise the money required, we risk the very real possibility of going out of business.  If our vehicles get taken away, the Library cannot be transported to events. If we lose our storage unit, the books risk being damaged while they sit in our Head Librarian's garage.  

All the items being given as reward tiers are hand-made except the donor plaques.  We anticipate a very quick turnaround time to get the items shipped out to donors as our creators currently do not have shows to attend due to the cancellations.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Sharing this fundraiser is a huge help to us!  There are many forums, social media threads, and websites where creators and vendors affected by the COVID-19 shutdowns are banding together to share info and help generate lost revenue.  We are sure we don't know of all of them and we are sure that you know some that we don't!

    • You can also donate directly at our website:  https://carolinamangalibrary.com/donate-funds/

    Stretch Goal 3: $5000: Making it to September

    Since we have 9 more days of the fundraiser, we are going to try and make it to our highest goal ever, $5000!  We've never raised this much money before, so let's give it a shot!

    If we make it to this goal, our Head Librarian will start a Twitch account and start streaming her two panels "Great Graphic Novels You Should Be Reading" and "What the %#@& Did I Just Read?!" on a weekly basis.  These will also be released via Youtube.  

    Funds raised to this level will enable us to stay in business to September 2020 in the event of more event cancellations.

     

    Stretch Goal 1: $3000: Making it to July

    We have to raise another $1000 because we just lost another huge event in May!  If we do this, we will be able to keep going until June!  We actually cannot change our total funding goal on Indiegogo, so we will add this Stretch Goal instead.  

    We will also be extending the campaign an extra 15 days.

     

    Stretch Goal 2: $4000: Making it to August

    Since Indiegogo won't let us end the campaign early, we will have a second stretch goal of $4000.  If we reach that goal, all donors above the $25 tier will receive a Manga Library Pop Socket!   Funds raised to this level will enable us to stay in business to August 2020 in the event of more event cancellations.
story_txt:
What's a Manga Library?  Why Should I Care?
The Carolina Manga Library is a non-profit organization that sets up free libraries at conventions for all attendees to enjoy. They bring over 5000 manga, American graphic novels, webcomics, and novels for fans to enjoy. By setting up a quiet place for people to relax at conventions, the Library seeks to promote literacy through the medium that they love.
The Library was founded in 2013, debuting at Nashicon in Columbia, South Carolina. Since then, the Library has been guests at conventions all over the eastern United States and their collection becomes larger with every passing month, having expanded to all forms of graphic novels. 
This group travels all around the US to set up these libraries to provide free access to graphic novels to underprivileged areas and to foster a life-long love of reading.  They set up at schools, hospitals, conventions, public libraries, and shelters.

What's Going On?
In the wake of the COVID-19 virus pandemic, more and more large gatherings are being forbidden by various cities in the United States.  This has unfortunately shown that many large scale events like conventions are now being closed down for 2020.
Our largest spring event was scheduled to take place March 19-21 in Lancaster, PA.  That event has now been cancelled with less than a week to go.  
This event was supposed to be our largest spring fundraising event.  We usually raise about 20% of our annual budget at this show.  Without that show happening, we will not be able to pay our bills in March, April, or early May.  Our next event isn't scheduled until mid-May.  
 

How Can You Help?
After the massive success of our Trailer GoFundMe in 2019, we did not want to do another GoFundMe where our supporters didn't receive anything other than thanks for their generosity.  
Most of the other vendors/artists who were supposed to attend these cancelled shows have the ability to have online sales to try to generate lost revenue.  As a nonprofit, we do not have that luxury.  Instead, we've decided to utilize Indiegogo so that our supporters can have a tangible piece of our gratitude.
We need to raise $2000 to pay our bills for the months of March, April, and May.  This does not include any salaries, this is strictly to keep the vehicles, storage units, and liability insurance paid for.  Anything raised over the initial $2000 will be put away in case any other conventions cancel on us.
 
What Do I Get?
Below are descriptions of our tiered donation rewards!
$10: Button Set
If you donate at this tier you will receive a complete set of our 2.5 inch buttons.  There are 7 buttons in all featuring various designs of our two mascots, our logo, and our slogan "Reading is Reading is Reading".

$25: Button Set + 2 Bookmarks
If you donate at this tier you will receive our two exclusively designed bookmarks featuring our two mascots, Caro and Lina, at leisure in their own homes.  These designs are ONLY available on our bookmarks!  Each bookmark comes with a colored tassel and star charm, as well as a holographic backing that makes each bookmark 100% unique.  The bookmarks are enclosed in a durable plastic sheath.

 
$50: Button Set + 2 Bookmarks + Sparkle Jar (Small)
If you donate at this tier you will receive a custom-made small Sparkle Jar.  Each donor will be asked their favorite colors and our Head Librarian will create a customized, one-of-a-kind sparkle jar for you to enjoy.  All the bottles are made of durable, nearly-unbreakable plastic and are sealed shut with a combination of wood glue, Gorilla Glue, and rubber cement.  

 
 
$100:   Button Set + 2 Bookmarks + Sparkle Jar (Small) + Shelf Dedication
If you donate at this tier you will receive the opportunity to dedicate one of our bookshelves to the person or organization of your choice.  Each donor will provide their dedication and we will create a custom plaque just for you.  Each plaque will be affixed to the top of our of our shelves.  Everyone who visits our Library will forever see your contribution and dedication to our cause of improving literacy.  

 
$500: Trailer Dedication
If you donate at this tier your name will be added to our list of donors on the back doors of our trailer!  This can be either your personal name or the name of your company.  This can be text only, or we will create a custom vinyl sticker of your logo (must be provided by you).  This trailer travels with us to all of our events, so everyone will see how wonderful you are!

Risks & Challenges


 
If we fail to raise the money required, we risk the very real possibility of going out of business.  If our vehicles get taken away, the Library cannot be transported to events. If we lose our storage unit, the books risk being damaged while they sit in our Head Librarian's garage.  
All the items being given as reward tiers are hand-made except the donor plaques.  We anticipate a very quick turnaround time to get the items shipped out to donors as our creators currently do not have shows to attend due to the cancellations.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing this fundraiser is a huge help to us!  There are many forums, social media threads, and websites where creators and vendors affected by the COVID-19 shutdowns are banding together to share info and help generate lost revenue.  We are sure we don't know of all of them and we are sure that you know some that we don't!
You can also donate directly at our website:  https://carolinamangalibrary.com/donate-funds/

Stretch Goal 3: $5000: Making it to September
Since we have 9 more days of the fundraiser, we are going to try and make it to our highest goal ever, $5000!  We've never raised this much money before, so let's give it a shot!
If we make it to this goal, our Head Librarian will start a Twitch account and start streaming her two panels "Great Graphic Novels You Should Be Reading" and "What the %#@& Did I Just Read?!" on a weekly basis.  These will also be released via Youtube.  
Funds raised to this level will enable us to stay in business to September 2020 in the event of more event cancellations.
 
Stretch Goal 1: $3000: Making it to July
We have to raise another $1000 because we just lost another huge event in May!  If we do this, we will be able to keep going until June!  We actually cannot change our total funding goal on Indiegogo, so we will add this Stretch Goal instead.  
We will also be extending the campaign an extra 15 days.
 
Stretch Goal 2: $4000: Making it to August
Since Indiegogo won't let us end the campaign early, we will have a second stretch goal of $4000.  If we reach that goal, all donors above the $25 tier will receive a Manga Library Pop Socket!   Funds raised to this level will enable us to stay in business to August 2020 in the event of more event cancellations.

story:
My name is Mariah, I am originally from New Jersey, USA. I was given an incredible second chance to escape my troubled life in New Jersey and move to Singapore, so I took it! I feel that the least I can do is give someone else the same second chance that I had, and to give back!   

    As mentioned above, my story starts in New Jersey. When I was eighteen years old I decided to see a doctor about my chronic migraines. Unknown to me, this doctor ran a pill mill (a doctor's office that freely writes prescriptions for heavy narcotics, in order to get a "kick back" from the pharmaceutical companies) and wrote me a prescription for a very powerful, opiate based, painkiller. Before I knew it, I was completely dependent and addicted. After a year or so, the doctor I was seeing began to get nervous after several of his patients were hospitalised, and without pryer notice, refused to see me. Being addicted,young, and not knowing who or where to turn, I began to purchase the prescription illegally of the street. I continued this for about two years. Right around that time, the U.S congress decided to pass a bill limiting the amount of opiate based painkillers that doctors could write prescriptions for. This made them very hard and very expensive to buy on the streets. Like most people addicted to opiates, I was terrified of becoming terribly ill from the withdrawal that is experienced when one stops taking opiates. The only solution my addiction could comprehend, was to use a more powerful, addictive, and cheaper opiate, heroin. It didn't take long for my heroin use to spin out of control. One night, nearly six months ago, I decided that enough was enough and for the next few weeks I relentlessly called drug detox programs in my area. When I finally found a detox program that had room for me, I was very optimistic about my sobriety, but knew that it would be hard for me to stay drug free where it would be so easy for me to relapse. As fate would have it, my mom was visiting from Singapore around the same time I was getting out of detox, so I made the decision to go back to Singapore with her and start over. I know all to well that most people don't have the options that I had, and I am extremely grateful for that. I can't think of a better way to give back to the world then to help the unfortunate people of the world in anyway that I can. I began researching NGO's all around the world, but primarily in Africa. After much research, I contacted a organisation called, GVI. They offer many different programs that one can join. I am most interested in working with the children in the orphanages, teaching them how to speak, read and write in english. Eventually I would like to look into Doctors Without Boarders and other programs through organisations like the Red Cross and the United Nations. Unfortunately, the cost on this program is nearly 5,000USD. When I started my life over, I left everything behind and because of this, I do not have nearly $5,000. I am asking that anyone who ever wanted to help the children of Africa, but cannot either do to scheduling conflicts or other responsibilities, to help me take this adventure and give back to the world for the unbelievable second chance I've been given.

story:
“I say namaste to myself in the middle of the night and I can't sleep because I'm scared and then I feel safe” ~2nd grade student

“Yoga always calms me down”  ~ 3rd grade student 

“And this is why I told you you need to do some yoga, man! Relax yourself. Free your mind. Use your imagination. Take a deep breath. Its all good, brother”  ~ 6th grade student

“Yoga makes me feel relaxed and more smarter… after relaxation I go to science and I finish everything because my mind is clear”  ~5th grade student


Brief Summary

We (Sierra and Laura) are community-minded yoga enthusiasts working towards our Ph.Ds in Applied Developmental Psychology at the University of New Orleans. We believe children of all race, gender, and socioeconomic status deserve equal educational opportunities. Because of this, we have teamed up with a local charter elementary school that serves primarily low income and minority students. They are one of the first in the community to implement yoga into their curriculum.  With the help of their yoga instructor, Chelsea (a 200-hour Registered Yoga Teacher), we are working to empirically assess the benefits of a school-based mindful yoga practice, which have been previously linked to academic success. 

The Impact: Education and Compassion

How do schools create and maintain an environment conducive to learning? 

  • Public schools are closing due to failing academic performance and graduation rates and charter schools are assuming the role of public education in the city. This opens the door to possibility.
  • One way in which schools are attempting to change the learning climate of their classrooms is by incorporating a mindful yoga practice as a required part of the curriculum. 

Through yoga, children are learning:

  • How to control their own thoughts, behaviors, and emotions
  • How to control their breathing
  • To build physical strength and stability
  • Compassion

As evidenced by:

  • Learning to calm down and problem solve instead of reacting aggressively
  • Reducing anxiety 
  • Focusing and sustaining attention on the present task
  • Learning how breathing impacts how they handle athletic events, stressful situations, or dangerous environments
  • Showing empathy for peers

Why is this Important?

It is crucial to empirically study the potential impact school programs are having on students.

  • There is a lack of research investigating the association between yoga and children’s adjustment.
  • The burden of implementing programs that are not empirically valid fall on our students, parents, and teachers.
    • We need to know with confidence how a program is beneficial for children before we have mass implementation. If this trend of bringing yoga to children in schools continues, as it seems to be doing, we need to know how it is impacting youth.

Why is this the Cause?

The discrepancy of access to a good education is alarming.

  • It is a disgrace that as a society we do not yet live in a system with equal opportunity for a good education. 

I challenge you to find one social issue where education and compassion will not help solve the problem.  

  • Through the empirical evaluation of yoga in schools we can speak with confidence about the potential benefits and bring this awareness to the educational community. 

We hope to use the results from this study to advocate for the further implementation of yoga classes in schools. 

What we are Asking for and Why? 

We are asking you to help us show our gratitude to parents, teachers, and students in the form of financial compensation for their time.

  • We need parents, teachers, and students to take time out of their busy lives to be in our study.
  • All funds raised will be put into an account for classroom teachers to use for school supplies that benefit the children in their class.
  •  100% of proceeds will go to benefit the participants.

Your generosity will help offset the financial burden families and teachers face by ensuring that school supplies make it into the classrooms.

    • The overwhelming majority of children who attend this elementary school are below poverty line and some are homeless. 
    • Donating $50 will cover the cost of school supplies for one child.  
  • The money you donate will help ensure that people receive compensation that will not be contingent on grant funding.

To show our appreciation, we will keep you informed about the progress of the study by emailing you a newsletter with information we have acquired from the study (at your request). 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to send donations, you can still help! Please forward the link to anyone and everyone. We are grateful for your help and generosity!

Skeptical about Yoga in the Classroom?

This is why we need to do this study! Recently, engagement in contemplative practice-based interventions has broadened from research with adult populations to school-aged youth. Research thus far suggests that involvement in repeated contemplative practices (e.g., yoga, thai chi, meditation) is related to various neurological, physiological, social, emotional, cognitive, and behavioral benefits in school-aged children, all of which are thought to underlie academic success.

The extant research with youth suggest that involvement in contemplative practices has been associated with higher levels of mindfulness, emotion regulation, attention, executive function, aggression, anxiety, depression, somatisation, and academic achievement. In order to explain the mechanism through which contemplative practices can provide positive benefits, the Mind and Life Education Research Network developed a model linking contemplative practices with their influence on neural substrates, psychological functions, and behavior. 

In this model, contemplative practices are proposed to directly alter psychological functions (i.e., emotion regulation, attention regulation, executive function, self-representation, empathy, and perspective taking), which in turn alter neural substrates, eventually modifying brain structures. 

After several contemplative practices, subsequent alterations in neural activity and psychological functions are expected to change behaviors. Importantly, each physiological function linked with contemplative practice is essential to academic success.

In order to explain the mechanism through which contemplative practices can provide positive benefits, the Mind and Life Education Research Network developed a model linking contemplative practices with their influence on neural substrates, psychological functions, and behavior. 
In this model, contemplative practices are proposed to directly alter psychological functions (i.e., emotion regulation, attention regulation, executive function, self-representation, empathy, and perspective taking), which in turn alter neural substrates, eventually modifying brain structures. 
After several contemplative practices, subsequent alterations in neural activity and psychological functions are expected to change behaviors. Importantly, each physiological function linked with contemplative practice is essential to academic success.

story:
My name is Emily, I have been nominated to Represent the state of Texas at the Congress of Future Medical Leaders. This is a HUGE opportunity for me and I would really like to attend to help further my medical career track. This is actually the 2nd time I have been nominated for a convention/workshop like this. However I did not have the financially support needed to go and I am in the same situation now. This isn't the first time opportunity has knocked and we didn't have enough money to answer. Please consider helping us out. 


As of now, I don't have any perks to give but I am open to ideas, I'm not sure what someone would want out of helping a girl pursue her dreams in academics.
All the money raised goes towards my tuition fee, travel, housing, transportation and meals. I really need to raise $1000. However for the additional 500 dollars, All of this is taken care of by the program.

If we do not reach our basic goal, the money will go into My savings account for College, supplies, tuition fee's etc.


    As a child of divorce, both my parent have taken excellent care of me. However my parents have both struggled financially and neither of them have completed college. I want to be one of the first in my family to complete college. I want to show how I overcame my financially obstacles and conquered my goals. I want to be able to make my parents proud, but most of all I don't want my parents to feel like failures for not having enough money to give me the opportunities I deserve.


    If you are inspired by my story and my campaign, but cannot contribute, that's ok. You can share my story via social media and ask others to help out. Every bit helps!! :)
    Thank you so much for reading. And an even bigger thanks to those who contribute. Lets make it to D.C.!!!!!!

story:
Short Summary

Greetings, friends! My name is Joe Fabian and here's the deal. I'm a student at Circle in the Square Theatre School about to start my final year. I'm essentially asking as much as the tuition is costing simply because what we have is almost all going to have to go to rent and living costs and that in NYC alone can leave one bankrupt. I hate to come and stick my electronic cap in hand to you all but this is just where we are. Any help would be spectacular, it's been a long road and I'd like to make a good end of it. 

What We Need 

I'm asking for $17,000 because this is what they at circle are asking for, this is wonderfully quite smaller of an amount for tuition than other schools so at least that's helpful. I have a single mom putting two kids through college, having lost my father right before my senior year of high-school, as well as living costs being what they were and circumstances being what they are, it's almost financially impossible to do this final year.  
Thanks to Indiegogo's "we won't keep it just because you didn't make it" policy, if we don't make our goal, we'll still use whatever we make to go to a payment plan for Circle. 
If you make the generous choice to donate to my cause, I can't necessarily give you a perk or something based on how much you donate, you'll have my immense gratitude and have invested in hopefully a successful actor's future and I'll remember you helped if that happens. 

The Impact

Circle in the Square Theatre School has given the world of entertainment almost 50 years worth of wonderful alumni actors, such as Kevin Bacon, Idina Menzel and the late Phillip Seymour Hoffman, to name a few. Being a student in it's halls has been a humbling joy and a privilege.  This past year has been utterly life changing and at the end of it, they asked me to continue my journey and finish out the school's program. In the final year for this program, we look more into classical works, further honing a foundation for all sorts of potential works before performing in front of agents and casting directors at the end of the year, hopefully gaining representation and a good chance at working after school, if not being successful as soon as possible after school. 

Risks & Challenges

Being an actor in New York obviously has it's obstacles, being one of thousands of people all looking to "make it big" in the big city. Having a certificate of completion of one of New York's finest acting schools certainly can help possibly bypass a good amount of grief that may come with the occupation. Having learnt a great deal thus far from some of the greatest teachers and professionals the world of theatre has to offer, the continued progress can better help get a leg up on some of the competition. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand if you just aren't able to help out, financially speaking, but if you'd like to assist in different ways you can help spread the word on Facebook or other social media outlets, ask around, any way you can help would be spectacular. 

Thank you so much for reading and possibly donating, I can't tell you how much it means to me that you help out, and I certainly will keep you all updated through Facebook as we go along! :)

Having learnt a great deal thus far from some of the greatest teachers and professionals the world of theatre has to offer, the continued progress can better help get a leg up on some of the competition. 
  Other Ways You Can Help
I completely understand if you just aren't able to help out, financially speaking, but if you'd like to assist in different ways you can help spread the word on Facebook or other social media outlets, ask around, any way you can help would be spectacular. Thank you so much for reading and possibly donating, I can't tell you how much it means to me that you help out, and I certainly will keep you all updated through Facebook as we go along! :)

story:
Hi I am Ezhil Maran Pandian. Currently pursuing my Bachelor of Engineering at MVIT College, Bangalore, India. My main intent of creating a campaign here is to raise funds so that I may help my brother keep our family running and also to continue with my education as my Father has come down with Guillaine Barre Syndrome(GBS).

GBS is a type of Auto Immune Dysfunction where the immune system in our body attacks and damages the nervous system. It more or less short circuits all the nerves that are connected to one’s spinal cord rendering the person paralyzed. In my dad’s case, even his respiratory muscles were severely damaged and hence furthering the timer for recovery.

My dad was diagnosed for GBS on the 19th of December 2013 with Immuno Globulins. The course of the hospitalization was something that we weren’t able to even comprehend. But with the help of relatives and friends we were able to pay up at the hospital and bring my dad back home. He isn’t back to action yet as his hands and his lungs haven’t fully recovered and is on Trachesotemy (a hole in his throat) and oxygen support.

We've already spent about 39 lakh rupees(63850 dollars), completely exhausted all our savings and money lended by benefactors.

All the people who helped us get this far are depleted of money that they can spare leaving my elder brother the sole earner bare the entire burden. I heard about the concept of crowd funding through the internet and decided to try my best to help my elder brother. Depending on the funding that collects here I can both help with the medical expenses and continue my education or simply drop out of college till my dad gets back and use the funds to help my family.

My college Fee is 2500$ for this academic year and anything less or anything more will only aid my dad’s medication and hospital consultations.

If anybody out there has been through the same situation or have any experiences with motivating and activating people with GBS kindly do let me know of effective chest physiotherapy and general physiotherapy that we can perform at home kindly let us know so as to fasten my dad's recovery.

We have come a good long distance since the December of 2013 living a nightmare, everyday. We are finally able to see a distant light at the end of this tunnel. Kindly help us through the “home stretch”.

story:
Support Cycle for Change's Youth Apprentices to attend the  Youth Bike Summit, a three day gathering geared toward youth, bicycles, education, and advocacy. This national conference aims to bring people from different disciplines to explore, network, and learn how bicycling can be a legitimate and safe form of transportation for today's youth. 

Cycles for Change is a non-profit community bike shop in the Frogtown neighborhood of Saint Paul, MN.  Our mission is to be an open, accessible space to educate and empower people to use bicycles as transportation, helping to build a sustainable environment and community. 

Cycles for Change's Youth Apprenticeship program includes sixteen amazing youth ages 15-18 who are gaining extensive skills in bicycle mechanics, learning how a small non-profit business operates, and helping with many other parts of Cycles for Change's operations such as teaching classes and doing outreach.  

The $1,000 will go part of the way towards transportation, food, lodging, and the summit registration fee for our sixteen youth apprentices and two youth programs staff chaperones. 

Thank you for your support.  Our goal is to bring back what we learn at the Youth Bike Summit to our community here in Saint Paul!


Perks: Our amazing artists have created the below perks







Bike Part Art

story:
Hi! 

My name is Madalyn Mason and as most of you know I love animals, specifically Primates. I am currently studying Biology at Ohio University and plan to graduate in the Spring of 2016. I have previously traveled to Costa Rica and volunteered at a Wildlife Sanctuary there. While that was a great experience, I am looking to expand my knowledge and experience in Wildlife Rehabilitation and Primate Conservation. The well established internship, that I have already interviewed and been accepted for, at the Alouatta Sanctuary is the perfect opportunity for me. 

Although it would be nice to be able to save up that much money by May, working at the Roadhouse 4 days a week does not cut it.  With the help of myself, my family and you this will help me get one step closer to achieving my dreams of becoming an Animal Behaviorist. 

The internship will last 3 months, costing $918 per month. A round trip flight is around $580 to Panama City, Panama and from there I will need to take a taxi to another airport to catch a connecting flight to David, Panama costing around $250 round trip. After all of these major expenses, there will still be smaller costs including taxis to the city and supplies for the trip. As much as I would love to reach this goal, I know $4,000 is not a realistic goal. Even if I do not reach this goal, all of the money will still go towards the internship. I will be leaving May 6th, 2015 and returning August 6th, 2015. 

Thank you all so much for your donations!

story: Calvin, one of the great friends I made in Uganda, needs help paying for his last semester of university. Invisible Children, the NGO that was sponsoring him, suddenly ceased operations and left the country last month. Unfortunately, the cost of a semester is too much to bear alone for most, and Calvin is no different. However, here he is, one semester away from graduating with a degree in Computer Science. The cost of his final semester is 1.2 million Ugandan schillings or $521 CAN or $419 US. I want to raise that and a bit of extra money so he can pay his a rent and eat this the semester. Any and all contributions are welcome !

story:
As as Afghan refugee born in Iran, I moved to Afghanistan after the Taliban regime collapsed. I was then able to earn my Master's Degree in Computer Science from the Technical University of Berlin in Germany. From there I moved on to teach as a professor in the Computer Science faculty at the University of Herat in Afghanistan. The opportunities I have had in life areas a result of access to digital literacy and education I’ve been fortunate to have. This has led me to find success and opportunity including giving a TED Talk in New York City and establishing Code to Inspire. Every single girl in our lab will also have an opportunity to access education and digital literacy and they will become ambassadors of peace, freedom, creativity and innovation. That is what Code to Inspire is about.



Code to Inspire Philosophy:

I am a technologist and social media enthusiast. We live in an online global village  where no geographical boundaries prevent people from connecting and communicating.

My goal with Code To Inspire is to spread the message of peace by connecting  women in Afghanistan to technology and the rest of the World. We educate and empower women in Afghanistan with technology by teaching them how to code and once they have the skills sets they need to succeed we help them find employment as  programmers. Our goals are to educate girls and young women in Afghanistan and economically empower them by helping them find employment so they can apply the skills they have learned at Code to Inspire.

Here is a message from our female mentors in Afghanistan to you (make sure subtitles are turned on for this video)



Why Code to Inspire is needed:

We are going to be the first coding centre of women for women by women in Afghanistan. Safety, security, travelling concerns outside of your hometown, family, financial issues and limited job opportunities for women in Afghanistan on the ground are putting them at a competitive disadvantage.

At Code to Inspire we offer a safe and secure place where the girls can learn, communicate and enjoy being in an educational environment. It is free of charge for the students due to the financial situation of families in Afghanistan who normally cannot afford to pay for education. Besides providing the educational, technical and social curriculum we will teach them how to be a good leader, teamwork and increase their self esteem and confidence.

How does our coding centre work?

We cover fifty girls from different educational backgrounds.There are mentors in Afghanistan helping students in the lab. Students are challenged to find a problem inside their community and build a software product as a solution.

What We Need:

We need to raise $20,000. These funds will directly go towards establishing our coding centre in Herat, Afghanistan. Here is what we can cover with your support:


  1. Establish a programming centre in Herat, Afghanistan which covers 50 girls daily.

  2. Provide 20 laptops for the centre.

  3. Provide 2 projectors and one printer, copy, and scan machine.

  4. Purchase equipment for the classrooms i.e ( chairs, desks, stationery)

  5. Provide four expert mentors to teach the girls in our centre and assist them to become programmers.
Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us as an advisory member by helping develop a technical and educational curriculum for our students in Afghanistan.

  • Support us by spreading the word using your social media network and publishing articles about our initiative in Afghanistan.

  • Assist us with networking and building more relationships.

"We are proud to have you as an INSPIRING friend. The generous support

of individuals like you make it possible for the girls in Afghanistan to overcome the challenging barriers. You EMPOWER THEM ONLINE and make them a DIGITAL CITIZEN of the world."

                                                                              Fereshteh Forough - Founder & CEO

story:
Hello!  

Over the last decade I've had the opportunity to learn from hundreds of young minds.  As a leader, I believe I can help build our world into a better place for these young minds to flourish and I am asking for your support to help me do so.


Each preschooler that I have worked with has provided an opportunity to work with their parents and see the importance of a strong child/parent relationship from an early age. I love the idea of working with families in their first moments and have, therefore, started to train to become a postpartum doula, providing support and education for parents from the beginning. Eventually, I would like to provide support for people experiencing the full range of reproductive possibility, from uncomplicated pregnancy to complex reproductive issues.


Here is how I can use your help:

Providing well trained Doula support to individual families is the heart of my work. Engaging in the work involves public advocacy and changes in social norms. I know that in addition to training to be a doula, I need to establish my personal leadership style.  

To this end I will be attending The Thriving Changemaker Summit.  This is a 4 day leadership training that gives diverse changemakers the tools and skills to empower themselves and others to thrive, while making a lasting impact on the issues to which they are committed.  I am a changemaker, and I am committed to being fully present at the summit to further my development.  Doing this will allow me to be grounded in the work I want to do and connected to a network of people working as thriving changemakers.  


Will you support me by contributing to my tuition costs?  I am raising $1500 to cover the cost of the four days.


Thank you for all the ways you've supported me, now and in the past.  I appreciate you taking the time to consider supporting me in this endeavour.


With Gratitude,

Sara Rose Rachlin

You can learn more about what a doula does here: What Is a Doula?

story:
For the last six years, TDChristian High School has sent a team of students to the Dominican Republic. Their mission? To learn to serve. In February 2015 I will be a part of the next team to serve in the Dominican.

Although each trip is different, during our time in the Dominican, our team will most likely have opportunities to learn for service in the following ways: we will teach English in Christian schools, visit with children at a government run orphanage, tutor and lead crafts and activities in a remote village (Cercadillo), and be involved in construction projects. (In the past, teams have built classrooms, fixed churches and built houses for Christian school teachers.)


During our time, we hope to step out of our comfort zone to meet and appreciate people from a culture that is very different from ours, be stretched in our ability to serve God and others in practical ways, grow in faith, and develop our leadership and team skills.


In class beforehand, we will be learning about the culture and social norms of the Dominican. We will be studying Spanish intensively so that we can interact with our Dominican partners on a more personal level.



As with many international opportunities, I need your support. While our families and TDChristian are supporting us financially, we each need to raise another $4000 towards the trip. There are also expenses over and above the money individuals are responsible to raise. Therefore, any money I raise beyond my goal will be used toward these expenses. In addition to financial support, I am requesting prayer support both in preparation for the trip as well as during the trip itself. Please prayerfully consider how you may be able to support me and the team in this wonderful opportunity for service in the Dominican Republic.

The 2014 team wrote a blog to share their experiences. Click here to see the 2014 team's blog.

story:
Short Summary

See that little girl in the picture?  That's Hanh (pronounced 'hi').  Isn't she a beauty?  Earlier this year, my family and I got the chance to travel to Hanoi, Vietnam to teach and play with Hanh, as well as a beautiful bunch of toddlers at a local orphanage.  Since then, my mother, Amy, has begun plans on building a kindergarten for the children.  Just recently, she received an offer to visit the orphanage in October to reunite with the kids, see the work that has been done on the kindergarten, and love on everyone there.  The only problem: not enough money to buy a plane ticket.  I have created this campaign to secretly raise money for her to go to Vietnam, and surprise her with a plane ticket.  My mother loves these babies and toddlers as if they were her own, and I would really love to get her to Vietnam, so she can create stories for the children.

What We Need & What You Get

So, basically, the overall cost of the trip would be close to $2,000.  I would love to be able to raise this much money, no matter how hard the task, by October 13 or 14.  By donating, your money would go to the plane ticket cost to get my mother to the orphanage in Vietnam so she can do some work at the kindergarten and love on the kids there.

    The Impact

    Sending my mother to Vietnam would be the surprise of a lifetime.  She has it deeply embedded in her heart to love these orphans and give them a story.  She is so dedicated to them, and I want her to have every chance she can get to go see them.  

      Risks & Challenges

      It is true that raising $2,000 in close to 30 days is going to be tough.  Insanely tough.  But, I know it isn't impossible.  With a little bit of trust and faith in God, I know that something incredible is going to happen.  

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If donating isn't your thing, feel free to shout into the void about this campaign.  Tell others!  Help me get other people excited for these orphans!  With your help, I know I will be able to put a smile on my mother's face, as well as all those kids in the orphanage.

story:
For the last fifteen years, PARC has corresponded with and mailed a directory of resources to prisoners, their friends, and family members. We are often the first point of contact for people to connect with prisoners' rights organizations, community organizations, prison literature and arts projects, family and visiting resources, health care and legal resources, parole and pre-release resources, and the prison abolition movement.

About the PARC Directory

First published in 2002, the PARC Directory is a 24 page resource packet (read our 2014 edition) printed on newsprint that is mailed upon request to over 5000 prisoners a year. Moreover, according to our surveys, each prisoner shares their directory with between 5 to 10 additional prisoners, resulting in between 25,000 and 50,000 having access to the information in the directory.  Below is some of the feedback we have gotten from prisoners about the directory:

Needed Support

Each directory that PARC sends individually costs $1.50 ($0.75 in printing, $0.70 in stamps, and $0.05 in envelopes) which annually costs $7,500 to print and mail the 5,000 requested directories.

PARC currently receives $2,500 in grants annually from such wonderful organizations as the RESIST Foundation, The People's Life Fund, van Löben Sels/RembeRock, and the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence and $2,000 in individual member donations annually to help fund our resource directory. For 2015, we are seeking $3,000 in community funding as part of this campaign to print and mail our 2015 directory. 

Ever since the ACLU stopped sending their Prisoners's Assistance Directory directly to prisoners, PARC is the only organization to freely provide information to tens of thousands of prisoners incarcerated across the nation. 

About PARC

The Prison Activist Resource Center (read our website) is an all volunteer prison abolitionist group based in Oakland, California committed to exposing and challenging the institutionalized racism, sexism, ableism, heterosexism, and classism of the Prison Industrial Complex. PARC works in coalition with other prison activist organizations such as the Prisoner Hunger Strike Solidarity coalition, California Prison Focus, and the National Lawyers Guild San Francisco chapter.

PARC meets regularly to answer letters from prisoners, update the information in our directory, organize educational events in the SF Bay Area, and send out copies of the directory to prisoners and their families. See a picture of some of members mailing directories to prisoners above.

Thank you for considering our request for funding. 

Yours for the revolution,
Prison Activist Resource Center

We are often the first point of contact for people to connect with prisoners' rights organizations, community organizations, prison literature and arts projects, family and visiting resources, health care and legal resources, parole and pre-release resources, and the prison abolition movement.
About the PARC Directory
First published in 2002, the PARC Directory is a 24 page resource packet (read our 2014 edition) printed on newsprint that is mailed upon request to over 5000 prisoners a year. Moreover, according to our surveys, each prisoner shares their directory with between 5 to 10 additional prisoners, resulting in between 25,000 and 50,000 having access to the information in the directory.  Below is some of the feedback we have gotten from prisoners about the directory:




Needed Support
Each directory that PARC sends individually costs $1.50 ($0.75 in printing, $0.70 in stamps, and $0.05 in envelopes) which annually costs $7,500 to print and mail the 5,000 requested directories.
PARC currently receives $2,500 in grants annually from such wonderful organizations as the RESIST Foundation, The People's Life Fund, van Löben Sels/RembeRock, and the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence and $2,000 in individual member donations annually to help fund our resource directory. For 2015, we are seeking $3,000 in community funding as part of this campaign to print and mail our 2015 directory. 
Ever since the ACLU stopped sending their Prisoners's Assistance Directory directly to prisoners, PARC is the only organization to freely provide information to tens of thousands of prisoners incarcerated across the nation. 
About PARC
The Prison Activist Resource Center (read our website) is an all volunteer prison abolitionist group based in Oakland, California committed to exposing and challenging the institutionalized racism, sexism, ableism, heterosexism, and classism of the Prison Industrial Complex. PARC works in coalition with other prison activist organizations such as the Prisoner Hunger Strike Solidarity coalition, California Prison Focus, and the National Lawyers Guild San Francisco chapter.
PARC meets regularly to answer letters from prisoners, update the information in our directory, organize educational events in the SF Bay Area, and send out copies of the directory to prisoners and their families. See a picture of some of members mailing directories to prisoners above.Thank you for considering our request for funding. Yours for the revolution,Prison Activist Resource Center

story:
Randolph's Front Porch - The Heart of Our School

The steps and boards of our porch welcome children and families each morning. The benches and railings gather us together each afternoon. Songs are sung here, field trips begun here. Our front porch is at the heart of our school--and it is in desperate need of repair!

  • Our front porch is well over 100 years old (we think it was built around 1876!). 
  • It needs new support posts and new concrete footings, the columns need to be rebuilt, damaged floorboards need to be replaced, and the gutter needs to be resealed. 
  • Your contribution will help pay for these repairs.

Help us strengthen and repair our beautiful front porch and you will help welcome children and families into Randolph School for decades to come!  

What We Need (& What You Get In Return)

How exactly is this going to work?

  • We need $11,900 to repair our front porch. It's a big job because the supports and concrete footings that hold the porch up need to be replaced, along with many of the floor boards and columns. 
  • We have a very reasonable quote from a local construction firm that is able to do both the engineering and construction work.
  • After donating, you will receive: a warm and fuzzy feeling and... a Thank You gift! Randolph School car magnets, t-shirts, water bottles, cookbooks, and maple-sugaring kits are our way of saying "thanks for your support!"  
  • 100% of the money raised through this campaign will go towards repair of the front porch. If we don't meet our goal, we'll take out a loan for the balance of the costs.

We Wouldn't Ask If We Didn't Need Your Help

Randolph School gives preschool and elementary-aged children a fun, creative, and safe environment where they learn to think, ask questions, solve problems, and work together. For 50 years we have focused on each child's individual development, nurturing his or her curiosity and fostering respect and responsibility. 

Our #1 goal is to provide high quality, progressive education to a diverse community of children. We get the bulk of our income from tuition and we use almost all of that money to pay our phenomenal teachers and to subsidize tuition based on financial need. At the end of the day, there isn't much left to cover building expenses--and a $11,900 porch repair is only possible with your help.      

  • We must repair our front porch to keep our building--and ultimately our children--safe.
  • Every dollar you give today for the porch will protect a dollar tomorrow for teacher salaries and tuition subsidies.

Risks & Challenges

Indiegogo (rightly) suggests we share the risks and challenges of this campaign with you. The main risk--not doing the repair--is not in the cards, since we cannot have an unsafe porch. We are committed to taking out a loan if need be, which will make it that much more difficult to meet the budgetary challenges of providing phenomenal progressive education to our diverse community.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word--let grandparents, aunts, uncles, former classmates, friends, bosses, and anyone else you can think of know about this campaign.
  • Copy the link for our porch campaign and email it to your contacts, or share the campaign on Facebook or other social media using the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much!

Acknowledgements

The soundtrack for the video was made by our 9 and 10 year olds, who interviewed students and teachers about what the porch means to them, edited by their teacher, Mike Ferrara.

If you would prefer to give the old fashioned way, you can send a check to: Randolph School, 2467 Route 9D, Wappingers Falls, NY 12590.

story:
AP Textbooks Campaign

Hi! I'm Ms. Sweeney and the photo above is my AP Statistics class at KIPP DuBois Collegiate Academy in West Philadelphia. This is the first year we are offering AP Statistics at our school. AP, or Advanced Placement, courses allow students to take an AP exam at the end of the year. Students who do well on the exam can receive college credit. Unfortunately, the current budget in the District of Philadelphia has not allowed us to purchase AP text books. We are raising money to purchase a class set of textbooks to help us prepare for the AP exam in May! 

What We Need 

  • The Practice of Statistics by Starnes, Tabor, Yates, and Moore
  • 13 copies at $142.99 each
  • You will receive a KIPP DuBois Collegiate Academy lanyard for every donation of $50 or more! 
  • Any additional funding will be used to purchase supplementary resources for AP Exam Preparation.
  • If we do not reach our goal, we will still purchase as many textbooks as possible with the funding we do receive. 

The Impact

These are the statistics:

80% of black graduates whose SAT scores suggest they should have taken an AP course never did. (Source: Insider Higher Ed)

Only 17% of AP test takers are coming from low-income communities. (Source: Education Week)

These discouraging facts are a result of a lack of school funding in black and low-income communities. Students who are more than capable of excelling on an AP level exam are not given the opportunity. At KIPP, our goal is to send students to and through college. This means offering college level courses in order to prepare them.

However, it is essential that students have a textbook to work from. Each night, readings and exercises are assigned as homework, and making copies from the few texts we do have has become a messy and unreliable task. I believe that my students are entitled to the same textbooks as their peers in better resourced communities. 

A class set of AP textbooks will impact my current class of AP students but will also provide resources for every class that comes after them. Your contribution will give many students the opportunity they deserve.

    Other Ways You Can Help!

    • Spread the word! Share this Indiegogo link on Facebook, Twitter, with co-workers, etc!
    • Vote FOR increasing funding for our students in the District of Philadelphia. 
    Thank you!

story:
PROJET ANNULE


CANCELED PROJECT



A propos de mon projet

                                                                                       (Scroll down for English )

  • Qui suis-je ?

Je m'appelle Lucie THOMAS et j'ai 19 ans. J'aime faire de l'escalade et m'essaye à la danse. Étudiante en première année de psychomotricité, j'apprends le développement biologique, psychologique et relationnel de la personne humaine, ainsi que ses troubles.

Comprendre l'autre me plaît. C'est aussi ce qui motive mon envie de découvrir le monde. Lire les lignes d'un visage, écouter l'histoire d'étrangers, apprendre d'une autre culture, parcourir des chemins inconnus, oser, créer, grandir...
L'été dernier, j'ai réalisé un premier voyage en solitaire, grâce à l'association Zellidja, à la recherche de l'espoir au travers des initiatives citoyennes en Grèce. Cette expérience m'a beaucoup enrichie et m'a donné l'envie de réitérer.
Cette année, je souhaite réaliser un rêve en partant découvrir l'enfance chez les Tau't Batu aux Philippines.

  • Mon projet

                     -Les rêves existent pour nous donner la force et le désir d'oser-

Les peuples de la forêt me fascinent depuis toujours. Cette osmose entre l'homme et son environnement m'intéresse. Comment peut-on vivre avec elle, sans la détruire ? Cette interrogation personnelle trouve écho dans la société actuelle. En parallèle de cette dernière, certains hommes continuent de vivre selon des préceptes ancestraux. C'est le cas des Tau't Batu. Leur mode de vie suit le rythme des saisons. Vivant au milieu de la nature, ils semblent évoluer en harmonie avec elle. Est-ce vrai ? En partageant le quotidien des Tau't Batu, j'aimerais m'imprégner de leur façon de vivre et de penser. Ces dernières se transmettent de générations en générations à  travers l'éducation. Pour moi, ce terme recouvre, la transmission des savoirs ainsi que la manière d'élever un enfant. C'est pourquoi, j'ai choisi de monter un projet sur l'enfance chez les Tau't Batu.

En effet, si personne ne choisit où il naît, cela fait pourtant de nous qui l'on est.

L'enfance porte une magie particulière, celle de l'émergence et de la construction d'un nouvel être humain. Fragile, le petit d'homme nécessite de l'attention et des soins.Ces derniers varient en fonction du milieu dans lequel il évolue.Comment grandissent les enfants des rochers ?  Quel place occupe les enfants au sein de la communauté ? Comment apprennent-ils à vivre dans la forêt ? Par quels biais se transmet le mode de vie et de pensée des Tau't Batu ? Dans quel mesure l'environnement influence-t-il l'enfance ?...

De cette recherche, je souhaite créer et publier (sur internet notamment), un reportage liant photos et écrits. Il comprendra mon journal de route, mon carnet d'étude et le compte-rendu de mon budget. Cet ouvrage sera aussi imprimé en quelques exemplaires.


Ce projet me tient vraiment à cœur car il est personnel et fait le lien entre tout ce que j'aime : mes études, la nature, l'écriture, la photo, mon envie de découvrir l'Autre, divers modes de vies et cultures.Je veux m'y investir pleinement grâce à vous. Vous pouvez m'aider à réaliser mon rêve !


Concrètement ça donne quoi ?...

Pour rencontrer les Tau't Batu, je souhaite entreprendre un voyage de 2 mois afin de me rendre dans les hautes terres de la province de Rizal au sud de l'île Palawan.

Pour ce faire, je pars de Paris. Direction : Manille.
A Manille, je reprends l'avion pour Puerto Princesa. Ce vol dure environ 1 heure.
A partir de Puerto Princesa, je prends un bus jusqu'à Ransang. Je passe la nuit dans cette ville avant de continuer vers les terres des Tau' Batu accompagnée d'un guide.


Ce voyage s'effectue sur plusieurs jours.
La bas, je souhaite vivre au sein de la tribu pendant environ 1 mois et demi. Cependant, il me semble nécessaire de ne pas être un poids pour la communauté mais aussi de minimiser mon impact d'un point de vue écologique et culturel.

Pour revenir, je recommence le même périple dans le sens inverse.

Pour mener à bien ce voyage, je recherche des contacts (associations, anthropologues, photographes, amis d'amis...) ayant déjà été sur les lieux ou y habitant. Je suis sur plusieurs pistes.


Comment m'aider et comment puis-je vous le rendre ?

Vous pouvez participer en m'aidant  financièrement pour que ce rêve advienne.

  • A quoi va servir le financement ? 

L'argent récolté par vos dons sera une aide précieuse dans l'aboutissement de ce projet. Par ailleurs, une bourse de l'association Zellidja et de l'Université Pierre et Marie Curie (UPMC) le complétera.

Crownfunding : 600 euros
Bourse Zellidja : 700 euros
Bourse de l'UPMC : 500 euros
Apport personnel : 350 euros

TOTAL : 2150 euros

  • Mon budget prévisionnel 

billets d'avions (A/R) : 689 euros
déplacement sur place : 200 euros
hébergement et nourriture : 500 euros
frais d'impression : 200 euros
divers : 150 euros
visa + taxes d'aéroport : 161 euros
frais médicaux : 250 euros

TOTAL : 2150 euros

J'ai réservé un billet d'avion Paris/Manille pour 689 euros.
Sur place, je vais être amenée à me déplacer en bus et en avion. Après plusieurs discussions avec des gens partis là-bas, un budget de 200 euros convient.
Je compte un budget de 500 euros pour la restauration et l'hébergement. Ce dernier est difficile à prévoir car il dépend du temps que je passe chez les Tau't Batu et des contre-parties qu'ils peuvent me demander.
RESTAURATION : Selon le Routard, le coût de la restauration bon marché varie de 1.5 à 5 euros par repas. Somme à laquelle, il faut rajouter l'eau en bouteille, car boire l'eau du robinet est fortement déconseillé.
HEBERGEMENT : Selon le Routard, les nuits bon marché vont de 6 à 10 euros.
500 euros correspondent environ à 10nuits et 80 repas.
A mon retour, je vais publier mon rendu sur internet mais je vais aussi l'imprimer en plusieurs exemplaires.
Les frais médicaux comprennent le traitement anti-paludisme et les vaccins nécessaires pour un voyage aux Philippines.


Si je ne parviens pas à récolter autant d'argent que souhaité, eh bien : je le chercherai ailleurs (babysiting, intérim, brocante...)

  • Et en échange ?

Pour un euro ou plus, vous recevrez un grand merci.
Pour cinq euros ou plus, votre nom sera inscrit dans les remerciements de mon reportage.
Pour dix euros ou plus, vous recevrez une photo imprimé de mon voyage.
Pour trente euros ou plus, vous recevrez une carte postale des philippines.
Pour cinquante euros ou plus, vous serez invité à l'expo photo.
Pour cent euros, vous recevrez un petit souvenir en provenance des philippines. 


D'autres façons d'aider

Il n'y a pas que l'argent qui compte. Soutenir quelqu'un c'est plus que ça.
Alors, participez à ce projet en le partageant, en en parlant autour de vous, en me faisant bénéficier de contacts et d'informations que vous pouvez avoir. 

Merci à tous pour le soutien et le partage.
Et rappelez-vous : "La vie est un long champ à cultiver. Voyager, c'est y semer la diversité de la Terre. Voyager, c'est l'embellir des couleurs du monde." (L. Lesven)



About my project

  • Who am I ?

My name's Lucie THOMAS and I'm 19. I like to do rock climbing and I'm training myself to dance. As a student in psychomotricity, I'm learning the biological, psychological and social developement of a human person as well as his troubles.
I like to understand the others. It gives me the willingness to discover the world. To read the words on a face, to hear stories of strangers, to learn from another culture, to walk on unknown ways, to dare, to create, to grow up are my main goals.
Last summer, I made a first solo trip. With the help of the association Zellidja, I went to Greece to discover citizens initiatives. This experience gave me so much satisfaction that I would like to try again.
This year, I would like to achieve a dream by discovering the childhood in the Tau't Batu community in the Philippines.


  • My project

                            - Dreams provide strenghth and eargerness to dare-

As far asI can remember, I've been fascinated by people living in forest. This osmosis between man and environment interests me very much. How can we live with it, without destroying it ? This personal interrogation is finding an echo in the actual society. In parallel from this last one, some people sucessfully maintain a traditional way of life. This is the case of the Tau't Batu. Their way of life follows the rhythm of seasons. Living in the middle of the nature, they seems to evolve in harmony with it. Is it the reality ?
By sharing the everyday life of the Tau't Batu, I would like to apprehend their way of living and thinking. The latter are transmitted from generation to generation by the education. For me, this term is speaking about the way to transmit knowledge and the way to raise a child.
That's why, I decided to make a project about childhood in Tau't Batu tribes.

In fact, even if nobody chooses where to be born, our environment makes us who we are.

Childhood carries a particular magic: the emergence and construction of a new human. Due to his frailty, the child needs attention and careness. This last one depends on the place you live in. How are living the children from the rocks ? Which place do they occupy in the community ? How do they learn to live in the forest? How is transmitted  the mode of life and thought of the Tau't Batu ?To what extent the environment do they influence? ... 

From this research, I would like to create and edit (on the Internet in particular) a reportage mixing writing and photography. It will include my road diary, my reportage and my budget. I will also print some copies.


I'm thrilled about this project because it's personal and it is linked with all the things that I like : my studies, nature, people, writing, other ways of living and cultures. I want to dedicate myself to this project thanks to you. You can help me to fulfill my dream !


And concretely ?

To meet the Tau't Batu, I want to make a trip of 2 months to go in the uplands of Rizal in the south of Palawan.


To do it, I leave Paris. Direction : Manila.
Over there, I take another plane to Puerto Princesa. This flight takes approximately one hour. From Puerto Princesa, I take a bus to Ransang. Then, I pass the night in the town before to continue to the Tau't Batu lands with a guide.
This trip last some days.
Over there, I would like to live in the community during approximately one month and a half. However, it seems necessary not to be a burden to the community but also to minimize my impact ecologically and culturally.

To come back, I'll make the same trip in the other way.

To realise my project, I'm looking for contacts in Manila, Puerto Princesa, and Ransang ( associations, anthropologist, photographs, friend of friends...). I'm following several tracks.


How can you help me and how can I give it back to you ?


You can help me financially to make this dream happen.

  • What will the funding be used ?

The money raised from donations will be a valuable aid in the completion of this project. In addition, a scholarship from my university and another one from the association Zellidja will complete it.

Crownfunding : 600 euros
Zellidja : 700 euros
University scholarship : 500 euros
Personnal money : 350 euros

TOTAL : 2150 euros


  • My previsional budget

Airline tickets : 689 euros
Movements in Philippines : 200 euros
Accomodation and food : 500 euros
Printing costs : 200 euros
Other : 150 euros
Visa + Airport taxes : 161 euros
Medical costs (anti-palu + vaccines) : 250 euros

TOTAL : 2150 euros

If I do not achieve to receive enough money that i wish... I will find another way  like babysitting, work in interim...


  • What will you receive in exchange ?

For 1 euro or more, you will receive a big "Thank you"
For 5 euros or more, your name will be write in the thanks of my reportage.
For 10 euros or more, you will receive a photo printed of my trip.
For 30 euros or more, you will receive a postcard from Philippines.
For 50 euros or more, you will be prompted at the photo's exhibition.
For 100 euros or more, you will receive a memory from the Philippines.


Other way to help ?

Money is not the only thing which count. To support somebody is more than that.
So, you can participate to this project by sharing, talking around you, and, giving me informations and contacts that you could have. 


Thanks to all of you for support and sharing
