Vous pouvez m'aider à réaliser mon rêve !Concrètement ça donne quoi ?...Pour rencontrer les Tau't Batu, je souhaite entreprendre un voyage de 2 mois afin de me rendre dans les hautes terres de la province de Rizal au sud de l'île Palawan.Pour ce faire, je pars de Paris. Direction : Manille.A Manille, je reprends l'avion pour Puerto Princesa. Ce vol dure environ 1 heure. A partir de Puerto Princesa, je prends un bus jusqu'à Ransang. Je passe la nuit dans cette ville avant de continuer vers les terres des Tau' Batu accompagnée d'un guide.Ce voyage s'effectue sur plusieurs jours. La bas, je souhaite vivre au sein de la tribu pendant environ 1 mois et demi. Cependant, il me semble nécessaire de ne pas être un poids pour la communauté mais aussi de minimiser mon impact d'un point de vue écologique et culturel. Pour revenir, je recommence le même périple dans le sens inverse.Pour mener à bien ce voyage, je recherche des contacts (associations, anthropologues, photographes, amis d'amis...) ayant déjà été sur les lieux ou y habitant. Je suis sur plusieurs pistes.Comment m'aider et comment puis-je vous le rendre ?Vous pouvez participer en m'aidant  financièrement pour que ce rêve advienne.A quoi va servir le financement ? L'argent récolté par vos dons sera une aide précieuse dans l'aboutissement de ce projet. Par ailleurs, une bourse de l'association Zellidja et de l'Université Pierre et Marie Curie (UPMC) le complétera.Crownfunding : 600 euros Bourse Zellidja : 700 euros Bourse de l'UPMC : 500 eurosApport personnel : 350 eurosTOTAL : 2150 eurosMon budget prévisionnel billets d'avions (A/R) : 689 eurosdéplacement sur place : 200 euroshébergement et nourriture : 500 eurosfrais d'impression : 200 eurosdivers : 150 eurosvisa + taxes d'aéroport : 161 eurosfrais médicaux : 250 eurosTOTAL : 2150 eurosJ'ai réservé un billet d'avion Paris/Manille pour 689 euros.Sur place, je vais être amenée à me déplacer en bus et en avion. Après plusieurs discussions avec des gens partis là-bas, un budget de 200 euros convient.Je compte un budget de 500 euros pour la restauration et l'hébergement. Ce dernier est difficile à prévoir car il dépend du temps que je passe chez les Tau't Batu et des contre-parties qu'ils peuvent me demander.RESTAURATION : Selon le Routard, le coût de la restauration bon marché varie de 1.5 à 5 euros par repas. Somme à laquelle, il faut rajouter l'eau en bouteille, car boire l'eau du robinet est fortement déconseillé.HEBERGEMENT : Selon le Routard, les nuits bon marché vont de 6 à 10 euros.500 euros correspondent environ à 10nuits et 80 repas.A mon retour, je vais publier mon rendu sur internet mais je vais aussi l'imprimer en plusieurs exemplaires.Les frais médicaux comprennent le traitement anti-paludisme et les vaccins nécessaires pour un voyage aux Philippines.Si je ne parviens 
pas à récolter autant d'argent que souhaité, eh bien : je le chercherai 
ailleurs (babysiting, intérim, brocante...)Et en échange ? Pour un euro ou plus, vous recevrez un grand merci.Pour cinq euros ou plus, votre nom sera inscrit dans les remerciements de mon reportage.Pour dix euros ou plus, vous recevrez une photo imprimé de mon voyage.Pour trente euros ou plus, vous recevrez une carte postale des philippines.Pour cinquante euros ou plus, vous serez invité à l'expo photo.Pour cent euros, vous recevrez un petit souvenir en provenance des philippines. D'autres façons d'aiderIl n'y a pas que l'argent qui compte. Soutenir quelqu'un c'est plus que ça. Alors, participez à ce projet en le partageant, en en parlant autour de vous, en me faisant bénéficier de contacts et d'informations que vous pouvez avoir. Merci à tous pour le soutien et le partage. Et rappelez-vous : "La vie est un long champ à cultiver. Voyager, c'est y
 semer la diversité de la Terre. Voyager, c'est l'embellir des couleurs 
du monde." (L. Lesven)About my projectWho am I ?My name's Lucie THOMAS and I'm 19. I like to do rock climbing and I'm training myself to dance. As a student in psychomotricity, I'm learning the biological, psychological and social developement of a human person as well as his troubles.I like to understand the others. It gives me the willingness to discover the world. To read the words on a face, to hear stories of strangers, to learn from another culture, to walk on unknown ways, to dare, to create, to grow up are my main goals. Last summer, I made a first solo trip. With the help of the association Zellidja, I went to Greece to discover citizens initiatives. This experience gave me so much satisfaction that I would like to try again. This year, I would like to achieve a dream by discovering the childhood in the Tau't Batu community in the Philippines. My project                            - Dreams provide strenghth and eargerness to dare-As far asI can remember, I've been fascinated by people living in forest. This osmosis between man and environment interests me very much. How can we live with it, without destroying it ? This personal interrogation is finding an echo in the actual society. In parallel from this last one, some people sucessfully maintain a traditional way of life. This is the case of the Tau't Batu. Their way of life follows the rhythm of seasons. Living in the middle of the nature, they seems to evolve in harmony with it. Is it the reality ? By sharing the everyday life of the Tau't Batu, I would like to apprehend their way of living and thinking. The latter are transmitted from generation to generation by the education. For me, this term is speaking about the way to transmit knowledge and the way to raise a child. That's why, I decided to make a project about childhood in Tau't Batu tribes.In fact, even if nobody chooses where to be born, our environment makes us who we are.Childhood carries a particular magic: the emergence and construction of a new human. Due to his frailty, the child needs attention and careness. This last one depends on the place you live in. How are living the children from the rocks ? Which place do they occupy in the community ? How do they learn to live in the forest? How is transmitted  the mode of life and thought of the Tau't Batu ?To what extent the environment do they influence? ... From this research, I would like to create and edit (on the Internet in particular) a reportage mixing writing and photography. It will include my road diary, my reportage and my budget. I will also print some copies.I'm thrilled about this project because it's personal and it is linked with all the things that I like : my studies, nature, people, writing, other ways of living and cultures. I want to dedicate myself to this project thanks to you. You can help me to fulfill my dream ! And concretely ? To meet the Tau't Batu, I want to make a trip of 2 months to go in the uplands of Rizal in the south of Palawan.To do it, I leave Paris. Direction : Manila.Over there, I take another plane to Puerto Princesa. This flight takes approximately one hour. From Puerto Princesa, I take a bus to Ransang. Then, I pass the night in the town before to continue to the Tau't Batu lands with a guide.This trip last some days.Over there, I would like to live in the community during approximately one month and a half. However, it seems necessary not to be a burden to the community but also to minimize my impact ecologically and culturally.To come back, I'll make the same trip in the other way. To realise my project, I'm looking for contacts in Manila, Puerto Princesa, and Ransang ( associations, anthropologist, photographs, friend of friends...). I'm following several tracks.How can you help me and how can I give it back to you ? You can help me financially to make this dream happen. What will the funding be used ? The money raised from donations will be a valuable aid in the completion of this project. In addition, a scholarship from my university and another one from the association Zellidja will complete it. Crownfunding : 600 eurosZellidja : 700 eurosUniversity scholarship : 500 eurosPersonnal money : 350 eurosTOTAL : 2150 eurosMy previsional budgetAirline tickets : 689 eurosMovements in Philippines : 200 eurosAccomodation and food : 500 eurosPrinting costs : 200 eurosOther : 150 eurosVisa + Airport taxes : 161 eurosMedical costs (anti-palu + vaccines) : 250 eurosTOTAL : 2150 eurosIf I do not achieve to receive enough money that i wish... I will find another way  like babysitting, work in interim...What will you receive in exchange ? For 1 euro or more, you will receive a big "Thank you"For 5 euros or more, your name will be write in the thanks of my reportage. For 10 euros or more, you will receive a photo printed of my trip.For 30 euros or more, you will receive a postcard from Philippines.For 50 euros or more, you will be prompted at the photo's exhibition.For 100 euros or more, you will receive a memory from the Philippines.Other way to help ? Money is not the only thing which count. To support somebody is more than that. So, you can participate to this project by sharing, talking around you, and, giving me informations and contacts that you could have. Thanks to all of you for support and sharing

story:
“’…in everything I did, I showed you that by this kind of hard work we must help the weak, remembering the words the Lord Jesus himself said: 'It is more blessed to give than to receive.'"

-Acts 20:35

May 21, 2014 will be the day I set out on my first mission trip with Christian Center School’s High School Spanish class. As the verse above states, our class did not want to stand around idly watching. So, we decided to take action and work with La Fortuna Orphanage, also known as Hogarcito San Bosco de la Fortuna in Costa Rica, with the struggling families and orphans. 

•My name is John and I am currently enrolled in Christian Center School as a Junior in High School. I have not had much experience with mission trips…actually, this is my first mission trip. 

•As my Spanish Teacher asked us what our biggest goal of the year was, one of the students suggested a mission trip and immediately the class went into an uproar for this great idea. After countless hours of praying and seeking God’s wisdom, we decided to go to Costa Rica and help out the La Fortuna Orphanage with many small and large tasks such as, painting, hanging out with the kids, teaching the children about the wonders of life, help restore any part of the main building and many other things.

•Not only am I passionate about helping others, but especially those in need. As I continue to live out my life, Acts 20:35 will always comfort me knowing that giving to those in need is far greater than becoming greedy and keeping everything to ourselves. 

For this trip, each student needs over $1,300.00 and we are in the final stretch of our journey to make it to Costa Rica.

That is where all you come in! I’d love to have any supporters to help me with my desire to help serve the Lord. As shown in the perks list…

•Support this Mission with $50 and you will receive fresh Costa Rican coffee!

•Donate $100 to this cause and you will receive a set of pictures and videos from our trip! Plus, Café Britt or Dota Coffee.

•Give $250 to this Mission and you will receive a hand written thank you cards from the kids in La Fortuna Orphanage in Costa Rica. Plus, Café Britt or Dota Coffee and pictures from our trip. 

How cool is that?? Not only will you be able to support me, but you'll be supporting the children in the orphanage! Seeing the smile on each of these kids is breath-taking and can be a once in a life time opportunity. 

Donations of $40, $20, $10 or even $500 will bless me beyond belief. Anything to help will be more than amazing! Especially seeing the glow on each of the Costa Rican children as we come and be with them.

Thank you in advance for supporting me and helping me gain this goal and especially in Jesus for instilling this desire to serve Him. 

With the love of Jesus Christ,

John A.

story:
Realms of Inquiry is an experience based private school that's been around since 1972. Part of our curriculum is international trips, and every year our students go somewhere out of country. Our goal is to give our students experience and education they will need for real life. During these trips we volunteer our time and money to help causes in need. This could be anything from orphans to sea turtles, and generally helping with community building.

The Mariposa

La Mariposa is a community building organization that has a strong focus on helping more rural villages build sustainable tourism. They have quite a few projects for volunteers to participate in. They also help small, local businesses to get off the ground, making sure not to take away job opportunities, as well as helping small children and providing Spanish lessons and home stays for the students. We will be staying with this organization for one week, and all of the money donated will go directly to them so they can continue to provide for their community.

New Project: Children with Disabilities

Working with children with disabilities in San Juan de la Concepcion, La Mariposa is starting a new project as of December 2013 working with Los Pipitos in San Juan de la Concepcion. Los Pipitos is a national organisation that works with families and children with disabilities around the country. Alongside local staff and volunteers we will provide a 6 week program of activities for children with disabilities, including music, crafts, games, and sports.

A few years ago the special education school run by Los Pipitos in San Juan de la Concepcion was robbed of everything. Prior to last week they only had chairs, one table and a chalkboard. There are at least 15 children with disabilities in San Juan de la Concepcion, however only two have been going to school, as the school has no resources. Some children are integrated into public schools, while others stay home.

Thanks to the generosity of students at La Mariposa we donated books, pens, paper, Legos, lacing materials, variety of games, soccer ball, and more! We hope that after this program during the vacation ends, that more children will attend school, and La Mariposa can continue to offer this as a volunteer placement.

The needs for children with disability in this area are huge. We hope this is the first of many projects in the area for children with disabilities. Volunteers are needed between Jan 6th and 20th 2014 for the second half of our program. Volunteers alongside the local teacher and volunteers, will help play with the children, organise a variety of games and activities that are appropriate to the children's developmental level. No experience necessary, but special education teachers, OT's, PT 's, speech therapists very welcome. Intermediate Spanish helpful.


We have undertaken a number of initiatives on our small piece of land to promote wildlife. We have planted and preserved a variety of flora for hummingbirds and butterflies. We reforested the land with trees to increase the local bird population, which includes Nicaragua's national bird the guardabarranco. These efforts to reestablish the natural vegetation have also created a habitat for iguanas, lizards, boas, squirrels, agoutis, and coatis. We also have a frog pond which is home to a variety of species (including a non-poisonous tree frog) that help keep the mosquito population down, as well as provide a chorus in the evenings.

In addition to fostering an environment of diverse flora and fauna, we also rescue and rehabilitate animals. We have a total of five aviaries for our parrots, parakeets, toucans and other birds. All of our birds kept in enclosures have been rescued, and when possible we release them back into the wild. We have also received rescued animals from the community, including four capuchin monkeys, and others which we could not support on our land - for example, once we released a female anteater and her baby into Chocoyero Nature Reserve. Roaming around the property we have seven dogs and five cats, almost all of which have come to us as rescued animals and we have rehabilitated them. Out on the ridges around Volcán Masaya we have a herd of 13 horses, now in semi-retirement, giving rides to our guests on Sundays and by special request. It may surprise many to know that this project is very costly - food, medicine and enclosure maintenance is one of our largest expenditures at La Mariposa! 

Panama is the poorest part of La Concha. The fumes from the Masaya Volcano pass directly overhead, so almost nothing grows there. The Panama primary school services about 200 of the 700 children in the community, although the majority of the children cannot attend school because they have to spend their days helping their families to collect the daily supply of water. With donations from past students, we have built a retaining wall, latrines and a small library. La Mariposa has taken responsibility for regular building maintenance, repainting, and furniture repair/replacement. The guests at the hotel have also donated books, clothing and school supplies. We pay a part time teacher to work with small groups of students in the library, some of whom would be considered to have learning difficulties if they had the resources to be diagnosed. We also used to truck water up to the school for meal preparation, until two generous guests funded the purchase of oxen to do the trip everyday. We hope with the growth of our organic farm that in the future we can provide vegetables to supplement the meals with much-needed vitamins.

Ruben Darío Primary School

Ruben Dario Primary School services more than 200 students from La Concha's barrios Los Encuentros and Los Mercados. Our intention at Ruben Dario has been to replicate the successful library/teaching project that we have at Panama School. La Mariposa and its guests have contributed funds to complete the construction of the library, and supply both the school and library with books, furniture and other school supplies. We received a generous donation that allowed us to undertake a project to build a retention wall to prevent and repair erosion damage. We are paying our teacher full-time now because he is splitting his time between mornings at Panama and afternoons at Ruben Dario. Kids from the morning classes also come in the afternoons to enjoy books from the library in the school's Rincon de Leer (Reading Corner). The library has a lending program so that students can enjoy reading in their spare time at home.


Previously, Paulette initiated a program in the local secondary school educating the students on conservation and protection of the environment. La Mariposa paid a professor to teach a class and organize an Ecological Brigade up until the teacher accepted a position in the local Ministry of the Environment. We still work closely with the Ministry on reforestation projects when feasible. On the Mariposa grounds, we maintain a small plant nursery from which we donate saplings and ornamental plants to our various projects. We plant our trees and other natural flora in schools and public space in and around La Concha. In November 2010 we undertook a project planting 20 or so already large trees around the sports field in San Juan to provide shade.


Although La Mariposa believes that learning English is not essential to local development, we understand that individuals in the community and our staff are often keen to expand their language capabilities. We offer volunteer work for certified English teachers to service the secondary schools in the municipality of la Concha. We also offer hotel guests or volunteers without certification the opportunity to teach English informally through conversation classes to local secondary school students or our staff. Many of our staff would like to learn English in order to communicate more effectively with our guests, which is especially helpful for those people coming to La Mariposa with little or no Spanish background.


The Eco-Tourism project

In October 2010, Paulette attended a meeting hosted by INTUR (the agency responsible for tourism in Nicaragua) at the town hall about promoting tourism in La Concha. From this meeting came the idea that La Mariposa should try to shape the direction of tourism in the community, marketing La Concha as an eco-tourism destination. La Mariposa is committed to working with businesses and touristic places in the community in order to achieve this goal. La Mariposa has already collaborated with El Nisperal Nature Reserve and Coffee Farm offering tours as a means to generate community based tourism in the rural barrio of Palo Solo, La Concha. With future plans to create a field study center for groups seeking a more educational based program, La Mariposa hopes to pursue other community based tourism initiatives in the La Concha.



Daycare Centre at Santiago

The building used in the afternoons for the Reading Corner in Santiago is now being used as a daycare project in the mornings. With the help of foreign development aid, the daycare is a collaborative effort between the department of Masaya and the local town hall. The goal of the project is to provide free childcare to low income families in the neighborhood. La Mariposa became involved in the project because the initial investment was not sufficient to finish the construction of a kitchen to provide a meal in the mornings to children attending the program. We have since been involved in connecting guests to the project in order to secure much needed donations, such as children's toys, books and school supplies. Currently, we are paying half of the teachers' salaries due to a cut in funding, and we will continue to support the project however we can in future.


Youth Sports Project 

Los Zapatos Rotos Corazón De Campeón (Broken Shoes, Hearts of Champions) is a soccer league created by Marlin, one of our Spanish teachers at La Mariposa. He dedicates weekends to working with soccer leagues since he knows the importance sports can play in lives of children and youth, especially in keeping kids out of trouble. La Mariposa is helping Marlin with funding for this league, as well as two new leagues in the municipality. The donations we receive are used to provide prizes and equipment for Marlin's leagues and also enable us to host daylong tournaments for different segments of the municipality. We would like to continue developing sports projects to benefit more children and youth in the community. Finally, with the help of the local town hall we have built a fence to prevent balls from getting destroyed by passing traffic.

The goal of the project is to provide free childcare to low income families in the neighborhood. La Mariposa became involved in the project because the initial investment was not sufficient to finish the construction of a kitchen to provide a meal in the mornings to children attending the program. We have since been involved in connecting guests to the project in order to secure much needed donations, such as children's toys, books and school supplies. Currently, we are paying half of the teachers' salaries due to a cut in funding, and we will continue to support the project however we can in future.


Youth Sports Project Los Zapatos Rotos Corazón De Campeón (Broken Shoes, Hearts of Champions) is a soccer league created by Marlin, one of our Spanish teachers at La Mariposa. He dedicates weekends to working with soccer leagues since he knows the importance sports can play in lives of children and youth, especially in keeping kids out of trouble. La Mariposa is helping Marlin with funding for this league, as well as two new leagues in the municipality. The donations we receive are used to provide prizes and equipment for Marlin's leagues and also enable us to host daylong tournaments for different segments of the municipality. We would like to continue developing sports projects to benefit more children and youth in the community. Finally, with the help of the local town hall we have built a fence to prevent balls from getting destroyed by passing traffic.

story:
Million Mask March Transport Squad

 Because Freedom of speech shouldn't just be for those with money.

  • Hi my name is Ryan and I am an activist and have been to quite a few protests and ran the DC trans squad for last years march.
  • We helped over 20 people from around the country get to and back home from DC for the march.
  • We also booked St. Stephens Church where over 50 protesters slept for two nights!
  • We hope to do the same this year only bigger and better!
  • I constantly see and talk to people who wish they could come and have their voices be heard but financially are not able. I got the idea to get a transportation team started when I saw how effective it was used for the NATO protests in Chicago in May of 2012 where the Nurses Union paid for charter buses to help people who wanted to come but were financially unable to come. They were able to come and express themselves and in the United States the ability to stand up for what you believe in shouldn't be just for those with money.
  • Your donation no matter how big or small will be incredibly appreciated and unbelievably helpful to those willing to go and stand up against a government that no longer has the best interest of the people in mind. Instead they are funded and run by corporations with unlimited money and power. 

What We Need & How it Helps

  • We are looking for enough money to fund the transportation of as many protesters as possible and to reserve St Stephens for people to sleep at if they need a place to stay.
  • You will be able to follow the progress and and updates from our twitter @MMMtransSQUAD or contact us through email at MMMtransportSQUAD@gmail.com
  • If we do not reach our entire goal we will use the money as wisely and efficiently as we can. If you would like your funds to go to something specific i.e. food/water for protesters shoot us an email and specify. We will tweet pics and shout outs with what your funds are going to. You will be kept in the loop every step of the way via twitter so rest assured your money will be put to good use.

The Impact

  • After seeing the effectiveness of transport coordination at the NATO summit and from contributors to the OCCUPY movement which led to occupiers being able to attend the DNC and RNC conventions we see it as essential to coordinate transport to give the maximum amount of people the chance to exercise their first amendment right as possible.
  • If we do not exercise our right to address our grievances with our government we will loose it.
  • Even if you are not able to make it to the march you are still able to help other people get there and your support is incredibly appreciated.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • If you are unable to donate money but still would like to donate something thats great also. Supplies are always needed for actions such as this. i.e. Water, Medical supplies, Masks, Clothes, etc then feel free to contact MMMtransportSQUAD@gmail.com to set up how to send your donations.
  • You can also help by sharing this page with as many people as you can. Literally any and all donations are extremely appreciated even if its a dollar it shows your support and it means the world to us.

Solidarity and Love to you all and see you in the Streets

story:
About Me

Hey, my name is Sean Fournier and I love being creative. I am a singer/songwriter, web designer, I also enjoy illustrating and I hope to one day publish a children's book. I am always getting ideas for projects that I'd like to do and I blast full throttle into creating it. There's always a great feeling of pride when I complete a project. But sometimes, along the way, I lose steam because either I'm not sure how to continue or I lose motivation. I know their are many other people out there like this and that's why I want to create Fostr!

What is Fostr?

Fostr is a place to share the creative projects you've always wanted to finish! Wether you've always wanted to record an album or even build a birdhouse, you can share your dream, post updates, and gain support from the community. The goal of Fostr is to build a community of people who want to share their creative experiences & guide and motivate people to finish their projects.

Why I need Help

I've spent a ton of time thinking of how Fostr will work as a website and a mobile app. I've also crafted a logo and designed a look and feel for the brand. All I need to do now is have it built! I need funding to hire a developer to execute my dream!

Where the Funds go

I'm trying to raise $2500 to get the development started. I am going to need much more than that to really get this idea off of the ground, but I think this will be a good start! If I do not reach my entire goal, the money will still be used to build the app, Ievery little bit counts!

How Fostr Will Change the World

There are so many people out there with great ideas and aspirations, but their project never gets completed because any spare time gets consumed by their day-to-day routines or they just don't know the next steps to take. Fostr will create a place to inspire, educate and guide people to finish their projects! We all know how a certain song or work of art can inspire others. Imagine all of those great ideas that have a better chance of being brought to life with the help of a little motivation and guidance.

My Success

I feel very proud that I have released multiple music albums, created videos and most recently, a project where I release a free song every month. I want to finish a project that can help others achieve their own goals!

story:
Tragedy in the U.S.

2012 Headlines:

  • US Child Poverty Rate Soars to 32%
  • 23 Million children live in poverty. 
  • Last night 20,000 children slept in homeless shelters in New York City

In Texas alone, 1,740,000 children live in poverty (income less than $11,140 per year for a family of four).

Wreck Kills 26-Year-Old Woman

Awful headlines, all of them! How do they relate to each other?

Our daughter, Rachel Ann Carr, was only 26 when a man drove his high performance vehicle into her car at 110 mph. There were no skid marks; his car’s black box confirmed the speed at impact. Rachel’s engine was propelled more than 200 feet through the air. Thus you see the motor and the battery sitting in front of her car. The man is charged with felony homicide and other crimes.

Rachel was beautiful, compassionate and full of life. Her two-
fold goal was to bring happiness to someone every day, and to make someone smile. Rachel had been sexually abused at age 6 by a family friend and she knew the pain that little children sometimes endure. She believed that kids should always be safe and should never have to deal with hunger, abuse or ugliness. At Camp at Rachel’s Ranch we can make hundreds of disadvantaged children smile each day for Rachel!

Rachel’s dream was to build a wonderful camp where poor children could attend for free and experience the activities enjoyed by other the children. She described to us a camp where “kids can just be kids.” Our family members can best endure the grief of losing our youngest child and little sister by building the camp Rachel dreamed of.

One last thing about Rachel- she collected inspirational quotes. You’ll see that many of the perks offered here include various quote gifts made from quotes Rachel collected. Some are inspirational, some are funny.  We also sell them at www.CampAtRachelsRanch.org.  

Let’s Talk About the Camp

Through contributions from generous people like you, and a lot of hard work, we will build Rachel's dream camp to look somewhat like this map. It will include four bunk houses, mess hall, gathering room, crafts and computer center, baseball field, soccer field, sand volleyball pit, a basketball court, swimming pool, archery course, lakeside sports facilities and more.

Larry and I have a personal commitment to the success of the Camp at Rachel’s Ranch. We have closed our business and are dedicating all our time to building and running the Camp. I have 12 years’ experience as a camp director, and Larry has been a builder and geologist. Rachel’s siblings, her friends, and volunteers are eager to help.

What Children Will Attend?

Headline: PressTV US Child Poverty Rate Soars to 32%

Now nearly 1 in 3 children in the US are living in poverty! Our campers will be chosen from these poor children who are recommended by ministers, schools, and government agencies.  These will be children whose families are living in poverty and are unable to pay for a camp experience. In fact, many camps cost as much as these families earn in an entire year!

Rachel wanted ALL campers to attend Camp at Rachel's Ranch at no cost. This means one of our winter activities will be finding ways to fund scholarships for the children to attend each year. We have lined up a steady source of qualified and compassionate camp counselors and instructors to help us care for our campers.

We can run the camp and change these children’s lives, but we can't build it WITHOUT YOU! Will you please help?

What We Need

We need funds. Plain and simple.

Our plan is to build the camp over a period of years, beginning as soon as we have the funds to do so. We’ve accomplished the preliminary issues with establishing the business. With this funding we can begin building the camp itself right away so we can open in June, 2013!

We currently have our eye on a 37-acre property that includes a small house that can be the office, a swimming pool, two lakes, and a 2-story barn that can be converted to bunk rooms. The kitchen is sufficient to feed the children until we can build a mess hall.  This will get us started and be ready for our first year of camp!

All this can be done if we raise $400,000. If we find enough generous people – like you! - to push us over that amount, all funds will be used to improve the property, adding more sports and activity areas shown on the map, and providing transportation and scholarships for campers. We'll start small, likely with 40 campers each session (about 160 the first summer), and build to several hundred campers per session as funds allow.

Won’t you please help us help the children?

We Can’t Thank You Enough - Here comes the fun!

We truly want to thank you for your donation, whether time or money. We think our perks will remind you of Rachel and her camp. You'll see the perks on the right-hand side of the page. They range from personal thank yous, to a set of Rachel's quote cards, to an autographed copy of "Rachel's Little Quote Book - Messages She Left Us," to a week for your family at the Camp at Rachel’s Ranch! Woo-Hoo!

Some of the Perks: 
When you make a contribution, you will receive a gift from the Camp. Some include Rachel's favorite quotes while others say, "I built the Camp at Rachel's Ranch." One even includes a week for you and your family at the Camp when campers are not in attendance.

The Impact YOU Can Make

You can be assured with your donation that you will be personally responsible for:

  • young lives being strengthened
  • self-esteem increased
  • self-sufficiency learned
  • spirits renewed
  • friendships developed, and
  • hope increased

in the campers who attend. 

Can you imagine a young person gaining the self-confidence to know he can accomplish anything if he works hard enough and then becomes the first child in his family to attend college? And all this because of life lessons he learned at the Camp at Rachel’s Ranch that  you helped build!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! The best way to reach our goal is to ask as many people to help as we can. To do that, you can:

  • Regularly post the following link to your Facebook, Pinterest, Google Plus and Twitter accounts, asking your fans to contribute and share in Rachel's dream to help the children. Link: http://www.indiegogo.com/campatrachelsranch?a=1106390                         
  • Copy and send this link to everyone on your email list TODAY.  And again next week, and again the week after. Link: www.indiegogo.com/rachelsranch
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools here on the site. They'll help you share our message at the click of a button.

We want everyone to remember our beautiful daughter, Rachel, and make her goodness live forever by helping us build her dream.

501(c)3 Application Note

We have applied for our 501(c)3 approval, and we're waiting for the IRS to approve the application. Since we can't predict their timetable, we can't guarantee a tax deduction for your contribution until that approval is received.

Want more information?

Camp Contact Information:

Website:  http://www.CampAtRachelsRanch.org (under construction, but usable)

Email:  CampAtRachelsRanch@gmail.com

Facebook: www.facebook.com/RachelsRanch

story:
Eco Womb Tour Update: 

Please help us raise at least $1500 in this next week to cover expenses already accrued to start our Tour this year! We need to raise enough right now for our family to stay on the road! Anything you can do to help us keep our Educational Programs going, we would greatly appreciate. Every $1 helps!

And, please read my blog post on "Putting it all out there..." http://www.ecowomb.com/blog

 

Eco Womb 2012-2013 Tour: The Conscious Caravan

"Connecting Families, Creating Change"

For Eco Womb's 2012 Tour we have launched The Conscious Caravan, a traveling tribe of families connecting communities and creating change through socially and eco-conscious education. Together we are traveling the country visiting communities and connecting the consciousness awakening. Our tour includes community events and workshops to engage, educate, connect, and co-create the change we are all seeking in the world.

But, we need YOUR help to keep the Tour rolling and to fund the community events we are setting up to educate families!

Who We Are

The Eco Womb Tour was launched in November 2010 to educate and connect with families as well as support other small and independent businesses during this time of conscious transformation. We have reached over a hundred thousand people with our message of simple and sustainable living, alternative fuels, renewable energy, natural parenting, living from the heart, healthy living, and organic foods. We have participated in twenty events in just over a year, including the Right to Know March during our Fall 2011 Tour, a historic two week March from NYC to Washington, DC to bring awareness and demand labeling for GMOs. Our Tour also traveled with the Sustainable Living Roadshow to help set up eco-carnivals and educate on sustainable and healthy living.

We have met so many people along the way, open and yearning for connection on all of these issues, that we want to continue. Continue marching to label and eventually ban GMOs; continue supporting local farms and businesses; continue sharing ways to lead a simple, sustainable, and healthy life; continue connecting families through play, art, food, and nature; continue demonstrating how to vote with your dollar and your fork; and, continue connecting communities and families so that they are supported in making these big changes of transformation during this time of a growing consciousness awakening.

Included in The Conscious Caravan is:

*The Malson Family from the Eco Womb Tour - educators on simple and sustainable living, alternative fuels, recycling and zero waste, Non-GMO's, eco-safe family products, and living from the heart.

*The Wagner Family from Sustainable Baby Steps - guiding you to live a healthy, sustainable and meaningful life, one simple step at a time! Including, Tara Wagner from The Organic Sister - a writer, speaker, life coach, and creator of the Digging Deep process, where she coaches women to recreate their lives and families and help them thrive instead of just survive; and, Justin Wagner from Oddball Juggling - a professional juggler who emphasizes the importance of play, meditation, and deepening family connections with the sport of juggling.

*The Anderson Family from the Inspire to Inspire Public Art Project - creating art and spreading inspiration as a family with their life-size mosaic butterfly creation. Including, Jema Anderson from Like a Monarch - a writer, educator and abstract artist who like a monarch is connecting with families through art and personal growth.

*The Taylor Family from the Conscious Kitchen - chefs who know how to nurture families through natural whole foods and daily meals together, connecting families organically through food.

*The Hawk Family from Colony Earth Farm - educators on sustainable agriculture, healing wellness, and indigenous traditions.

What We Do

We offer workshops on sustainable living, alternative fuels, renewable energy, eco-safe products, healthy foods, healthy mind and body, creating sacred places for women, organic life coaching, women's circles, inspiration through art, nurturing your family with whole foods and daily meals, living from the heart, going green, the importance of play, meditation, and following your spiritual path;

-We hold community gatherings, potlucks and bonfires, creating a safe and open space for connection to happen, planting the seeds of change along the way;

-We host movie screenings, speakers, musicians, artists, and performance, bringing the arts together as a way of educating communities; and, 

-We administer a website, forum, Facebook, and Twitter pages in order to thread the connections as we move from place to place, focusing on families and communities to help create change by supporting each other in living sustainably and with intention.

Why We Need Your Help

For over a year, we have been educating and hosting workshops and connecting families, funded solely on our own. We are now seeking to expand the Eco Womb Tour but we need YOUR help.
 
To help fund The Conscious Caravan, we are seeking ---$25,000. This will help cover our community and educational initiatives, keep our tour rolling, and cover basic expenses for setting up events and community gatherings. The funds will cover website development and maintenance, media expenses, marketing materials for flyers and informational pamphlets, educational supplies, event set-up and promotion, movie screenings, gathering locations, and other travel expenses as we seek to continue to connect families and communities along the way.
 
  
To start off the Tour, we Sponsored the Kid Village for Asheville Earth Day on April 21, 2012. Our next event was Drum Strong 2012 on May 19-20, raising money for cancer and creating awareness for healthy living. We then participated in The Conscious Corner Anniversary event at Roots Market in Olney, MD, and Shopping for Truth at Trader Joe's in Portland, ME. We are averaging one event per month, as well as one community potluck and campfire gathering a month to further connect with families and all of the amazing conscious souls we are meeting on the road. We need to raise at least $1500 to cover expenses in participating in these first few events, so by contributing up to this amount you are helping keep our Tour rolling, and cover supplies for our Nature Art activities, our Zero Waste Family Project and Non-GMO Family Awareness Campaign.
 
You can also contribute by inviting us to your community or event, volunteering your time, hosting the caravan, offering food or fuel, or bartering goods and services. We thank you for whatever contribution you can make, as this is only the beginning!
 
 

All donations $25 and up receive an Eco Smiles Organic Tote Bag 

Designed exclusively by Eco Womb, these bags are made from 100% organic cotton jersey fabric grown and sewn right here in the USA. The bag holds 20-30 lbs and you can fold it up and put it in your purse or pocket. Our organic cotton tote bags are printed locally by Planet Ink, using patented vegetable based ink.

Please help us raise at least $1500 in this next week to cover expenses already accrued to start our Tour this year! We need to raise enough right now for our family to stay on the road! Anything you can do to help us keep our Educational Programs going, we would greatly appreciate. Every $1 helps!
And, please read my blog post on "Putting it all out there..." http://www.ecowomb.com/blog
 
Eco Womb 2012-2013 Tour: The Conscious Caravan
"Connecting Families, Creating Change"
For Eco Womb's 2012 Tour we have launched The Conscious Caravan, a traveling tribe of families connecting communities and creating change through socially and eco-conscious education. Together we are traveling the country visiting communities and connecting the consciousness awakening. Our tour includes community events and workshops to engage, educate, connect, and co-create the change we are all seeking in the world.
But, we need YOUR help to keep the Tour rolling and to fund the community events we are setting up to educate families!

Who We Are
The Eco Womb Tour was launched in November 2010 to educate and connect with families as well as support other small and independent businesses during this time of conscious transformation. We have reached over a hundred thousand people with our message of simple and sustainable living, alternative fuels, renewable energy, natural parenting, living from the heart, healthy living, and organic foods. We have participated in twenty events in just over a year, including the Right to Know March during our Fall 2011 Tour, a historic two week March from NYC to Washington, DC to bring awareness and demand labeling for GMOs. Our Tour also traveled with the Sustainable Living Roadshow to help set up eco-carnivals and educate on sustainable and healthy living.
We have met so many people along the way, open and yearning for connection on all of these issues, that we want to continue. Continue marching to label and eventually ban GMOs; continue supporting local farms and businesses; continue sharing ways to lead a simple, sustainable, and healthy life; continue connecting families through play, art, food, and nature; continue demonstrating how to vote with your dollar and your fork; and, continue connecting communities and families so that they are supported in making these big changes of transformation during this time of a growing consciousness awakening.
Included in The Conscious Caravan is:
*The Malson Family from the Eco Womb Tour - educators on simple and sustainable living, alternative fuels, recycling and zero waste, Non-GMO's, eco-safe family products, and living from the heart.
*The Wagner Family from Sustainable Baby Steps - guiding you to live a healthy, sustainable and meaningful life, one simple step at a time! Including, Tara Wagner from The Organic Sister - a writer, speaker, life coach, and creator of the Digging Deep process, where she coaches women to recreate their lives and families and help them thrive instead of just survive; and, Justin Wagner from Oddball Juggling - a professional juggler who emphasizes the importance of play, meditation, and deepening family connections with the sport of juggling.
*The Anderson Family from the Inspire to Inspire Public Art Project - creating art and spreading inspiration as a family with their life-size mosaic butterfly creation. Including, Jema Anderson from Like a Monarch - a writer, educator and abstract artist who like a monarch is connecting with families through art and personal growth.
*The Taylor Family from the Conscious Kitchen - chefs who know how to nurture families through natural whole foods and daily meals together, connecting families organically through food.
*The Hawk Family from Colony Earth Farm - educators on sustainable agriculture, healing wellness, and indigenous traditions.

What We Do
We offer workshops on sustainable living, alternative fuels, renewable energy, eco-safe products, healthy foods, healthy mind and body, creating sacred places for women, organic life coaching, women's circles, inspiration through art, nurturing your family with whole foods and daily meals, living from the heart, going green, the importance of play, meditation, and following your spiritual path;

-We hold community gatherings, potlucks and bonfires, creating a safe and open space for connection to happen, planting the seeds of change along the way;
-We host movie screenings, speakers, musicians, artists, and performance, bringing the arts together as a way of educating communities; and, 
-We administer a website, forum, Facebook, and Twitter pages in order to thread the connections as we move from place to place, focusing on families and communities to help create change by supporting each other in living sustainably and with intention.

Why We Need Your Help
For over a year, we have been educating and hosting workshops and connecting families, funded solely on our own. We are now seeking to expand the Eco Womb Tour but we need YOUR help.
 
To help fund The Conscious Caravan, we are seeking ---$25,000. This will help cover our community and educational initiatives, keep our tour rolling, and cover basic expenses for setting up events and community gatherings. The funds will cover website development and maintenance, media expenses, marketing materials for flyers and informational pamphlets, educational supplies, event set-up and promotion, movie screenings, gathering locations, and other travel expenses as we seek to continue to connect families and communities along the way.
 

  

To start off the Tour, we Sponsored the Kid Village for Asheville Earth Day on April 21, 2012. Our next event was Drum Strong 2012 on May 19-20, raising money for cancer and creating awareness for healthy living. We then participated in The Conscious Corner Anniversary event at Roots Market in Olney, MD, and Shopping for Truth at Trader Joe's in Portland, ME. We are averaging one event per month, as well as one community potluck and campfire gathering a month to further connect with families and all of the amazing conscious souls we are meeting on the road. We need to raise at least $1500 to cover expenses in participating in these first few events, so by contributing up to this amount you are helping keep our Tour rolling, and cover supplies for our Nature Art activities, our Zero Waste Family Project and Non-GMO Family Awareness Campaign.

 

You can also contribute by inviting us to your community or event, volunteering your time, hosting the caravan, offering food or fuel, or bartering goods and services. We thank you for whatever contribution you can make, as this is only the beginning!

 

 

All donations $25 and up receive an Eco Smiles Organic Tote Bag 
Designed exclusively by Eco Womb, these bags are made from 100% organic cotton jersey fabric grown and sewn right here in the USA. The bag holds 20-30 lbs and you can fold it up and put it in your purse or pocket. Our organic cotton tote bags are printed locally by Planet Ink, using patented vegetable based ink.

story:
About me!

My name is Rebecca Lehman and I am a junior at Skyview High School and I am a member of the SMT Magnet program. The magnet program consists of science, math, technology and engineering units. I am currently in the engineering unit and when I graduate, I want to become a mechanical engineer. The SMT Magnet program’s graduation requirements include participating in the International Science and Engineering Fair, ISEF, and earning required credits. I will enroll in this program this year. I am a third-year member of the Skyview High School’s FIRST robotics team. FIRST is a worldwide organization that promotes science and technology at the grade school thru high school levels.  FIRST stands for "For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology". Our robotics team placed third in the Seattle regional competition in 2012. In previous years, I was the team's safety captain and I also helped build the game objects for the competition field.

Important? I think so!

My campaign is important to me because it is helping my school reduce its footprint on the environment.
How your contributions will help me achieve my goal! By contributing to my ISEF project, not only will you be helping me achieve my graduation requirements, you will be helping me develop renewable energy for my school and hopefully set an example for other schools in our area to follow our lead and reduce their own footprint. If we spend less money on energy at our schools, we we can use those funds to support kids who are in need of a little extra help. I hope this project will grow from our high school to many public schools around the country.

What We Need & What You Get

I will be making 4 wind turbines to place on top of Skyview High School. My materials list below represents one turbine.  I hope to build a total of 4 turbines so these quantities will need to adjust. All investment money will be used for my project and to involve and educate the community about renewable energy for public schools.
Materials I will need!

Major Electronics:

Generator Motor, 260 volts DC, 5 amps, with a 6" threaded flywheel

Bridge rectifier, 30-50A, with center hole mount

Copper wire, #8 or larger, red and black, both stranded. Enough length for both a red and black piece to run from the top of the tower, down through length of pole, to batteries.

Battery

Regulator

Fuses

Major Hardware:

PVC pipe (2' length) , 8", Schedule 80

Sheet metal

Metal tubing (36") , 1" square or 1" angle iron

Steel pipe, 10'-30' length of 1-1/2", threaded at both ends

Quick-mix concrete (3-Feb) , 10 lb. bags

Guy wire, galvanized steel with a working load of 200 pounds

Turnbuckles (4)

PERKS!?

For the minimum contribution we will put your name on part of our wind turbine. for higher perks, we offer various gifts such as t-shirts, flash drives, engineering drawings, a miniature 3D model of our project or even part of an actual turbine blade! See the details above.  Show your support for the environment, clean air and renewable energy!
We appreciate all the help that we can get, because this project will quickly get very expensive.

Other Ways You Can Help Us Out!   Lets talk about these highlighted things.

If you can't afford a donation, don't worry! There are still ways you can help us!
Spread the word about our amazing project on your Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, blog etc.  Just because you might not be able to help doesn't mean you can’t help spread the word!

story:
GooTopia

We're trying something different. The world doesn't need another generic toddler book about shapes or numbers or letters or rhymes or comparisons...there are plenty out there to choose from.

What kids need is to develop character. There are books on the market with a character message, but no comprehensive set of books that introduces young learners to different aspects of character, and helps them to have fun doing it.

So we decided to build GooTopia, a place to tell intertwining character stories, because in the real world character values are all intertwined. We plan to develop 50 stories about individual Goo Guys & Gals, each representing an important character value. We also plan to build more and more interactivity into our site GooGuysAndGals.com, where each Goo Guy or Gal has their own character profile.

GooTopia Graphic Readers are different in a number of other ways. We intend for these books to grow with your child. That starts with you. At the earliest ages, you'll sit down and read the stories and do the activities with them. That gets them interested in reading, and it helps them to pattern their brain for character thinking. They'll read the pictures and begin to format the left to right, top to bottom reading direction. They'll also be getting ready for school by searching for and identifying letters, shapes colors and numbers with you. They'll even be expanding their vocabulary, and their awareness of the variety of interests people can pursue in life. And they'll have lots of fun with the songs and the audio extras! All of these "hooks" (ways of learning) will reinforce the character message over time.

Then as your child grows older, they'll begin to explore the books and the site on their own. The graphic layout of the books will help them to understand the sentences and phrases in each frame. There are over 80 Dolch List words in each book, preparing them for fluent reading later. The profiles, activities and links on the Goo Guys And Gals site will  reinforce the character message while teaching them about new interests. Although the target age for these books is 3-7, we've had some younger toddlers and some older children up to 12 and over really enjoy Olympia On-Time.

Olympia On-Time

This is our beta book, we printed 400 copies and are sharing them with local educators, kids groups and parents. We continue to gather feedback and will incorporate it into future stories. This campaign is to try to  secure funding for a pilot study of cartoon format books and materials in (character) learning, using Olympia On-Time and some other cartoon tools. We intend to make these the best books they can be.

The Olympia story follows a formula that we will keep throughout the series. First the negative side of the character value is presented. The character realizes the problems it causes. Then the positive side of the character value is presented, along with the solutions it brings.

The size is roughly 6" x 6", making it perfect for for manipulation by little hands (another essential skill). All of the books will be brightly colored and come with a Goo Guide that explains how to get the most out of the book.



Science Behind the Books

We've read a lot of studies and we won't bore you with all the details, but these books are built on four over-arching premises:

•Vocabulary by the age of three plays a strong roll in future cognitive capacity (which is why we encourage you to start reading to you child as early as possible).

•Children who are prepared for school with certain skills before they start do better and go further in school. Our books incorporate exercises for a number of those skills (see below).

•There is a massive spurt of right brain dendritic branching from the ages of 4-7. We believe that the graphic format, with visual and situational cues, infused action and emotion, and idea summaries are the best way to reach their young minds in a lasting way.

•Character has been shown in tests to correlate more highly with success in school and achievement in life than IQ. Why not  get children started on character education as early as possible?


Who is Wade Gugino?

I am a cartoonist with my own small studio (GooGenius, LLC). I apply cartoons to communication needs in business, education and commerce. I played professional basketball overseas for fifteen years before starting my cartooning career. During that time I studied how cartoons are used in Europe, and contributed cartoons (in French!) to newspapers and magazines. I have dual citizenship and speak French...which is why I'm hoping someone scoops up our big reward to the right. If you have any questions, about me, don't hesitate to ask at Questions@GooGuysAndGals.com. 

What is ArtPrize (from the video)?

It's a huge open art contest in Grand Rapids, MI. The radio interview on the bottom lefthand side of the GooGuysAndGals.com homepage talks more about GooToopia, ArtPrize, and gives you an idea of where we stand at the moment. 

What do we need the money for?

•A mixed-methodology pilot study of the impact of cartoons and cartoon stories on character learning. This won't cover the whole tab, but we believe we can make up the difference through local grants if we meet our goal here. We have been working with the West Michigan Character Council on grant funding for a while now and we have some grant making entities willing to fund  a larger study and our materials if we can show some more traction. This campaign is to try to show that traction. We have a Chicago based evaluation team that has been interested in conducting this study for over a year. We just need the funds to do it. This is a small but significant step on the way to a much larger GooTopia. If we receive funding, the pilot will be conducted in late winter and spring. All of your names will go into the final report on a backers page, and you'll receive a PDF version of the findings.

•If we do not reach full funding, depending on the amount we do reach, we may be able to convince some local philanthropists to help us make up the difference. 

•If neither of those options pans out, we will put any funding we receive into marketing Olympia On-Time, and developing Rolando Responsible, the second GooTopia Graphic Reader.

Like any campaign, we'd love it if we need stretch goals...any extra funds will go to developing more of our books and the website so kids can enjoy a more complete GooTopia. We'll update you with what that means specifically as the need arises.

Rewards


The Impact

While we can't guarantee the impact of GooTopia, we believe it will grow and exert a positive influence on future generations to all of our benefit. Character has universal value, regardless of economic status, race, education, culture or any other variable. We believe the appeal of GooTopia to kids allows the real possibility of broad international impact.

You could be a huge part of that. Even if you can't support us financially, you can help us get the word out. Please feel free to share Olympia On-Time and GooGuysAndGals.com in every way you possibly can. And live out character daily...that is, after all, the goal...little eyes are watching!

story:
The Story

South Chicago, 2008. In the wake of the Great Recession, a group of college kids at The University of Chicago founded Moneythink as a way to empower disadvantaged youth to pursue their dreams. They served as peer-mentors in local inner-city classrooms, teaching financial literacy and entrepreneurship workshops.

Pretty soon, students were coming back to their Moneythink mentors with stories: one student had secured a scholarship with the help of her mentor, another had helped his mom keep the heat on in the winter using his new budgeting skills, and yet another launched a student store.

Within a few years, Moneythink programs had spread to 18 campus communities nationwide and had been recognized by President Obama at the White House--a grassroots movement by Gen Y for Gen Y was under way!

No Obstacle Too Great

Now, Moneythink is taking it to the next level. We're hiring a small, full-time staff, building out new curricula, and developing enhanced training methods. 

To prove that we're serious, and to show that we believe no obstacle is too great to overcome, Moneythinkers Chirag Sagar, Sam Smith, and Ted Gonder are participating in the toughest athletic event on the planet: a 12 mile obstacle course designed by the British Special Forces to test all-around strength, stamina, mental grit, and camaraderie. 

The Mission

Our mission in running this race is to inspire young people to believe in their dreams and motivate them to take control of their lives, defeat fear, and reach success.

  • We are a group of Moneythinkers who constantly strive to become better individuals, face challenges, and empower others.
  • When we learned about Tough Mudder, the premier obstacle course in the world, we decided to train ourselves and do our best to motivate younger generations to do things that seemed impossible and out of reach.
  • For weeks, we have physically exhausted our bodies by alternating routines such as HIIT, TEMPO & ENDURANCE.
  • We hope this event will motivate other Moneythinkers to contribute to our efforts of transforming lives and building a more sustainable community.
  • We want to continue empowering high schoolers across the country to make money & manage money with the right knowledge and tools.

We want financial empowerment for all. We are Moneythink!

The Facts

  • More than 2/3 of young adults in the US lack basic financial knowledge.
  • To make matters worse, financial education courses are required for graduation in only 13 states.
  • Urban youth are particularly at-risk because they lack access to proper financial services and exposure to financial knowledge via family and peers. Inadequate public education and twice-national-average unemployment rates exacerbate urban youth’s financial illiteracy, entrenching them in a vicious cycle of poverty.
  • This cycle of poverty denies urban youth adequate resources to become financially capable, income-generating adults.

The Impact

You contributions will help us to expand our efforts as we make the leap to build a full-time operation and a sustainable model in the 2012-2013 school year. All of your funds go straight to operations on the ground, in the classroom; none of your funds pay for our flights or tickets to the race (we paid for those out-of-pocket). 

  • $10 trains a mentor to volunteer and serve in a local classroom.
  • $25 provides mentorship and financial education for three students and equips them with invaluable knowledge to succeed.
  • $100 helps sustain our internal technology and communication infrastructure to keep volunteers updated and equipped to make an impact.
  • $250 provides mentorship and financial education for THIRTY students (a full classroom!)...that's less than the price of Netflix for a year.

Please contribute to this cause and be part of the positive cycle of change!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Spread the word! The more people you tell about this, the higher the probabilities of reaching our goal will be and the more lives you will change!

Facebook, Twitter, Google + & Email, you name it!

All of your funds go straight to operations on the ground, in the classroom; none of your funds pay for our flights or tickets to the race (we paid for those out-of-pocket). 

$10 trains a mentor to volunteer and serve in a local classroom.
$25 provides mentorship and financial education for three students and equips them with invaluable knowledge to succeed.
$100 helps sustain our internal technology and communication infrastructure to keep volunteers updated and equipped to make an impact.
$250 provides mentorship and financial education for THIRTY students (a full classroom!)...that's less than the price of Netflix for a year.

Please contribute to this cause and be part of the positive cycle of change!


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Spread the word! The more people you tell about this, the higher the probabilities of reaching our goal will be and the more lives you will change!

Facebook, Twitter, Google + & Email, you name it!

story:
Our Story

South East Asia has a long and noble history; sadly the last century has been full of war after war after war. These wars have created deep deficiencies in the educational system and the great majority of the people, even today, don't have a high school education. The scars of war still run deep and many people still suffer the effects of wars long gone by. Yet even with deep scars and fresh wounds the people here are resilient and many choose to help their fellow human. Yet the desire to help is not always enough. After 18 months in South East Asia I have met many optimistic and helpful people, community based organizations and Non-Governmental organizations that are doing fantastic jobs at helping others. They free sex slaves, rehabilitate landmine victims, fight government land grants that steal their homelands without compensation, help the poorest find innovative solutions to pull themselves out of poverty, educate the future generations and so much more.  There is heart, there is determination but there is also a lack the knowledge on how to increase their outreach and success.  

 

I have already started giving free trainings to these altruistic souls. Trainings to help them get and keep the funds they need to expand. Trainings to make sure that their finances and policies stay transparent. Trainings to help them and the world see how much of a difference they are creating in the lives of others.  

 

I will continue to do my training's in a more mobile fashion, traveling myself to communities that have organizations that are helping them but would like to have my training's. There in the communities I will give my trainings.

 

There are 4 main subjects that include multiple trainings. They are:

 

1.       Successful funding

2.       Organizational transparency

3.       Monitoring and Evaluation

4.       Research training's

 

The Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) training is always in high demand as most people haven’t had the chance for a formal education in this field. There are three classes for this training. The first one is Field data collection which helps them develop monitoring skills in how to collect information about those they help. Like all classes this class has in the field activities, in the past I have assigned projects to trainees for them to develop research goals and then go to specific areas and collect the research. This class is about 24-28 hours. The next class is on Evaluation. This class teaches them how to get the collected data and use it in a way that they can better understand it.  This class is about 16 hours. The final class is management through data which helps trainees learn that they can make decisions based on the data they collect.  For example they learn that If the data is reliable and it says that program A increased a family’s income by 50% while program B increased a family’s income by 400%, then they can focus more on developing program B. This may seem obvious; however without the data it is not obvious and even with the data making big changes like that can sometimes be very difficult for an organization that does not understand the underlying information. This class is about 16 hours.

 

The Impact

One person with a good idea and a good heart can change a lot. Yet if they can get to expand on their ideas, they can increase their impact. If they learn how to measure their impact then they can show others how well it works then others will follow their lead.  

My trainings don't develop the ideas, they develop the individual and help them to find the help they need and to show their successful ideas to others. The reason I do this for free is because I truly believe that through providing these "capacity trainings" we can assure that the best ideas and practices that come from any person or group gets perpetuated and that the most amount of people as possible are affected.

If these people do not get trained they will continue to do good but the expansion of the good they do will be slower or might not happen at all.

In a real life example, an small community based organization with limited funding attended a M&E training (which was 100% free to all participants) and later went on to share their results with large international aid agencies. the agencies were so impressed by the information and their program results that they agreed to fund the project for 5 years.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am currently seeking $5000 to fund this project. 

 

$1000 for a new projector   Richard Cassada pledged a projector!

 

$2000  for translators. I can speak quite a few local languages at this point, but not always to the level that I need to. Many community organizations can provide English translators for me if their staff do not speak English. But for those that cannot I want to be able to help them regardless of the language barrier. Because of this I am seeking $2000 to pay for a estimated 100 translation days. At $20 per day. 

 

$1000 for rent. Constantly I get the office space I need for free. However some of my training's require that I train people on how to use some computer programs. Because of this I occasionally need to rent out Computer cafes for whole days. 50$ a day is usually enough to rent out a whole cafe to train about 15 people. This much money should be enough to rent out computer cafes for a total of 20 days which would allow me to train about 300 people in different aspects.

$500 to help with transportation. I can't take my training everywhere, sometimes borders or infrastructure block me or the place I want to do a training in just doesn't have access to electricity. I need $500 to subsidize travailing expenses for community workers. The money will help pay for the buses, oxcarts, motos and horses that they have to take to come to where I host my training's.

 

$500 to cover my other training costs. For my training's I often do a lot of printing for hand outs and activities. I also hand out DVD's that contain my presentation and activities so that attendees can go over them later or train others in the future.  I believe $500 would be enough for printing and CD costs over the next 6 months.


 

Please remember I am not asking anything for myself. I will give my trainings for free, but with your help I can increase my impacts and truly help others who help those most in need.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can fund the whole project yourself I still need your help. I need help from experts to strengthen my trainings, I need help from adventurers to help me give trainings (don't worry I can train you to train), and I need volunteers who can help with media and fundraising.

story:
The Story

 

My name is Nathalie Jackson. My husband, 3 boys (and various animals) and I have been living on our land (just south east of Edmonton, Alberta, Canada) for 3 years now and have been studying and learning and gathering with other people who love the Earth and desire to live more consciously upon Her. As a collective, we have been celebrating all that is beautiful and joy-filled about being in community. We have been on our individual paths of awareness, expansion and transformation and believe that at the heart of the Earth's changes, we must continue to stay true to our most authentic selves, speak honestly and boldly when our heart has something to say, and live harmoniously with the Earth, the animals, our neighbors, and all living things. Our Council has expanded to include other visionaries in the community. Together we are co-creating the vision and the model that will be repeatable in other parts of the world. It is our vision to create a similar educational center in British Columbia, Canada. There are many intentional eco villages in existence worldwide. Through conscious relationship building and eagerness to learn, we have been visiting other such communities and researching the systems that are working for each.

 

It is our desire to build an intentional eco-farm on our land. This community will have at its heart a 3000 sq. ft. educational facility that will host The Academy of Alchemical Arts. The Academy will focus on various forms of healing and  transformation through meditative practices, conscious dance classes, wholistic arts and therapies, traditional indigenous arts and wisdom, and the ancient alchemical arts. The facility will also host workshops and trainings by local and international facilitators on sustainable/green living, community building and living, wholistic nutrition/whole foods, and so much more. The facility will be available to the greater community for meetings, conferences and gatherings. This centre will hold the vision of a new future for humanity, as the council meets on a regular basis to vision and guide all decisions that are made in the community.

 

Our eco-farm grows the healthiest food possible using the most sustainable methods and materials as the foundation of an open source model for sustainable living that will bring a new ethos for humanity. The eco-farm will work towards growing a majority of the food itself, while also supporting local farmers and food producers in the surrounding communities. The new ethos will begin in our own back yard by nurturing the body, mind and spirit of the people in our local communities, while providing information and resources globally.

 

Presently there is a Red Tent Temple on the land, where ceremonies and celebrations are held regularly that honor all walks of life, all religious backgrounds, all ethnicities and cultural paradigms. There is also an outdoor sauna for purification and healthy living practices. Various communities meet here to celebrate, learn, grieve, rejoice, and otherwise experience all aspects of human life.

 

Future vision includes the building of monolithic dome structures to host various wholistic and creative arts and therapies, sustainable greenhouses for year-round food production, amphitheatre to host concerts and festivals, housing accommodations, nature trails, gardens, and labyrinth.

 

The Impact

As a result of leading by example, our eco-farm inherently teaches how to live sustainably with all of life. The food we grow, harvest and prepare through sustainable, least-impact, energy-efficient systems fuels the healing, transformation and growth of our staff and community in short-term and long-term onsite and offsite educational wellness programs. Our programs focus on teaching skills for living in excellence across the mental, emotional, physical and spiritual domains of life.

 

The building of this educational center will impact the local community by providing valuable resources and education about growing our own food, living sustainably, and transforming ourselves and our lives to better reflect a conscious, new humanity.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Stage One – Residential Educational Center

 

The Educational Facility, hosting the Academy of Alchemical Arts, will be built to support 200 people at any given time. It will be 3000 sq. ft., have a commercial kitchen and rooms for residential living during training. This stage will cost $500,000. The funding to initiate the project will begin at $150,000, at which point the structure will be built and the community can gather in the space.

 

If you are interested in seeing the financial background and plan for this project, please contact Nathalie at info@nathaliejackson.com. We are pleased to share the particulars with all those who support this vision.

 

As our goal of $150,000 is reached, further funding will help the completion of the building to be completely off-grid, sustainable and fully operational.

 

As this model will be able to be replicated, your support will also help our vision of the creation of educational centers and sustainable community living in other areas of the world. We currently have partners who are researching possible other locations in Western Canada.  There are similar visions and communities in existence worldwide and our team has been researching and visiting such locations. It is our intent to continue to build sustainable relationships with these communities, learn from the expertise and proven systems of these groups, and build upon the wisdom that surrounds us.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Spread the word! Start thinking globally. Intend to be a part of the evolution!

 

Post on facebook…Tell your friends…Send to you email list.

 

Get excited about the shifts and changes that are happening. Know that your part in the change is an important one.
